## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Welcome to Coin Talk, Jay Kang back in the crypto cave."
## [1] " I feel like Ive returned home."
## [1] " Theres way pegboard than there was last time you were here, right?"
## [1] " Yeah. And theres also some sort of acoustic, ceiling things going on I think that you just put in."
## [1] " Those have always been there."
## [1] " Oh, well they seem a bit askance, Aaron. Like I feel-"
## [1] " Theyre not straight at this point."
## [1] " Did you have like a small earthquake in here or something like that?"
## [1] " No, I think I was just wrestling around behind the wire there. I had a little flood. Thats probably why everything got knocked askance. One thing I actually was curious to get your take on, I was reading Ryan Selkis email newsletter this morning. And he was commenting on now that were seeing a little light at the end of the tunnel, a little bounce back, like looking back on this big downturn that happened, what coins held their value the best against Bitcoin. This is something weve talked about, like-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Alt coins can be a lot of fun while youre playing with them, but youre gonna like youre gonna take a hit during a dip, and crunched what were the five coins that held their value the best. A couple of them Im not familiar with Bytom, Zilliqa, ZXL, EOS, BNB, Binance coin and OmiseGo OMG, your old favorite."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " And the thing that he noticed amongst these coins that held their value the best, is that theyre all less than a year old."
## [1] " OMG is less than a year old?"
## [1] " I guess so. I didnt know that either. But what do you think about that? As we look at these other projects over time, do you think that theres gonna be a recency bias where stuff thats newer, people are more likely to hold on to during a downturn?"
## [1] " I think I would ask a question before that-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which is like what are we expecting to figure out? Like what do we think that this holding of value tells, right?"
## [1] " Right. Thats a good question. I mean I would think it would be a signal of long term viability of the project that people are willing to hodl its tokens through a dark winter."
## [1] " Yeah. I guess I would just say that like a five then would be too small of a sample for me to think that was viable because something like BNB-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which is the sort of utility token that Binance Exchange puts out."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " There are all sorts of reasons why it wouldnt lose its value. It could be because people are actually still using it to trade during down periods of time. It could be that like CZ who is the guy whos the head of Binance, it could be that he has all of them and just them throughout it. And Im not saying any of this is true obviously, but I think that I would need a slightly larger sample size to figure out if theres any sort of correlation or any sort of story that we could tell out of it."
## [1] " I like your take that. I actually think there is an explanation in terms of BNB, which is that Im not positive about this but I think that Binance has started auto converting, what is referred to as dust. The like little-"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah."
## [1] " Bits of coins that are left over in transactions, they infinitesimal, decimal points into their native token, BNB-"
## [1] " Wow."
## [1] " Automatically, so as not to leave you Which I actually appreciate-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Cause Ive got My Bittrex account is chockfull of weird scraps that are less than a coin, but that would kind of explain like an inflow of automated interest in BNB-"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " If every single transactions generating a little BNB for people."
## [1] " The subtext to all of this seems to be that coins in which people seem to have a lot of faith in both the technology and the longevity of the projects, did they do badly. Like So something like monero, which we talk about here a lot, Zcash, Ethereum I guess Ethereum probably He wasnt including that, was he?"
## [1] " I dont know."
## [1] " Well I mean Ethereum got wrecked anyway."
## [1] " Yeah, Ethereum got pretty wrecked. I dont know Like Im not sure exactly what has like pegs were, but like bottom Ethereum was wrecked to Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah."
## [1] " Like if you were holding all Ethereum, you did worse than someone who was holding all Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yeah, I think significantly worse. So I guess that would be the underlying question, right? Like did Was there institutional and investor faith in these long term projects and in these big projects that allow them to weather this sort of storm better than something that felt completely like vaporware-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And that was just being ridden for like pumps and dumps? And he seems to have shown at least in limited form, this is not that maybe that wasnt true."
## [1] " Yeah. I mean I agree the sample size was low and it does seem anecdotally like monero and Zcash and a lot these privacy coins that have more of a real world utility right now did hold their value pretty well compared to like alt as a whole. But I kind of agree with you. Like someone was saying that those privacy coins have done well recently because of like like some porn thing accepting them or something like-"
## [1] " Pornhub."
## [1] " Whats that?"
## [1] " Pornhub."
## [1] " Pornhub accepting them. So as usual, I think theres like maybe too many factors to read a lot of these things clearly."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " But thats an interesting idea in its own right, that like there are so many forces acting on these coins that to try to draw any sort of a singular narrative of it, is to draw a false narrative around it."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " But I would I wish I could just sort Like cause a lot of these projects, I dont know how old they are. I love that this was more like Saved by the Bell classes, you know? Where it was like the first year of alts, the second year of alts, like next generation. You know? Because I do think that-"
## [1] " This summer with Stacey Carosi."
## [1] " Yeah. I think that they I do think the different waves of this stuff are pretty different from each other and how you would evaluate a project thats like one year old, versus a project thats like two or three years old would be different in your expectations of how far along they would be and I wish as an investor, I had more of a thesis about the age of the projects that Im buying into."
## [1] " Yeah. I have no idea either and honestly there is part of me that When I think about a project thats very old and I research it and theres not much new about it, I sometimes wonder if it still exists or not. So I wanted to talk to you about something which is that This is a story out of China that I actually found interesting-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " In terms of people always asking this. I guess its the infinite question about what is the blockchain, does it actually have any applications, and it China it seems like And look, this heavy caveated story I dont know if its real-"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " It was on Yahoo, so can take that for what it is."
## [1] " Probably not real then."
## [1] " But in China, there was a student who was looking into sexual harassment at a university 20 years as part of sorta this extension of MeToo I would say. And like theres a documentary about this recently called Red Sparrow, which was a very similar narrative in which somebodys looking back in the past. Did you see that?"
## [1] " Wait, isnt Red Sparrow that most recent like Russian action thriller? Or is there two movies called Red Sparrow?"
## [1] " No, no, no. I think theres two movies called Red Sparrow."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " This is like a Chinese film student who made it."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " It was very good and it might not be called Red Sparrow, so whatever. Like well figure it out."
## [1] " Look as weve said, none of this is investment advice."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I got wrong how the blockchain was created. Jay has totally misidentified the film Red Sparrow, which Im pretty sure-"
## [1] " I think thats Jennifer Lawrence in there, right?"
## [1] " Is a Jennifer Lawrence action vehicle that was recently-"
## [1] " Its red something. All right. So-"
## [1] " I was wondering how youre gonna tie the Jennifer Lawrence vehicle Red Sparrow, into Chinese blockchain censorship and I was ready for some verbal fireworks."
## [1] " I looked it up. Its Hooligan Sparrow."
## [1] " Hooligan Sparrow."
## [1] " Hooligan Sparrow."
## [1] " Its a great title."
## [1] " It is a good title."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " It was a good documentary. Its a very similar narrative in which a woman is trying to investigate something that has happened and she comes up against all sorts of resistance and censorship, so-"
## [1] " Okay. Hooligan Sparrow is similar to this blockchain story."
## [1] " Yeah, to this blockchain. This young student at Peking University is trying to figure out what happened 20 years ago."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " All of her questions are rebuffed and that she feels somewhat at danger but she still writes an open letter to Peking University and she puts it on WeChat and it goes viral. Right? And shes like, Why are you not answering these questions? A lot of the messaging apps in China start taking this letter down."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And so people in China to get around it, do things like theyll like embed the text in an image and then send that around so that it doesnt quite match up with the image-"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " So that it stays there, but that starts getting taken down. Then someone has the idea to put it on the Ethereum blockchain and so at that point, it cant be taken. And so the Yahoo article, which is somewhat non-committal about it because its not advocacy journal. Its saying that like this is actually an interesting application of the blockchain. What do you think about this?"
## [1] " I think my mind goes very quickly to the dark side when I think about this stuff. I actually just talked to I was talking to Charlie Warzel, who weve had on this show and with all of the things that are happening to the big American tech companies, which themselves were originally identified with allowing for the kind of speech that were talking about. That there were forums where anyone, not just someone who had a magazine or a printing press or whatever could get their message out, could freely express themselves, and now a lot of those systems have been co-opted."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " And so the blockchain does feel like a step forward along that progression, but I just immediately jumped inerasable tax. Its like the force, theres like the light in the light in the dark side of it. I cant imagine that people were not gonna find some pretty like dark uses for the same thing."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Should I not let like the bad possibilities ruin the good possibilities for me?"
## [1] " Like this is something in our world, right? Like Not our world, because you refuse to acknowledge that youre a journalist in any sort of way. But weve had a lot of controversies all the way up to Joy-Ann Reid right now, which if you dont know she had a blog a while back and theres a homophobic post. And shes saying now that she didnt make them and that some hack-"
## [1] " She said she got like hacked or something?"
## [1] " Yeah, that some hacker went back and time stamped it and inserted those blogs into her old blog."
## [1] " Im gonna set an overall rule for humanity. If you got hacked and youre gonna claim in the future that you hacked, you have like Its like the 30 second rule for food dropping on the floor, you gotta call out, I got hacked."
## [1] " Immediately."
## [1] " Its like a bank shot. You cant be like I called bank like three days later."
## [1] " Yeah. Theres no one who got hacked. Like my favorite example of this is the guy on Villanova in the national championship who hit all those shots. I forget his name, but like he was the MVP of the finals."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And he had all these problematic tweets from when he was 16 or 17 years old, which is understandable, 17 year olds say stupid shit."
## [1] " Absolutely."
## [1] " But Villanova immediately right at when theyre asked were like, He was hacked. And then youre like he was not hacked. Unless some hacker went back four years ago and changed all of his tweets. Its actually functionally impossible for him to be hacked and then they scrubbed the he was hacked line. But they tried to follow your rule of 30 seconds, but went the wrong way cause they just lied about it. But I tend to I agree with you."
## [1] " Those things make no sense, cause its like you got hacked and then you got back control of your account, but you left the homophobic tweets that were like there from the hacking."
## [1] " Yeah. So the Joy-Ann Reid thing is interesting because its sort of both sides of it. Right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " If she had published all those on the blockchain, then no one could hack it because she would always have a record of what she had said at the time."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " And But at the same time, it also shows how if you do say something in the past that can be misconstrued or excerpted or however and never disappears, that also can be bad. You know?"
## [1] " Yeah. I feel like you should be able to like discount some things you said when you were 16 or 17."
## [1] " Yeah. And I mean like theres some people who because of that, myself included, who put on programs to delete all your tweets after a few days. Theres a great argument to be had and I like I obviously am one side of it and some people would say well as a journalist, you should have all these things be public record forever. And Im like I only tweet about the NBA. You know?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So I dont think its really that big of a deal. But you know like it really is sort of scary to think that if you are 17 years old right now or 16 years old, and youre in like a the type of thing that young people do, which is try and say the most horrible thing to your friends-"
## [1] " Youre 17, youre publishing willy-nilly on the Ethereum blockchain. You dont know where this could lead."
## [1] " Exactly. Exactly. Exactly. You and your friends are making like horrible racist and holocaust jokes to one another."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And then its there forever. Like it seems like you shouldnt do those things, but Im sorry. Its just like a part of young behavior and if a system gets normalized in which everybody can see it and it is forever, that might be bad."
## [1] " Okay. Im gonna play the other side here and say what this woman has done in China is not publish her entire life history to the Ethereum blockchain. Shes taken a particular document that was already subject to state censorship or unofficial state censorship and said, This is important I want this to pursue this."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Do you think that like having some sort of a more subjective to it that if were not saving everything, but were like very specifically saving somethings that could have a utility?"
## [1] " Yes. And thats where I feel like that people should strive to go with this type of project."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So we had Maria Bustillos sign it before with Popula and she said that theyre going to publish all their articles to the note section of the Ethereum blockchain and that it would be immutable."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And that nobody could take it down."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Now I would say that projects like that make sense to me and it is a take it or leave it type of thing. Theres no totality where every tweet that you and I put out or every text that I send to you needs to be on these blockchains. Right? Like it can be specific tool thats used in these sorts of instances and I find it very hard anyone who had argued that its not good in these cases. Like if this China story is true, thats great, they get Its a way to get around censorship, its a way raise awareness about what might have happened 20 years ago and it a way to get around like what is People in China are very afraid right now because of whats happening with Xi Jinping and the threat of a totalitarian government there, that is more oppressive than it is right now in terms of information. And if there already turning to the blockchain, I think thats a plus."
## [1] " Its interesting. Like I was like well okay, so what is the analog equivalent of this? Like what is the pre-digital equivalent, and I think its the book. The book is the immutable artifact. Yeah, like books have been lost to history, but you know thats like Outside of a 1984 type history, thats what books are. If you publish a book, the contents of that book are generally written into history, particularly in the 20th century. Very hard to make a book totally disappear from the public consciousness and I think weve been able to navigate that pretty effectively. Like the fact that Mein Kampf still exists and has not been purged from the world, I think is a good thing."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I think its worthwhile to allow for a class of information thats immutable."
## [1] " I agree with you and I think that it needs to be efficient in a way where people given the speed with which they need information now can access it. And I would say that of all the stories that I read week about Bitcoin, blockchain, this one was the most exciting to me because it seemed to be the type of thing A, that a lot of people can rally around. Its not about like some sort of abstract idea and its not about money. It is really about something that I think a lot of people would agree is a good thing, which is to sort of fight censorship in countries like China."
## [1] " I guess if CHinas able to censor internet sites and http requests, what stops them from just blocking the Ethereum blockchain from China wholesale to prevent this kinda stuff from being disseminated?"
## [1] " Can they actually do that?"
## [1] " I dont know. Thats a really interesting question. Like how would someone go about blocking the blockchain?"
## [1] " I dont know. Thats a question for somebody else."
## [1] " Okay. Well have to ask someone that on the show."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I think that if this becomes prevalent enough, this will become an issue, like And all of the things that we think about, decentralized applications and blockchain becoming a new form of internet like-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Or a replacement for the internet. There was a time when the internet itself was uncensorable."
## [1] " Exactly."
## [1] " Until people figured out how to censor it."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. I know and thats But thats what is the most exciting part about this for me. I remember what I was excited about-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which is that it Like in terms of the new internet right?"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " Which is a phrase thats thrown out all the time and it sounds ridiculous."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " But this is really the first thing where I was like oh, maybe it really is the new internet in some sort of way, because AWS cant shut this down. You know? A lot of people already have this in a way where it cant be taken off. I guess it could be taken off if more than 50% of the people decide made some sort of decision or something like that, but thats certainly not gonna happen. And it seems like a different way to sort of store information in an era in which we have highly centralized powers that do control the internet and do control information. Its just a different path and itll get more efficient, itll get more elegant, itll be easier to access and then at that point, I feel like you might have an actual new internet."
## [1] " Yeah. I mean weve made jokes on the show about like trying to store information in the notes field of Ethereum blockchain thats like real user friendly. But theres no reason someone cant build user friendly interfaces for some of the stuff and really create a new internet that does allow you to navigate some of these decentralized spaces effectively. Were just in an incredibly nascent stage right now."
## [1] " Yeah. Like do you I mean And you and I are about the same age and about the same level of nerdiness, but like do you remember how hard it was to play MUDs back in the day?"
## [1] " Oh, my God."
## [1] " Did you ever play MUDs?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " It was horrible. You had to like You had to-"
## [1] " Did you used to call bulletin board services when you were younger?"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. Of course. You had to like We had to like cue up our modems."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " We had to memorize these lines of texts and then this complete I dont think I could decipher it right now. And these like completely decipherable indecipherable like lines of texts would come up and then youd train your brain to figure it out. Like that was not that long ago. Like that was probably what? Like when you and I were like 15 or 16 years old, so it was like 22 years ago."
## [1] " I feel like that was more of like when we were like 12 maybe."
## [1] " Well Im a couple years older than you."
## [1] " Youre a couple years ahead of me, yeah. And I remember how much you had to learn about the systems you were using before you could anything on them."
## [1] " Yeah. You had to learn like why the modem works."
## [1] " The MS-DOS prompts, you know? Like just to play a game, you kinda had to know like-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The entire DOS language and I think that was valuable and I think that Something that is exciting to me about decentralized crypto projects is theyre not that easy and if people do get involved in them, teenagers, 12 year olds or whatever, theyre gonna know way more than you and I do. And while theyre learning how to use them, they are gonna be creating the future of them in the way that like we learned how to use the internet, and that became the internet. The kinds of things we were learning about on bulletin boards and AOL chatrooms, that influenced what Twitter and Facebook became."
## [1] " This is exactly the type of thing that fueled the original internet. Its not like a mainstream thing like a DApp that allows you to have Facebook decentralized."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " It is a specific concern that excites a lot of people because it seems to be solving a problem that everyone is dealing with."
## [1] " Speaking of the early internet, one of the things I was curious to get your take on was a lot of stuff has come out in the last couple of weeks about this consortium of venture capitalists, who have been creating a working group and trying to lobby for a safe harbor exemption for certain tokens to not be treated as securities. And basically not be subject to these same regulations that securities are generally subject to and its an interesting like echo of that internet. Because I think the guiding ethos at least from Silicon Valley and venture capitalists have been like, Dont regulate. Let us figure it out. Youre gonna kill whatever innovation or potential billion dollar, trillion industry by over regulating it. We know best. Let us do it. And so it makes sense to me that now that cryptos becoming a big part of what investors are interested in, they would feel the same way about avoiding regulations for crypto. This is a strange time to be making that argument though with Mark Zuckerberg testifying before congress and the biggest products of that Silicon Valley era finally facing some regulatory scrutiny."
## [1] " And like a breaking point with the public."
## [1] " And a break in a public trust."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah. It is a hard time for them to be making this argument right now."
## [1] " Yeah. A year ago wouldve been a better time for the safe harbor act I feel like."
## [1] " Tell me a little bit about it because like Im not quite clear on it, but its They see an inevitability, right? They think that the SCC is gonna be heavy handed and call all these things securities."
## [1] " I dont know about all of them, but a lot of them."
## [1] " But a lot of them, yeah."
## [1] " Particularly ICOs. So a worst case scenario and theres an interview in the New York Times with I think it was Neil Genzlinger-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Who was formerly the CFTC, where he was like, Ill just name two. Two things that look a lot like securities to me are Ripple and Ethereum and if Ethereums a security, all of the ICOs that have been done on top of Ethereum are potentially securities also. That would be a major, major shift that would sort of end the ICO market. It would end a lot of the functionality of Ethereum."
## [1] " Yeah, but why? Why would it end the-"
## [1] " Well it would mean that only certain types of investors would be able to invest."
## [1] " You would have to be an accredited investor. So youd either have to have over a million dollars in net worth or $200,000.00 a year or something like that. Right? Like isnt that worth it?"
## [1] " I think I dont know that thats the exact like-"
## [1] " Its somewhere around there."
## [1] " Something around there."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And additionally, there is a huge amount of work involved in complying with being a security that none of these companies have been doing, none of them want to do and might severely limit their potential."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " When weve talked about the Bitcoin apocalypse scenario, this is a little bit of the ICO Ethereum apocalypse scenario. I dont think its likely, but I think when youre like, How would Ethereum just go down in like a giant Hindenburg crash? This is one way it could."
## [1] " I dont understand how they are going to have that much traction honestly. It seems like the SEC is going to do what the SEC wants to do. I read a bit about this. I dont find the arguments that Ethereum is not a security, but other things are securities. I just dont find that particularly convincing."
## [1] " Well theres two good articles Id recommend. For the Ethereum is not a security argument, check out our former guest, the Coin Centers Peter Van Valkenburgh. He wrote about that and I think Preston Byrne had something pretty good that took the other side of that issue. And I think the like central sticking point Theres something called the Howey Test, thats supposedly how you test if something-"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Is a security or not. And I think the biggest variable in how we would evaluate something like Ethereum is its decentralized nature. If you believe that Ethereum is a totally decentralized application thats not owned or controlled by anyone, then its probably not a security."
## [1] " [crosstalk 00:25:32] why? Why?"
## [1] " For something to be a security, I believe it has to be issued by someone."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " And a decentralized Like Bitcoin was not issued by anyone. Bitcoin is mined but no ones ever issued someone a Bitcoin token. So what it comes down to for Ethereum I think, if I read this correctly, it comes down to this Ethereum presale. Is that the Ethereum Foundation distributing Ethereum or is that a totally decentralized event like the genesis block of Bitcoin? One of the arguments that Van Valkenburgh is making, which I think is kind of interesting is that Ethereum had two periods, it had the presale period and the current period. And he draws a bunch of distinctions between like in the presale period, the records were kept in a centralized database for the Ethereum foundation. In the post presale period, theyre now held in a decentralized blockchain. So I think hes basically saying that like yes, the original sale wouldve been a security, but its become something different now and thats not a security."
## [1] " Wow. Hes like using the Shaggy defense."
## [1] " What? It wasnt me?"
## [1] " It wasnt me. Hes saying that the thing that issued the token and kept records in a centralized place and had an entire foundation, like thats not actually Ethereum anymore. All That is another thing that just had the same name and at this point, what is Ethereum has sort of Not even that its different, but that it has sort of had this metaphysical and full body change and now it is something different. Like it is Its morphed. Its now a different thing."
## [1] " I kind of buy it. I mean in so far as something can start off centralized and become decentralized. Its not the same thing forever. This centrally comes down to like, does Ethereum require any central authority to continue? If the Ethereum Foundation ends, will Ethereum end?"
## [1] " Probably."
## [1] " But not necessarily. Like whats stopping it from I mean the GitHub page will get real quiet, but maybe there wont be future development on it. But I think it would continue to work and be used."
## [1] " Yeah. Well heres I read Preston Byrnes response. I enjoy his writing even when I disagree with it because I think he makes points very clearly. One of the things he said was that the Howey works, the way that U.S. security law works is that you kinda have to get under the hood and figure out what is actually going on. Right? So you cant take a 10,000 foot birds eye view and look down on and say, Well that kinda looks like a security and that doesnt really look like a security. And so in that sense, I would say that we dont really know, cause we dont know how decentralized Ethereum is right now. We dont know who holds a ton of Ethereum. We dont know how influence really works. Right?"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " Like we have a general sense. We know what Vitalik says, we know what Peter Van Valkenburgh says, but we ultimately dont know."
## [1] " We know that its more decentralized than it was because people are mining it and more people are holding it. But we dont know how decentralized it is."
## [1] " Yes. And I would say that And I think that this is what Preston Byrne is arguing in some ways as well, which is that even if it has become more decentralized, you cannot say that it has had a full body conversion and that it is now something completely different. That they did have a presale-"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " A lot of those tokens did go to small numbers of people. Right?"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " A lot of those people are now very wealthy and very invested in the future of Ethereum."
## [1] " And a lot of those people have ties to the Ethereum foundation."
## [1] " Exactly. So if youre trying to say that theres no longer a central force thats very powerful and theres no sort of centralized group that benefits from Ethereum going up or down or the future of Ethereum or people investing more in Ethereum, I think that that probably fails. And at that point, yeah, I do I would argue that I think that if the Securities Commission was to say that Ethereum is not a security right, then I think that it would be very hard for them to argue that anything is a security."
## [1] " I kind of agree with you and all the arguments weve just made about Ethereum are like times seven if you take Ripple."
## [1] " Maybe times a 100 seriously."
## [1] " Times a 100."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Yeah. Like theres good arguments on both sides with Ethereum. Id say theres not very many good arguments that Ripples not a security. In my mind, it seems to be very heavily controlled by a central corporation-"
## [1] " Is Ripple even trying Is Ripple part of this exemption?"
## [1] " Well one thing that they do have going for them is theyve got Snoop Dogg playing at their census of that. So that actually gets you a special exemption."
## [1] " I feel like thats proof of centralization. Like Snoop Dogg only really plays at things that are like centralized, corporate events now. The last thing Ill say about this is that Or the last question Ill ask you is, do you think that the argument for that this thing is completely decentralized and that therefore should not be treated as a security Do you think that that argument is hampered by the fact that they have Vitalik Buterin as a center piece of all this?"
## [1] " I do. I think the most notable difference between Bitcoin Core and the Ethereum Foundation is the lack of a figurehead in Bitcoin and I think thats a very smart decision by whoever Satoshi Nakamoto is. And I think it puts it in this realm where you can truly say the person who made this is anonymous. This could continue for hundreds of years without intervention and this is not the product of a company or a corporation or some issuance. Do you think that if Ethereum had it over again, they would not do the presale?"
## [1] " Oh, yeah. Well cause I mean if they knew that they were gonna be this successful-"
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " Like they certainly wouldnt have. I dont think so."
## [1] " Yeah. It kinda reminds me of how like before Vitalik started Ethereum, he was like involved in like some kinda scammy stuff supposedly. And its like Im sure he wishes he hadnt been involved in that before he was involved in Ethereum. You get involved in some more questionable stuff when youre starting off, you really need the money for your-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " To get your idea off the ground. What if Ethereum had just been a truly mineable project from day one? There was never any presale, then again maybe they wouldve never gotten here then."
## [1] " No, and I dont think they would have. Its the same thing with Vitalik, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like if you dont have Vitalik as the talking head who goes on YouTube or whatever and talks about this thing. If you dont have the belief in the central figure that you write magazine profiles of, who is quite identifiably a genius-"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " You know like I dont think it gets off the ground at all. So you have a double edged sword here and I think that at some point, theyre probably just gonna have to be like, Look, we can make all these arguments we want. But at some point, the SECs gonna come and look under the hood and theyre gonna also use sort of a smell test and we probably will fail that."
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " Speaking of centralization and securities and all these things. Its been a while since weve done this, but I think that we should talk about a specific coin."

## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " A big part of the promise of Zero-X is that these DApps are gonna be able to be moving all kinds of ERC-20 tokens and making all kinds of smart contracts and none of it is gonna cost or burn anything. It will be a perpetual motion machine of DApps controlling your whole life."

## [1] " If you use it. So it is essentially just like an engine in which all of this can run at much, much more efficient pace."

It is not a shady project with a shady team. It is people who have their photos on the website, it is people who you can look up everything that theyve done in the past. ## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I think you look at Bitcoin, you almost have like two strands in the family tree of crypto, which is this one strand that starts with the dark web, and starts with people who wanna do semi-anonymous, shady online transactions and that accidentally create an entire decentralized Not accidentally, intentionally create an entire decentralized currency around it. And then theres this other strand of people who want smart contracts to power everything about your life and everything about your banking and identity, and everything else. And I almost dont Like I dont see those two paths ever crossing over each other again. The only war theyre really at with each other is for market share. Right? Do you feel like the Bitcoin and Ethereum world views even really matter much to each other at this point?"
## [1] " No, actually You know thats good cause thats actually the last thing I wanna talk about on this topic, which is that from a zoomed out perspective-"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " It really does seem like theyve been more divergent in the past few weeks or past few months. You know that you do have stories about Ethereum that do seem to be closer to being able to articulate a world in which Ethereum is a big deal and that it replaces a lot of the functions in which we use on our phone or on the internet."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And that it affects large portions of our life and that they seem to not really even be interested in talking about Bitcoin-"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " And whereas Bitcoin seems to be sort of going another path, which is actually somewhat closer to the origins of Bitcoin right, which is we are looking at a world in which a deflationary currency is a good idea, and thats what were concerned about. So like nobody in the Bitcoin community is saying like lets build Bitcoin apps. Like BApps and figure out ways in which we can like create a better version of Twitter or something like that. And I dont if its for any other reason than I feel like the people who are behind Ethereum projects have recently been able to articulate their ideas a little bit better."
## [1] " And that makes sense. Like it makes sense that the V1 is different from the V3 and that people have to experiment and pivot. I think we make fun of some of the ideals of Silicon Valley. But these are people who are experienced at building giant ideas that seem silly at first."
## [1] " Or might be horrible for the world."
## [1] " Or might destroy the world. It seems like Bitcoin is more comfortable with Bitcoin being the whole idea. I dont think Bitcoin necessarily needs to like change what its doing a lot in the next few years in order to validate its importance and its hypothesis. And I think thats like made me a bit more of a Bitcoin Maximalist recently. Its just like I get what Im support When I support Bitcoin, I think Ive wrapped my head around at least like 50% of it. I dont really understand a lot of this Ethereum world stuff and maybe Brian Armstrong understands it better than I do and hes seeing a future that I cant see."
## [1] " He probably does."
## [1] " He probably does but-"
## [1] " But his extrapolation or his conclusions might be worse."
## [1] " Well they need I do think that those people need to get better at articulating the world that theyre imagining. It cant simply be like more, more, more tokens, more like more Ethereum, more everything. Like has to be like a pause where we start actually showing people like what to do with this stuff."
## [1] " But what if theyre in the MUD phase right now? Which I think thats what they would argue. Right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like what we talked about earlier in the podcast. Like its very hard to articulate and extrapolate out of what we have right now, what its going to be, but that clearly its going to be something."
## [1] " I agree with that. I think we are in that MUD phase. Its weird to talk about the joint like Ethereum, Bitcoin market cap as a result of that, cause I dont understand why if Ethereum moves past its MUD phase, thats a bad thing for Bitcoin, or Bitcoin should be like, Oh, were in decline. In some ways I always think that Bitcoin will be the gateway drug to all of this stuff cause its like much easier to understand at the gateway at least, like what youre doing. And I expect that over time like if Ethereum is right, if the Ethereum world is right, then over time it will become bigger than Bitcoin. I think."
## [1] " Yeah. No, I totally agree with that and it does seem in the last six months at least or three months even, that there has been more diversions than there was in the past year and a half if that makes sense."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like the two were always compared to one another. The question you and I always get is, Hey. Like should I buy Bitcoin or should I buy Ethereum? And I think what Ethereum wants"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " And maybe what Bitcoin wants as well, but what the people who are backing Ethereum really want is for that question to end."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " Like they dont wanna be involved with Bitcoin at all."
## [1] " And I think that its proper to think of Ethereum and Zero-X more in terms of startups. I think that theyre like startups that have a certain amount of runway and they have to make a strong case during that runway, that people should invest more in them and that their vision is gonna take over the world, or its gonna like fall apart. Whereas Bitcoin, I think the vision has already been executed and we can start thinking about Bitcoin as a store of value, as something that has like a long term place to park money and wealth. And if Bitcoin is basically exactly the same thing, but a little bit more efficient and has figured out some lightning network stuff in the next couple of years, I dont feel like Bitcoin will be like behind as a result. I think Bitcoin is in somewhat of a more stable position despite the price not being stable cause the idea is stable."
## [1] " Yeah. Sure. I mean I still dont wanna live in Brian Armstrongs world."
## [1] " You wouldnt wanna live in anyones world."
## [1] " I mean Im okay living in this current world. Cool. Is there anything else you wanna talk about?"
## [1] " Oh, yeah. I got something for you. Youll see here this lovely book here. Ive purchased The Bitcoin Standard by Saifedean Ammous."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Do you know how to say his name?"
## [1] " Famous eater of only meat. I think hes a carnivore."
## [1] " Carnivore. Im gonna start this book. I was wondering if you would like to read it alongside me and we could start a little podcast book club."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. Lets do it. I mean look, I The books that I tend to read these days are really not gonna be that much better."
## [1] " I mean Ive heard this book getting a lot of praise. So if youre interested, lets say well do it in quarters."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " So well do it over four weeks. We wont start this week cause well give you time to go buy the book."
## [1] " Mm-hmm (affirmative). Do I have to buy it with Bitcoin?"
## [1] " No. Ill Yeah, you can get the Kindle one. Ill tell you, the printing is very cheap. So I dont even know if I totally endorse getting the print copy, but pick it up in the Kindle. Its only a few bucks, read alongside us. Well announce next show what the page numbers were gonna go up to are. I think it will be nice to were like budding up against the limits of like how we can discuss this stuff based on a like 200 word CoinDesk article."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And hopefully the book will provide a framework for us to get a little deeper and people who are reading along can send in questions. Well answer them. Maybe well have a guest or two whos read the book on. Itll be fun."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " All right. Cool. See you next week."
## [1] " All right."
## [1] " That was Coin Talk, edited this week by James Nicholson. Thanks very much to my cohost Jay Kang. Thanks to our partners at Medium. You can find every episode of this show including transcripts at medium.com/cointalk. Its kind of a fast way to get through the archives if you like to read this kind of thing. Also you can send us an email hi@cointalk.show. Thanks for listening. Well see you next week."

## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Welcome to Coin Talk. Jay, so much to talk about."
## [1] " A lot to talk about."
## [1] " I feel we have to go straight for it."
## [1] " Lets talk about what youre wearing first."
## [1] " Whats that?"
## [1] " Are you wearing a jersey that has no logo on it?"
## [1] " No, its actually got a white on white Warriors thing on it. Its like a Warriors warmup jersey. I feel like this is something you would like to go to the club and you would see Klay Thompson wearing this."
## [1] " Speaking of which, I was talking to somebody recently and I was reminded of watching game six, when Klay Thompson hit all those shots again the Thunder, when they had Durant. And I was like, I think that I watched it with Aaron and he was wearing a Warriors poncho."
## [1] " Thats correct. That poncho is currently in the crypto cave. That poncho got quasi-retired after the Warriors lost to the Cavs the second year, because it seemed like it might have bad mojo after that. But I think I might bring it back for the imminent Rockets/Warriors series."
## [1] " Fair enough, fair enough."
## [1] " Were actually going to talk later in the program about the greatest ICO athlete pairing in history, and it reminded me that I think the greatest product athlete fit so far in the marketplace has been Klay Thompson and chocolate milk."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah."
## [1] " Theres no more natural pairing than that possible."
## [1] " It was much better than the Kevin Love/chocolate milk pairing, which is just him shooting three pointers."
## [1] " All right. We will be talking to some NBA ICOs later on. But first, I feel like we have to address the elephant in the room."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah."
## [1] " Or should I say, the vandal in the network."
## [1] " It was Coin Talks first quasi-viral moment. I feel like you got a lot of re-tweets from the luminaries of the space."
## [1] " I would say that I feel like my crypto OG card has been punched."
## [1] " Yeah. Youre punched."
## [1] " Let me tell you a little about what happened for the listeners out there. We wont go through the whole thing because its embarrassing trying to recount internet jokes on audio. But after many times us joking about getting hacked as a result of hosting this show, I got a DM from a listener to the show actually, shouts to him, who alerted me that aaronlammer.com, my website, had some sort of a hacking notice on it and a demand for a Bitcoin ransom."
## [1] " Yeah. And what was on aaronlammer.com? Ive known you for maybe 8 years. And Ive never been to aaronlammer.com."
## [1] " Aaronlammer.com is just like says all the projects Im involved in. It links to all my podcasts and music and stuff like that. Its of not huge value to me. I wouldnt be glad to lose it. But its not like I would have bought aaronlammer.com from a reseller for $10,000 or something like I bought stoner.co. I felt like we were in a pretty good position to negotiate here. Anyway, basically what happened was I went through a long sequence with this hacker of offering him various other cryptocurrencies that were not Bitcoin and pretending to be confused about the differences between Bitcoin Cash and Bitcoin. Its on Medium. People can look it up."
## [1] " Well, okay, so here are my questions immediately about it. I saw the hacked page, and it was pretty funny. It was like a [crosstalk 00:06:29]-"
## [1] " Jay also, Id like to say, expressed absolutely no sympathy before and started laughing at me, no worry that perhaps the show we host together had caused me problems or that perhaps our assets could be getting hacked."
## [1] " Well, it is true. I had zero moments of sympathy."
## [1] " Yeah. And you werent like, Dude, our domains or our hosting got hacked, you just started laughing at the fact that our show got hacked."
## [1] " Well, okay, so it looked like it was a page that had been created on Angelfire or Geocities. The quality of the hacking page was very bad."
## [1] " Yes. Well, instantly, I was like I Googled the hack because it had a name and I could see that other people had been hacked in this manner with the same page."
## [1] " Okay. How much money did this guy want from you?"
## [1] " Well, he asked for.025 Bitcoins, which I originally read as.25 Bitcoins, which is thats where I thought we were going to come in. I thought we were going to be talking about a couple thousand dollars. But.025 is like $230-ish, kind of low."
## [1] " Well, that was my problem with the whole thing was that he asked for so little amount of money and I was trying to think what would go through a hackers head when they do something like this. Are they like, Listen, we need to set a reasonable price for aaronlammer.com. Do they have a scale where they think that certain pages are going to be worth more to people? If he looked you up, if he did this hack and he was at all Im sure that he didnt, he might be under the impression that youre this immensely successful podcaster and recording artist and that you might have millions of dollars."
## [1] " I think it was random."
## [1] " I think it was random too."
## [1] " Although, at the time, I was like, Oh, no, I shouldve have never dabbled in coin celebrity."
## [1] " Yeah, and this also came on the tail end of your Cryptopia account being hacked every single week."
## [1] " Right. And Adrianne Jeffries, who actually wrote about this in The Verge had asked me, Do you worry about getting hacked because youre doing this show now? and I was like, Ha-ha. No. And then instantly after that, someones been trying to brute force reset my password on Crytopia for months. Its caused me to sell my SUMO and lose the amazing SUMO run thats been happening since then."
## [1] " You lost your title and you lost out on gains because of that, which, look-"
## [1] " Its just like real feudalism. If you leave your land, its over for you."
## [1] " I will say that when you told me that someone was trying to brute force your Cryptopia account, which, to me, is the most hysterically bad use of that sort of technology ever, that perhaps it was karma for you talking about SUMO every single episode and talking about how you had it on Cryptopia. Do you not think those two were related at all?"
## [1] " Well, now I dont think that they were related, but, at the time, this is the nature of paranoia around these things, youre never going to know. Hes never going to tell me how he came upon me."
## [1] " I would agree. I dont think that this hack had anything to do with any of that though because it was so unsophisticated-"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " and they asked for so little money."
## [1] " I have another piece of evidence there too because the actual exploit of my WordPress with through a friends WordPress site that I host on my server thats for his maple syrup operation, so, basically, the door in was not my website. It was a small maple syrup WordPress site. Great syrup though."
## [1] " Its good syrup?"
## [1] " Good syrup."
## [1] " The way that this guy tried to get you to talk to him was over Facebook Messenger, right?"
## [1] " Well, that was the most surprising thing. I was like, Oh, great. Im fucked. Its.025 BTC, so maybe I should just pay it. Also they had all these instructions about how to buy Bitcoin to pay him off. Im like if youre going to put someone through the trouble of buying Bitcoin, you might as well ask for more than.025 BTC. But, anyway, I click on the contact button and it just takes me straight to a Facebook page."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " The Contact Us link was just to a specific with a name, which Im not going to say because Medium has asked me to blur out his name on the web, but its just a guys Facebook page with a bunch of anime on it."
## [1] " Shocking. Shocking. Did he say where he was from?"
## [1] " Well, he didnt say where he was from, but the person who alerted me to it did some snooping in some hacker forums and said that his Facebook page matched someone named Syntax Error, whod been in hacker forums, who was in Morocco. And one of the things is the site that they put over my site had this autoplaying video in the background that was playing this ominous I describe it as like stock music hip hop."
## [1] " Wow, so it really was Web 0.0 with autoplay music."
## [1] " Yeah. And one of the things he had said in the hacker forum was, Make the victim listen to music."
## [1] " Oh, wow, so it really is like-"
## [1] " Its really to annoy you, and if you dont pay, this autoplaying loop is going to be on your website forever."
## [1] " That actually would work for me, I think. I dont know if it would push me to pay the Bitcoin, but it would be a factor that I would put into my calculations. Id be like, Oh, my God, anyone who Googles me first is going to believe that I have the worst security on everything possible and then theyre going to be like, What the fuck is this song?"
## [1] " One of the things I was thinking about doing as I was progressively trolling him was to A lot of the things I was doing is pretending I didnt understand various Bitcoin debates and I was going to pretend I didnt know that you could send.025 Bitcoin and tell him that I was going to send him a full Bitcoin and have him send me back the change. Oh, another thing was our friend [Naraj 00:12:08] looked up the address he had supplied to send the Bitcoin and said one person had sent a ransom to that address."
## [1] " Yeah, see, thats-"
## [1] " Its kind of like the Nigerian scam. Its probably millions of tries before you get one."
## [1] " Yeah, and thats why you should ask for more money."
## [1] " Totally agree."
## [1] " Thats the part where Im just like, well, what is his return on time invested here when hes only asking for $220?"
## [1] " Well, and additionally, how many people even have Bitcoin or could figure out how to get Bitcoin? If you hit someone, like me, who actually has Bitcoin, you might as well try to get more than that. I actually have the Bitcoin to send him and didnt send it to him."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. And how do you resolve this sort of thing, for our listeners who may get hacked?"
## [1] " Well, I went to my My server is with a company called DreamHost and they were really easily, like within five minutes, been able to see on the server logs what had happened. It had to do with leaving a WordPress installation that had not been set up yet, so you could set passwords and get into it, and they got into this domain through it being on the same user. But the basic thing was that by the time I was talking to him, I already knew I had the domain back, which he did not realize, which gave me the upper hand in these negotiations."
## [1] " Yeah. It seems like a very bad hacking strategy, to be completely honest with you. And also Bitcoin is pretty traceable, but I guess its just the easiest thing for people to buy. He couldnt be like, Okay, the first thing you do is go on Coinbase and you buy Bitcoin and then you go on Bittrex, you send it and then you buy Monero and send me that Monero."
## [1] " I was thinking the same thing. Ransoming someone for Bitcoin is brazen. Its like extorting someone and being like, Mail a check to my home address."
## [1] " Naraj could figure out how many ransoms had been sent to this guy within six seconds of the time when you announced it."
## [1] " Well, that also empowered me to not pay him. I was like, Oh, only one person has paid him ever? Im not going to pay him."
## [1] " What you should do is you should send a bunch of fake 0.25 Bitcoin donations into that wallet so it seems like everybody is doing it, and then thatll press you in because youll be like, Oh, there must have a point where these people capitulated because something was over their head."
## [1] " Yes. That would have been the narrative I was looking for. If I saw that 10,000 people had paid him, I wouldve been like, Fuck it. Im paying. Clearly, thats the smart money."
## [1] " Hopefully, hes listening to this podcast and that he can improve his hacking in the future."
## [1] " Well, I did invite him on the show."
## [1] " What did he say?"
## [1] " He was like, I dont need this bullshit, man. He eventually lost patience with me. Then I posted these chats online and, almost instantly, I would say within an hour, people were accusing me of faking the entire thing."
## [1] " Yeah. Well, look, thats the community that you and I have decided to enter."
## [1] " Yeah, and get hacked with it."
## [1] " Yeah, everything is fake news."
## [1] " Are you worried about getting hacked?"
## [1] " A little bit, a little bit. I did triple down on all my security after this happened to you, but I dont have jaykang.com. I think I have a Wikipedia page, but people vandalize that all the time. Its always stuff like-"
## [1] " Jordan Peterson fans."
## [1] " It really is. There was one where somebody edited to say, On such-and-such day, Jay Kang aired a piece that was clearly edited to slander Jordan Peterson, or something like that."
## [1] " On this date in U.S. history, Jay Kang got owned by Jordan Peterson."
## [1] " That happens all the time. There was one that was saying that I had maliciously slandered MLS fans and called them all fascists and I was like, Yeah, okay. Thats fine. The last thing I will say about this hacker guy is that he is very bad at posting actual threats. I feel like if he was taking personal website addresses that people use for their businesses or to present themselves to the world, then he should have a much more inflammatory image on there so that people are like, Oh, I hope that nobody who goes to aaronlammer.com is going to see a picture of X, a terrible beheading or anything that nobody actually wants to see."
## [1] " I feel like he was kind of hinting at that because he kept saying, Im going to do horrible things to you on a hacker forum if you dont listen to me, and I was like, You need to be more specific than this, like a 1990s hacker forum or"
## [1] " Well, are you afraid at all now?"
## [1] " I wasnt, and then when I saw that that article that Adrianne wrote about it in The Verge went up, I was like Im not worried about that guy, but Im worried about some other hacker seeing it now and being like, Oh, Im really going to get this guy."
## [1] " Oh, yeah, yeah. Well, they all have hacker solidarity. They have to stand up for the other hackers."
## [1] " Yeah, I feel like its like in Revenge of the Nerds. I fucked with the nerds and now Im expecting my return prank or something."
## [1] " Theyre going to all show up in matching suits."
## [1] " More likely, Im probably just going to get swatted or something."
## [1] " Oh, geez, make sure that Im not here when you get swatted. Speaking of Actually, thats a terrible segue, but-"
## [1] " No, dont say that."
## [1] " Stephon Marbury, right?"

## [1] " Youre the perfect person to ask because weve always struggled with this. You said basically it would be cool if utility tokens work. And my whole impression, from reading about a gazillion ICOs and the whole cultural history of this era, is there was projects like Bitcoin that did not require any capital to get off the ground and then eventually people started making crypto projects and theyre like, Hey, this is kind of like a startup. We need to pay ourselves and have a foundation. And so they did ICOs and then they were like, And also a utility token because the whole economy of this wouldnt work if it and then people started speculating on those utility tokens. Why do utility tokens have to work, in your opinion? Why do they need to exist for all this cool stuff to happen?"
## [1] " Let me ask you a question, because I know youve written a lot about the Telegram ICO, and thats the opposite of the garbage side. Its the most prestige well, in a way."
## [1] " What? Are we being sponsored by Telegram?"
## [1] " Jay, its a solo deal. They only wanted me. They didnt want you in on it. No. Okay, Im going to elaborate on that. Its very big-"
## [1] " Its not an outright scam. Telegrams a real app. Theres a real product, etc. And it seemed like, in that case and correct me if Im wrong, they started off down the ICO path that were describing with a utility token and then when they realized that they could easily get all the money they needed without going down that path, they basically canceled the original ICO and just went with a bunch of individual investors?"
## [1] " But how is this utility token future going to unfold if Roman Abramovich or whoever got all of the Telegram ICOs sitting on 25% of the worlds Gram supply?"
## [1] " Youre not worried then that those sorts of massive dumps by huge, huge investors is going to destroy that type of market and attract interest from regulators? Yes, I think in a sort of anarcho-capitalist world, that makes sense, but in a world in which people are trying to invest good faith in good faith projects, that does seem a bit dangerous to me."
## [1] " On the short-term, extremely cynical."
## [1] " Wheres the incentivization? When you take a bunch of seed money, theres someone whos like, Yo, you better at least try to make this product or Im going to be fucking pissed off at you. And if youve already got 100, 5, 10, 20, 100 million dollars out of the gate and, not only have you taken the money, its not from hundreds of thousands of people who are all going to yell at you and try and come after you, its from a few billionaires who can easily lose the money. It just seems like it doesnt even have to be a scheme, its just a bad way to engineer a company."
## [1] " Yeah. It was like the day when the ex-head of Ripple was the richest man in the world or whatever. We had a discussion about it. It was just like, well, what is the incentive to build Ripple at this point? Why would he build this bank to bank thing or invest a lot of money in it? Hes already fucking rich. With the Telegram thing, that was my question about it was just why are they going to build this network at this point? They could do a really shitty job of it and people are already going to be skeptical of it because of the way that they raised money and the amount of money that they raised. And the idea that people would slowly get into it and theyd try and buy it and that there would be a measured sell off of it that would retain the value and then you would have an operating marketplace, it just seems to go against almost everything that has happened in crypto so far."
## [1] " Its a lot easier to believe in these things if theres an independent track record of the person behind them and that involves something thats not pure financial [crosstalk 01:05:05]. The way that you situated Telegram there made the ICO seem more legitimate to me than when its just like, Hey, were pulling the ICO and these people got all the tokens. How do the gears of the utility tokens in something like [inaudible 01:05:19] start going though? If its all held by these people, how are people going to start using it, if so many of the tokens are just being hoarded?"
## [1] " I dont even know what the Kin token is."
## [1] " Okay, okay. Cool. Yeah, weve talked about Kik. Why is Kiks token not called Kik?"
## [1] " I continue to be-"
## [1] " I appreciate your enthusiasm and belief in this. I think I just dont want the Toshi universe where Im a Mechanical Turk Worker and my computer is being leased slightly in the background. Im just kind of like, ah, what, for the 75 cents, I dont see myself earning a living that way."
## [1] " Its hard for me to wrap my head around how all of this stuff is going to somehow shake down to a bunch of people, if were super interested in it and were barely able to do any of this stuff on it."
## [1] " You did valiantly. Thank you."
## [1] " In the spirit of defense."
## [1] " Its hard to talk positively on this stuff. I know the negative vortex that Jay will suck you into."
## [1] " I think I got email in high school."
## [1] " I had AIM."
## [1] " We would agree with that."
## [1] " I would agree with that. To me, the crazy idea is Bitcoin becomes money, not like Im farming server space and shoring my files with utility tokens so I can earn money from President Brian Armstrongs Toshi corporation."
## [1] " No, no, no, no. That will be not a democracy."
## [1] " I just think its the most provocative idea is just digital money, just be like all the money goes digital."
## [1] " Its kind of like the divide between what youre talking about is sort of a consumer tech/labor tech vision and, to me, Im more interested in the dissolution of nations. To me, the most provocative idea is countries lose control over money. Money is not linked to national identity. In some ways, the more consumer tech vision almost feels too small to me comparatively. It has to be like theres no more countries for it to fulfill the promise almost. Jay, we got anything more before we want to get out of here?"
## [1] " No, I think were good."
## [1] " All right. Well, thank you, Brady. This was fun. Where can people who want to find your writing on CoinDesk find you?"
## [1] " One last question. Are you bummed to be no coining through this coin era that youre spending so much of your mental energy on?"
## [1] " Art hustling."
## [1] " Its weird. Its like if sports reporters werent allowed to watch sports, or I guess itd be if they werent allowed to play sports."
## [1] " Or bet on sports-"
## [1] " Bet on sports, which theyre -"
## [1] " which theyre not allowed to do."
## [1] " All right. Well, thank you for coming on, Brady."
## [1] " Hey, thanks for listening to Coin Talk. Im Aaron Lammer. My cohost is Jay Kang. Our partner in this is Medium. Our guest this week was Brady Dale from Coin Desk. Thanks to him, thanks to them. Thanks to our editor, James Nicholson, and thanks to all you people who are listening. If you want to get in touch, its hi@cointalk.show. We do offer sponsor slots. If you have a company in the blockchain space that you would like to promote on here, were happy to do so. Send us an email, hi@cointalk.show. Make sure to pick up the Bitcoin Standard. I think its 11 bucks on Amazon or something. Its not expensive and were going to read the first four chapters for next week. So if you got it, Tweet at us at CoinTalkShow. Let us know youre reading. Were going to start with that, again, Bitcoin Standard by, I apologize for this pronunciation, Saifedean Ammous. Well see you next week."

## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Live in the crypto cave."
## [1] " Hows it going?"
## [1] " No cockroaches so far."
## [1] " Yeah, I know. Ive been eyeing that guitar case where that mammal sized cockroach just went under it. But I have not seen it resurface. No shame here. We have cockroaches too in our apartment. I feel like-"
## [1] " Theres no shame in having cockroaches in New York. You could easily get into seven figures in New York in real estate and still have cockroaches."
## [1] " Yeah, I would actually say-"
## [1] " Not that I have This place is $350.00 a month, this basement where we tape. But Ive heard that people do."
## [1] " I dont think that theres any correlation between the price of the price of the place where youre at and the number of cockroaches."
## [1] " No, I mean I kinda feel like New York City cockroaches are like this separate phenomenon thats like, Hey, its not even gross. Its a city cockroach over there. Hey, its the pizza rat over here."
## [1] " That thing was massive though. That was actually one of the biggest cockroaches Ive seen in my life. All right. So speaking of cockroaches-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Should we just get into the news right now?"
## [1] " Yeah, lets get into it. People have been getting feisty on the internet. Its like NBA playoff time, everyones a little chippy in basketball, you see a fight almost every night. I feel like the crypto world is ready to brawl."
## [1] " Yeah, well I feel like that actually is a bullish sign for me for crypto-"
## [1] " Oh, yeah."
## [1] " Because I think for a while-"
## [1] " Do you thrive on the conflict?"
## [1] " Well no, because I think for a while everyone was just kind of depressed and all the memes and theres not that much fighting because everyone was super poor at once."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And now like people are starting to go back to their corners."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like the raid is over. People feel a little feisty. Spring is in the air right now and theyre ready to scrap. So there is one big scrap this week."
## [1] " Yeah, I feel like this one hit close to my heart because were fans of Laura Shin and the show."
## [1] " Yeah, Coin Talks ombudsman."
## [1] " Ombudsman-"
## [1] " Laura Shin."
## [1] " Yeah. Shes corrected some of my numerous errors."
## [1] " I feel like shes gotten to like 1% of our factual errors on this, but it was a very long email detailing several of our factual errors."
## [1] " Side note. So when we were prepping to talk about this, we were looking at her show. Her podcast is called Unconfirmed-"
## [1] " Unchained."
## [1] " Unchain Well she has two. She has Unchained and Unconfirmed. I think youre right, Unchained is the episode were talking about. It has a disclosure in the description that says, I own Bitcoin and Ethereum. And I was like man, like if we had to do that, I wouldnt even know what we would say. Its like, Aaron has like tons of shit in bag. A bunch of them he got bad entries on."
## [1] " Hahahaha."
## [1] " Several of them have been de-listed and he cant move them. Jay may or may not have some Bitcoin. If he doesnt, hes [FoMO-ing 00:04:40]."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly. If Jay was not too lazy to buy alt coins right now, these are the coins that he would have."
## [1] " But anyway, so Laura does this show. Its a great show. She has on lots of CEOs. I mean her guest list is mostly the people behind these coins."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. She does not go our route, which is to invite on degenerate gamblers."
## [1] " I feel like we like are both on the degenerate journalist and degenerate gamblers list, but we havent had that many people who are actually like building-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The stuff that were talking about. So that is kinda what she normally does in the show and Im always curious cause I do listen to the show and I always sort of think about this decision to have people talk about their own work. These are people who have literally billions of dollars at stake in how the public perceives their projects."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So its not necessarily people that I associate with deep honesty, but its interesting, I listen and if I have heard someone on the show it does affect whether Id want to buy that coin."
## [1] " Yeah. Look its the dance that all journalists have to do-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " For a certain especially tech journalists I think more than anybody else."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And maybe like celebrity profilers, which is is it worth having this person on in an unfiltered forum like the podcast, where I can press them on certain things or her."
## [1] " Right. And Laura to her credit, shes not a no coiner whos gonna try to like poke holes in what youre doing necessarily. She-"
## [1] " And she is interested in the world."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So shes not a troll."
## [1] " Not at all."
## [1] " I think if you and I had on her guest list, one of us-"
## [1] " Jay."
## [1] " Me, would spend most of the time-"
## [1] " Theres only one troll whos on this show."
## [1] " Yeah, would spend most of the time trolling and asking absurd questions and trying to corner them into like stupid debate trick stuff."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " She doesnt do that-"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Because she is a curious person in real journalism. Shes trying to get these things out. So-"
## [1] " And shes like generally takes the attitude of like let people like represent themselves how they wanna rep themselves."
## [1] " Yeah. I do not take that."
## [1] " So she was gonna do a show on Ripple. I guess she hadnt done the show on Ripple. I mean Ripple is this weird anomaly where it is one of the biggest coins, but it also almost exists outside of the rest of a lot of these coins, like in a different sort of business realm. And so she was trying to get on Brad Garlinghouse who runs Ripple Inc.-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Hes the CEO of Ripple Inc. and they were kinda giving here runaround on this. I had a lot of empathy for this cause Ive had the run around before by some PR apparatuses and they were like, We Were not actually getting you] Brad Garlinghouse, but like we got you the next best thing, this other guy."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And she basically negotiated with them and they kinda didnt want to budge. And so she was like, Well fine. Im gonna do it with these two other guys., who she had booked. One of whom was Ryan Selkis who I admire. Anyway, the Ripple dudes kind of freaked out on Twitter and were kinda accusing of her of acting in bad faith-"
## [1] " Unbelievable."
## [1] " And trying to argue their way on."
## [1] " Unbelievable. Yeah, yeah. And then their like army of Ripple fans also swarmed Lauras Twitter account and were making all sorts of crazy accusations towards her, which is really the sort of sad state of discourse in America right now. ## [1] " 7% of the global money supply is 6.28 trillion dollars."
