## [1] " No. Definitely not. So that is 50 Jeff Bezozes in one vault."
## [1] " Yeah, I mean its kind of incredible. In some ways in the present day, the bunker seems excessive. In the Bitcoin maximalist world view, theyre gonna need a lot of guns around that bunker."
## [1] " Yeah. Well I mean So heres my question to you, which is that look the idea-"
## [1] " I dont know why Im always talking about guns on this show."
## [1] " The idea of a small number of people holding 6.28 trillion dollars in a bunker, right now it would destroy any sort of world economy because so much wealth would be centralized in one spat, amongst a small number of people. Right?"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Does this actually make the case for Bitcoin itself taking over the entire world economy a little bit harder, because its so Like none of these people are gonna sell their Bitcoin or distribute it. And so if Bitcoin does take over the world, it means that even just with this, you have a massive concentration of wealth."
## [1] " Well-"
## [1] " Does that bother you?"
## [1] " I dont Im not sure I agree with that none of these people are ever gonna sell or move their Bitcoin."
## [1] " If Bitcoin keeps going up and they believe in Bitcoin in the way that they do, I dont I think that that concentration will stay pretty constant."
## [1] " I do think that that much of the Bitcoin in one place is a problem on several levels and I assume that as the price accelerated, there would be more Xapos scattered around the earth, and that we would try to spread out the Bitcoin amongst them. I just see it would make sense. You know? Bitcoin goes 10 X and theres 10 times much money there, you might wanna at least say, Hey, we dont wanna keep more than like a 100 billion per bunker. Or something like that."
## [1] " I guess my problem is more that like if we try and think of visualize Bitcoin as being the standard for all wealth in the world. Right? And that some of the ethos of Bitcoin is like were gonna help bank the bankless-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And thats gonna lead to Like I think that what it basically has led to is that the people the wealth concentration that we see right now is gonna become hyper concentrated. Right? And its going to just be the people who bought into large amounts of Bitcoin early, and that seems like its a real problem. You have very little flexibility in that world because small amounts of people are essentially gonna be nation states upon themselves, which already is sort of happening. But it will be accelerated for no reason, for no value except for the fact that they own all this Bitcoin early. Like do you see that as a problem?"
## [1] " You know I dont know enough about the like current concentration of wealth in the world. Somehow it compares-"
## [1] " Well just think about 50 Jeff Bezozes in like one vault."
## [1] " But I mean thats what Im wondering. Like if you took the top 100 Fiat holders in the world and concentrated their wealth in Swiss bank. Does the Swiss banking system as a whole have that much money in it?"
## [1] " Well its not even Its just like there arent 50 Jeff Bezozes. Like theres one Jeff Bezoz."
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " Right?"
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " And if you-"
## [1] " But theres the 50 richest people on earth-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which lets say are like somewhere overall around 50 Jeff Bezozes."
## [1] " Yeah. No, that would get nowhere close to 7% of the total net worth in the world."
## [1] " Wow. Yeah, I mean look I think its a major liability. I think these people are liabilities and Satoshis stash is probably a liability in its own right. My guess is that the like gamblers amongst us would read that situation and say, Probably none of those coins are ever gonna move. Lets just look at it as a smaller supply. That said, if someone decides to like become like a despotic tyrant-"
## [1] " Thats the problem!"
## [1] " With their money. I mean and like clearly the betting odds are on Peter Thiel here. Right?"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " I mean we know that Peter Thiel and not just looking at Peter Thiel the individual, but his sort of network of like companies of investments. Yeah, it could be like a major holder amongst those."
## [1] " Yeah. Do you want Peter Thiel to be richer than he already is by several, several hundreds percent?"
## [1] " Id be against it myself."
## [1] " Yeah. And so that-"
## [1] " But I am getting rich during that scenario. Now if I go 100 X and I also know that Peter Thiel is going a hundred X, will I accept scenario? I think I probably would."
## [1] " I dont know. I would think very, very hard about it."
## [1] " I think you also have to look at this a little bit like the force. Theres a dark side and theres a light side and I would hope that some of the people who became powerful and insanely rich through Bitcoin, would use it to do good. And that its not an inherent system that those people would become like despotic, tyrant nation states. That money could be used a lot of different ways."
## [1] " I guess so, but you are still setting up a world in which there are oligarchs. Youre setting up like a mass concentration of wealth-"
## [1] " Yeah. But we live in a world where there are oligarchs already."
## [1] " Yeah and its not great. Its not great."
## [1] " I mean I dont see how you disrupt currency and also end oligarchy simultaneously."
## [1] " Well look, thats the problem with things like Ripple right, where they start out so concentrated. I guess that-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The thing that I would think And this is what I think actually will happen and this is like my hottest take-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which I think that there will be a minable coin in the future that will probably be less centralized in wealth. And that because people will be more used to the idea of crypto, that it wont be as concentrated and that that feature, that it is not so concentrated that there arent these massive dents clusters of wealth, that that will cause people to actually buy into a little bit more, because they can buy into a more democratic vision. Like-"
## [1] " Kang coin. Its for the people."
## [1] " Kang coin for the people, like lets do it. But like the problem-"
## [1] " So part of the way Kang coin works is sort of like magnetism. If you get too much Kang coin, like it repels other Kang coin."
## [1] " Yeah. You can only Your Kang coins are capped, right? Like I actually dont think I would do that. But that is If something spread and was mine to add paste, where it was sort of by propulsion was more evenly distributed, I actually think that that would probably be a better vision of it. And maybe thats what the people who are behind Ethereum are hoping for."
## [1] " I dont really see how Ethereum is in improvement in this respect, other than its a different group of people whove become the oligarchs."
## [1] " I personally just dont think its good for 12 random people to have 7% of the worlds wealth. Thats just me. All right. So go-"
## [1] " I mean theres also like a timeline where like Xapo is involved in some sort of like insane like atomic accident or something that-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like I mean the incentives-"
## [1] " EMP baby."
## [1] " Destroy Xapo, if Bitcoin really was a million dollars would be intense. You know?"
## [1] " Now that would be a good movie."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Breaking into Xapo to do an EMP to like wipe out all of this wealth."
## [1] " Yeah. Kang coin can reconquer the world."
## [1] " Exactly. Oh, maybe the Kang coin should just fund the Kang coin movie."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " It should be a production house where we should make all the dumb Bitcoin movies that we think of."
## [1] " The Jaytoshi Saga."
## [1] " All right. So the second part of the Xapo story is how it actually works and this is something that I think was very interesting to me at least, which is This is from Bloombergs story, At Xapo, retrieving Bitcoin from the vault takes about two days. The company verifies a clients identity and authenticates a request before manually signing the transactions with private keys from multiple vault locations. Approval from three separate vaults is required for any transactions to be authorized. The company also offers customers a trading desk to buy and sell Bitcoin and created the first Bitcoin debit card to spend it."
## [1] " Well for starters, thats the first scene in the movie, is its you during those two days. Youre getting verified."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " But youre really a mole whos breaking into Xapo to like destroy it from the inside-"
## [1] " Yeah. Im taking like a mental map."
## [1] " But youre posing as like a wealthy Korean business man, whos like eye scan youve stolen. Youre like Youre wearing his eye balls."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly."
## [1] " I mean that sounds like pretty good security. This is interesting to me because one of the thing we hypothesized I think during the basement tapes, was that ultimately rich people were gonna wanting to buy into Bitcoin through some sort of an ETF or some sort of a basically an abstracted way that was secure, where they basically just owned stock. And this presents a different, I think superior vision, which is if you really have that much money, just buy hire someone to buy a bunch of Bitcoin and go put it in this place that has a two day wait and the most insane security procedures in the world. As long as youre putting it making a big investment, thats probably more cost effective than using one of these GBTC like kind of investment products."
## [1] " Yeah and I think that if youre like a Bitcoin purest, it is certainly the most pure vision of it."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I mean it actually makes Bitcoin seem very cool."
## [1] " Its cool to have an internet thats not on the internet. Like they just have like Theres just like a Like you know? Its like just dead inside Xapo. The computers cant talk to anyone."
## [1] " Yeah. Im picturing like a very, very old man hunched over, walking like from vault to vault."
## [1] " Yeah, with like a-"
## [1] " Writing down-"
## [1] " Big, big key thing with like thousands of little keys on it."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah. And hes like writing down the private keys on a little piece of paper and walking it over."
## [1] " Mr. Kang, you can come in now."
## [1] " Oh, thank you. Oh, hello Mr. Kang. Yeah, exactly. Hes like, What will your withdrawal It sounds awesome actually."
## [1] " How was your stay at the Swiss town in the Alps Mr. Kang?"
## [1] " Maybe we should put our very small amount of Bitcoin into Xapo just so that we could get the service."
## [1] " I dont think youre allowed. I think its like you have to like meet some sort of minimum, right?"
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " I dont know."
## [1] " Im sure. Im sure."
## [1] " We should try and get Casares on the show. I know its a long shot, but come on the show, man."
## [1] " Yeah, answer all of our questions."
## [1] " Hes a friend of a friend to me. Im gonna try and talk him into it."
## [1] " Well cut you into the movie rights."
## [1] " Thats what I said. I think we should just ICO this movie about us breaking into Xapo and then well use that money and put it in Xapo."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly."
## [1] " And not actually make the movie."
## [1] " Well give him a producer credit."
## [1] " All we need to do is story board this story out."
## [1] " Yeah. Start a kick starter that only takes that only deals in cryptocurrency."
## [1] " Well there must be competing Xapos out there or people must trying to create competition for this."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah. I mean look its too good of an idea and it is one that basically takes out or seems to take out the biggest fear that one would have if you had a shit load of Bitcoin, which is what if someone kidnaps me, what if I get hacked, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera."
## [1] " Yeah and it also creates like a framework where you can imaging like hodling across hundreds of years."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " You know like post apocalyptic movie where people are like walking across the like shattered remains of Europe to try to get to Xapo to like get access to these billions of dollars."
## [1] " Have you seen the land before time?"
## [1] " I have."
## [1] " I feel like we could make a movie that was like where Xapo was like the oasis, you know?"
## [1] " Oh, yeah."
## [1] " And that the world has become a post apocalyptic hellscape and a small group of people are trying to make it to Xapo."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which is the only place with money in the world and its been walled off and like Its like Elon Musks computer deals."
## [1] " Oh, see I In my vision, the world was a scorched wasteland and the people were walking to Xapo so they could get the Bitcoin out to like restart the world economy-"
## [1] " Why would you need a world economy if theres no world economy left?"
## [1] " I mean-"
## [1] " Like what is Bitcoin worth in like a scorched earth scenario?"
## [1] " Its like the key to rebuilding civilization, is to get the Bitcoin network back up."
## [1] " Explain how."
## [1] " I think we have to cut this off before like we just turn this into a Bitcoin movies podcast."
## [1] " Yeah, like the stoned Bitcoin movies podcast."

## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Jay."
## [1] " Whats up?"
## [1] " Did you read the Bitcoin Standard?"
## [1] " I did. I mean, it actually was a little bit of an effort. And I had to scrap it together from different parts of the internet. But I believe that I got all the pages together."
## [1] " After we announced this, I assumed that you would have purchased the book. But instead, I understand that youre working from like a PDF you got off of Reddit?"
## [1] " Not entirely! To tell our future guest, the author of the book, I attempted to buy it on Kindle, and it had even a price on Kindle that I could order it on. And so I was going to pay it, but it was only in the sample. So it was like the prologue, the introduction, and the first chapter."
## [1] " That was it shows before you pay I think."
## [1] " Well I went back and I try to actually pay, and then I was like, oh no, Im in trouble. And then I did what I do when I cant get an NBA game to stream. So I went on like basically Bitcoin book streaming, like subreddit."
## [1] " Last week we had Art Kang, this week, bootlegger Kang."
## [1] " Yeah, like, its one of these things where, well look, you and I are both in our, I would say late thirties."
## [1] " Yeah. Got liveshare Kang in that."
## [1] " And I think that the one sort of weird artifact of our exact age is that we probably should just pay for things in the full way. But we just try and hack them to save like fourteen cents or something like that."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Anyways, so the point being, I did read it."
## [1] " Well that, before we get going, the point being the book is only ten dollars in print on Amazon. If you havent picked it up, pick it up. This is kind of our like introduction to the book. So were only going to do the first couple chapters. Youre going to be able to catch up if you want to catch up. And were just going to start talking about things that were thinking about as we read this book. Jay, whatd you think?"
## [1] " I thought it was a very interesting and provocative argument for Bitcoin. Being a very impressionable man, right, I find myself at times scratching my head and saying, hm. Like you know, like maybe I should just become a full on Bitcoin maximalist."
## [1] " Yeah, I mean, in some ways the vision doesnt seem that crazy. Once you sort of start seeing the big leaps that have come before."
## [1] " Look, I think what he has presented us is a revision of the white paper. So for a lot of people who got into Bitcoin who werent there from the very beginning, we have a shorthand of these sorts of ideas. Of what money is, how Bitcoin fits into the evolution of money. But its never really fully articulated for any of us. And I think that we get, we sort of have a piecemeal understanding of it. And what this book does over the first three chapters and which I actually appreciated, even though there were parts obviously that I think anybody would, you know, Im sure Saifedean wants people to disagree with, there were parts I disagreed with. But it was very nice to see the whole thing laid out."
## [1] " Its interesting that you brought up the white paper there. That wasnt what I thought about it in relation to the white paper. My thought when I was reading this, and basically like the second chapter, which is Monetary Metals, kind of goes through all of these previous incarnations of how weve created currency from scratch here on earth. And I was like, oh, this is definitely the stuff that Satoshi was interested in when he made Bitcoin. I always thought of Satoshi as a cryptographer. And a person interested in computer science, and it made me think of Satoshi in a more humanities, economics-based light. As someone who had really studied this human problem of currency as probably a big part of at least his passion in the world."
## [1] " Yeah, and I think that some of the earlier people who are interested in the space, whether it be like Zeba or, really anybody who was working on this currency projects before, that was also part of their interest. And I think that the 2008 crash really pushed a lot of those ideas even further when the government just started printing money. But lets get to that a little bit later."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " So lets start with the introduction, who is written by the man who has blocked me on Twitter, who seems to come up every single time in our episodes, Nassim Taleb. And he wrote the introduction."
## [1] " And I would like him, Im going to try to get him to come on the show."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " Id love to have him on the show."
## [1] " I would too!"
## [1] " Hes like, I think a, he hates journalists so Id like to see him like go after you a little bit. Additionally, one of the things that actually I learned in trying to get in touch with Saifedean Ammous, that Taleb was actually influential in him getting this book published. I mean hes not a quote unquote, writer, by trade. He is an economist and a researcher. Although I find his writing very crisp."
## [1] " Yeah, it was, I actually thought it was very readable."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And that the argument was laid out very clearly in a way that I actually appreciated because I expected given Saifedeans somewhat, I think, purposefully heightened and somewhat florid Twitter account that this would be like a really over the top defense of Bitcoin. But its not. It is rational [crosstalk 00:06:39]."
## [1] " No, its even keeled. I actually find it interesting that you have referred to it a couple times as an argument for Bitcoin. Its so smooth that to me a lot of it reads like, and this is what happened through history and of course the logical place wed end up with. Its almost like the way that Marx describes the end state of socialism. Not as, hey, this would be a good idea. We should fight for it! But as like this is a historical inevitability."
## [1] " Yeah, and Marx is a very interesting example to use when talking about anarchocapitalist. But yes, I do think the rhetorical techniques are similar.So Taleb writes the introduction, I will say and I think you would agree, Taleb doesnt, he writes a very short introduction. Its kind of like an extended blurb."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " But there was one part of it that was, rational markets do not require any individual trader to be rational. In fact, they work well under zero intelligence. Zero intelligence crowd under the right design, works better than a Soviet style management comprised of maximally intelligent human beings. And so what hes making an argument for is essentially markets are going to stabilize over time and that theyre going to have their own logic to them. And that they dont need actors within the market, they just need to exist. And that thats what his argument for Bitcoin is."
## [1] " The way that that viewpoint works is that Bitcoin is by its very creation by the Satoshi moment, like on some inexorable rollercoaster ride towards ubiquity. Although I think its interesting that Taleb, hes made this point in other writing that Ive read of his. Does not say that Bitcoin is necessarily going to succeed or not succeed. Hes like, the cryptocurrency itself, the cat is out of the bag. And even if this fails, it can be recreated now. The idea can never go away."
## [1] " That is the real question I think that was sort of facing crypto right now. And its something that weve talked about before, but it is really, I mean theres just news that is coming out that well discuss later in the show. But its about sort of the high concentration of Bitcoin in a very small number of peoples hands. It makes me wonderful if that is sustainable or that will sort of tank the idea eventually. But I dont think that-"
## [1] " Really? See I thought that argument, like when you look at Bitcoin compared to all the other currencies. Its like pretty spread out."
## [1] " No, well like the other cryptocurrencies."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " But not like world currencies."
## [1] " No, not world currencies, yes. Not legitimate currencies."
## [1] " Thats a separate argument, but I do think that the question of whether or not it will be Bitcoin is one that should be seriously asked right now. And I think eh is asking that same question as well. The person who is not asking that question is Saifedean Ammous, right? And so this book starts with a very bare bones and very sort of logical progression of an explanation of money. Did you know all this stuff about money?"
## [1] " I would say that I knew like 50 percent of it. But I didnt know it, know it."
## [1] " At the start of money then, Saifedean sort of starts with this idea of bartering, right? That the barter system is one that still exists today and it is by far the most logical way to exchange something. Which is like youll say Ill give you these fish, and you give me, lets say those apples, right? And thats the barter that you do. And he explains that the problem is that when you go from saying I will give you these fish, you give me a house, right? Like, how do you make that exchange? Like obviously there are many problems with it because you cant, how many fish do you need for a house? Now, do you give the fish at the beginning, or do you give it at the end when all the fish are dead? You know, how do you deal with a perishable good, versus like an actual thing, and how do you make that transaction over time? So thats a very logical thing, I think thats at the core of all economics. And I think thats where he starts."
## [1] " Well, and in the twenty-first century, theres such a great diversity of goods. Theres such an assymetry of what one person would have that the other person would need. And then that working the other direction. Kind of reminds me of, you ever buy stuff on Craigslist?"
## [1] " Not as much as you do. You seem to have bought everything in your life off Craigslist at some point. So not quite like you. So why dont you explain Craigslist?"
## [1] " So sometimes Ill be trying to buy like a synthesizer or something. And theyre like, also well consider bartering and trades. What is the chances that I have something of equal value that this person wants? With like no guide whatsoever. That just seems like a pretty far fetched assumption to make about the world. So it kind of feels like almost immediately you start needing an intermediary if youre going to be able to do almost any kind of business."
## [1] " Yeah, and thats his argument is that the history of exchanges starts with bartering, and then you immediately run into these problems when its not just like hunter gatherers trading things with one another. And they need to actually trade goods. So you need something that stands in for some sort of promise, right? Which is saying like this is worth this. This is a store of exchange, or this is a store of value. And that theres a logical progression that goes through a lot of different things. Shells, for example, he talks about a lot. There were like seashells that were used."
## [1] " Those rocks with the holes in the middle of them."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. And then all these types of money have problems with them. So for example, wampum. Did you know what wampum was before?"
## [1] " I was not familiar with what wampum was."
## [1] " Okay, so wampum was a native american tribes version of currency, and it was shells, right?"
## [1] " Yeah, seashells."
## [1] " Seashells. And at some point, some explorers I think came, and they sort of flooded the market with wampum. And then the wampum became devalued."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And he says that thats bad for any number of reasons. Like did you understand the reasons he was saying that was bad?"
## [1] " Well, I mean, he gives all these historical examples that seem like theyre divergent, but then end in the same place, which is technology catches up, and So even when people like try to fight that devaluation, usually when technology catches up, and people can figure out how to make whatever it is youre using as money, that thing is fucked."
## [1] " Yeah, so thats one of the principles that I think hes laying out here, which is that money needs to kind of be scarce, right? The resource needs to be scarce, it needs to be very unique in the sense that you cant just go get more wampum out of like the wampum hole that nobody has discovered and then flood the market with new wampum."
## [1] " The end state of all this is that we resolve on these metal currencies, theres been many metal currencies, but gold, silver, bronze, are like the biggest one in history that require a certain amount of labor to extract the medal, and its hard enough that the market cannot be flooded. And if it is flood, or if you do mine more, its not enough so that it undermines the value of the stuff."
## [1] " Yeah, theres no sea captain coming in with like a whole bunch of gold."
## [1] " I mean the interesting, so like, those are sort of the end state of all these ideas or the like pre-fiat money end state of all these. Like we talk about like FUD, and what the like greatest existential threats to like Bitcoin system is. The greatest existential threat to the gold system was like alchemy, basically. If someone had figured out alchemy, it would have been like all over."
## [1] " Yeah, well if you could turn regular metal, thats probably why alchemy was such a good racket for so long."
## [1] " Thats what Im saying!"
## [1] " So Saifedean goes on to outline his case then for why Bitcoin, given all these things that we know about money, is the best version of money that there ever has been, right? And that what used to be the gold standard, which is, like the problems with gold is that its hard to divide up. So if I bring out a nugget of gold for your synthesizer, and I haggle you down to-"
## [1] " Id be like, thats a big nug man."
## [1] " Yeah, I haggle you down to like half an ounce of gold for your synthesizer. Its very difficult for me to sit there and like hack off half an ounce and give it to you."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " And so thats why paper money exists. Because its more divisible, and it is based on gold. So I think when the United States first dollar was printed, like an ounce of gold was twenty dollars or something like that. He mentioned it in his book."
## [1] " I mean, I didnt realize that the gold standard wasnt established until I think like the late 1800s. So like even the end state of gold is like a last 200 years kind of thing. Like were in a pretty young state of money."
## [1] " For the type of money that we have right now?"
## [1] " Yeah. Fiat money, like money that originally represented gold in Fort Knox. And then was printed way more than there is gold in Fort Knox."
## [1] " Yeah, and I would argue that in the United States that we had another revolution in money beyond the switchover to fiat currency, which started in probably the 80s when Wall Street was basically printing money and money stopped meaning anything. And then 2008 obviously where peoples relationship with all this fiat currency and Wall Street radically changed. And now were in some sort of flux period. And so I think that within that continuum it does make sense that something would change. Its not like were dealing with something thats deeply rooted and has thousand of years of history that seems pretty intractable. And I think that of all the arguments makes, at least at the beginning of this book, is the most convincing to me. Which is that if you zoom out a little bit, the idea that this would switch over does actually make sense. Its not like human nature or anything like that to have a fiat currency that used to be peg off the gold standard and is no longer."
## [1] " He also makes a pretty strong argument at least to me, that this problem of how do you keep money and hold its value over time? Any solution to that problem is in some ways a gamble. Whether its holding fiat currency, buying commodities. Whatever youre doing, youre in some ways gambling on some future state. And as he goes through all these historical examples of different kinds of money, eventually the long term money of just holding money keeps going down and people are driven to speculate on wilder and wilder things, rather than just holding their money. Do you mind if I read a quick quote from him [crosstalk 00:17:02]."
## [1] " Yeah, no, please."
## [1] " It should be of interest to modern Keynesian economists as well as the present generation of investors that although the emperors of Rome frantically tried to manage their economies, hes talking about these early Roman gold coins that the emperor kept clipping bits off of. They only succeeded in making matters worse. Price and wage controls and leaguer tender laws were passed, but it was like trying to hold back the tides. Rioting, corruption, lawlessness, and mindless mania for speculation and gambling engulfed the empire like a plague, with money so unreliable and debased, speculation in commodities became far more attractive than producing them."
## [1] " What you described right there in that passage seems very similar to where we are right now."
## [1] " Absolutely."
## [1] " Everything is wild speculation and peoples idea of store of value is no longer in the country itself but or in civic or government institutions, but instead are in tech companies. When you do that you are engaging in wild speculation. You know, if you have all your money invested in Amazon or Apple or something like that, thats wild speculation by anyones standards."
## [1] " Well I would also argue that what youre seeing people doing cross a variety of investment activities over the last twenty years is betting on the future. If you bought apple when it IPOed in 1980, you were betting on the future. If you bought Apple stock when the iPhone came out, youre betting on the future. If youre buying Tesla right now, against the most massive market shorting in history, youre betting on a specific future. And if youre buying cryptos now, youre betting on a specific future. So people have shown a wild appetite to gamble speculatively on what the future will be like."
## [1] " Yeah, and that doesnt even count things like real estate and everything."
## [1] " Oh, sure."
## [1] " So we do live, I think, and Im sure some economists will tweet at us and say that were wrong, but it feels to me at least, and maybe it is-"
## [1] " We encourage that by the way."
## [1] " It is just you and me being also being very speculative. People with gambling problems."
## [1] " Its a human impulse. Thats what hes saying. People felt this way during the Roman empire. Like, its nothing new."
## [1] " And part of that I think does have to do with the fact that our faith in this currency and in the stability of the economy, for example like, it used to be that people worked for a company and that they would be paid a salary, but they would also be paid in the company stock, and it would never occur to them to trade that stock for something else, you know? That they could count on a certain stable life of comfort. And thats not where we are right now, you know, we have people, like look at the people that got really rich off Bitcoin or Ethereum. Like theyre sort of the people that people look up to now. Its not people who work twenty years anyway."
## [1] " I was struck, I mean he gives some great historical examples, but once you start wracking your mind, you can keep coming up with different ways that weve created weird markets that people then speculated on. And sometimes they were dead ends, and sometimes they led to giant economies. I was reading about Michael Cohen and his taxi medallions. I didnt know what the origin of the New York City taxi medallion is."
## [1] " Oh my God, I know all about this, but go ahead."
## [1] " So its, during the Great Depression, in New York City, almost everyone was out of work. And lots of people had cars. So people would just start driving around trying to pick people up for like a little bit of money to drive them somewhere. And eventually there was like, huge traffic. People were like, we gotta regulate this, theres too many cars on the road. So they were like, all right, were only going to grant a certain number of taxi medallions. What struck me about this medallion story was how quickly it went from being this regulation of basically unemployed people trying to make money on the side, to people were like massively speculating and accumulating taxi medallions."
## [1] " It is actually, I cannot think of a worse, if you were going to be, how would you get most wrecked and be like listen, you just get up to nose leveraged in taxi medallions? There was a period of my time, Aaron Lammer, where I considered speculating on taxi medallions. [crosstalk 00:21:50]"
## [1] " If I could short taxi medallions, I would!"

That did happen, it was very rare. Its that this whole thing got you know, swapped up by a small number of people who are either prospecting for it or were straight up mafia, you know?"
## [1] " Or in the case of Michael Cohen, were like Jewish attorney mafia."
## [1] " Yeah. Exactly. So thats the problem with the deflationary currency or any sort of deflationary And I do think that you can say that taxi medallions are a currency. Is that once its fucked, its very hard to unfuck it, right?"
## [1] " And I think thats the risk of Bitcoin, which is youre like, this is great. Its taxi medallion! Also if an Uber comes out, this could be worth almost nothing."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly. And also now that I have these medallions, and Im making money off of it, nobody else can have medallions, because I also control the guy who prints more medallions. And Ive told him that he cannot print any more medallions. So, a few weeks ago we talked about Jim Surawaks article that he wrote in MIT Technology Review. And one of the things that he said was that the reason that fiat currency is good is because you can unfuck things. Like you can figure out how to solve massive problems that happen."
## [1] " You can engineer an economy."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " And Bitcoin is not an engineered economy."
## [1] " Yes, like basically Bitcoin right now is taxi medallions at the height of Michael Cohen, fucking leveraging himself, borrowing money to buy more taxi medallions."
## [1] " And I think to their credit, people who believe in Bitcoin, true maximalists. People who believe fully in Bitcoin are like yeah, thats better. Like dont engineer the economy. Like the example we just read of Rome, its like they did all this crazy stuff trying to engineer the economy, but people kept wildly speculating. And it ultimately led to x and y. So I dont embrace total free market libertarianism myself, but I find a lot worthwhile about the idea of Bitcoin and I think to criticize it from any sort of a standpoint that we need to engineer economies. If you believe that youre never going to believe in cryptocurrencies. Theres like a fundamental disconnect. You either want engineered economies or you want some sort of amorphous, unengineered world money pool."
## [1] " And thats what I appreciate about Saifedeans book, which is that it is a very clear eyed, if you believe in crypto, this is what you should believe in. Like you should be an Austrian school economics person. And you should believe in anarchocaptalism. You should believe that, and I dont know if he would say that this is true, but if he is consistent with his opinions, which I imagine he is, hes okay with the Uber coming along."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Like hes okay with Michael Cohen getting completely wrecked. He doesnt think that the government should step in and save Michael Cohen because Michael Cohen was profiting off a New York City taxi licensing commission that was completely corrupt, and was inefficient and was not servicing the number of people who needed it. And so when Uber comes along, it destroys it, you know. And thats a good thing. So that could happen to Bitcoin as well. I dont think he would say it would because he would say that all the other coins are shit except for Bitcoin. And thats why Bitcoin is good."

But like the way you just described, you know, dont save the economy. The very first thing we know about Satoshi is that Bitcoin is directly inspired by the like, banking bailout. Its like one of the only things we sort of know is that what is what he was thinking about when he launched Bitcoin. So I think if you look at that as the foundational myth of the Bitcoin narrative, were driving towards some point where economies can no longer be bailed out because theyre not under the control of governments. If you look at, if youre a true Bitcoin maximalist. I also think he makes an argument, Im wondering what you think about this. That theres no real half way with Bitcoin. That the only path for Bitcoin is maximalism at some point."
## [1] " Yeah, and I actually found that part of his book to be the most convincing. Was that this thing only really will get to its full potential if it becomes the standard for the world. And I actually-"
## [1] " I didnt even think about the title until you like said that."
## [1] " Yeah, I have real problems with that pragmatically, but I actually think I might agree with it in a theoretical idea where I dont even know which way I would go, but I would say yeah, if its going to work, it needs to be full on. It cant be this thing that only certain people use. And is like an interesting idea and is only used for certain types of transactions. It need to be like the store of value for everything. And thats where the idea, the deflationary currency really needs to be, it needs to be the only deflationary currency. And like I actually found that to be quite convincing."
## [1] " It made me think about like what the last project that I had heard about thats goal was the whole world. Which is probably Facebook. If you invested in Facebook, when it was already being publicly traded, youre basically like whats the ceiling? Well the ceiling is the entire world. And at a certain point, as enough people invest in these things. Like an investor in Facebook, if youre buying Facebook, you know as its already up there, youre basically like I think it will. And at a certain point, if youre buying Bitcoin, you have to believe in a Bitcoin maximalism. As Bitcoin gets up over 20, 50, 100 thousand dollars, if youre still buying then, the only way youre going to win is if Bitcoin maximalism takes over the world."
## [1] " Well yeah because the price, even at 10000 right now or whatever its at, 9000. That potential is baked into the price right now. Its not like people think that a Bitcoin is actually worth 9000 dollars right now. Theyre baking in the idea that perhaps this is going to take over the world. He actually brings Facebook up in the book in a way. Where he says, well look, these types of ideas have worked in technology where like look Facebook became the standard because it allowed for certain features. And as the network grew and after a certain size, all other competition became impossible. So like Google could create Orchid or Google Plus, it didnt matter. You know, like things like MySpace fell off obviously. Massive, massive companies could try and make social networks, but it wouldnt matter because Facebook had gotten a certain amount of share in which there was no feature you could add could actually replicate the features that happen when you have a ton of people on it, right?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " And he says that for Bitcoin to work it needs to reach that point. He believes, he seems to believe that it is close to that right now."

## [1] " The number of people who use it. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah."

## [1] " I think that the current price compensates for a lot of scenarios that are not Bitcoin maximalism. That are like, hey, Bitcoin gets so big, its as big as the fifteenth largest economy or something like that. But it does not totally take over in that kind of way. Did the book make you want to buy Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Yeah, it did. And you know, I think we should go over one example that he brings up. Of why Bitcoin is good. And he, this is about Bitcoins potential to influence governments, right? That right now is a veil between the government and the people. So that even when you have the gold standard and you have dollars that are pegged to the gold standard. Like we cant peer into Fort Knox or walk in there with like a little scale or something like that and make sure that the amount of gold that they say they have is what they actually have."
## [1] " Similar to my like arguments about bad actors on block chains, which is like, yes, all this works if you assume that people are not lying. But in a non-public block chain, there is a certain trust that people are not lying, just like there would be in Fort Knox there."
## [1] " Yeah, and he is essentially saying that when you have this radical transparency of money, that people will, and when money is scarce, that people are actually much more prudent about how they spend money. And so his argument is that this will affect everything. So people will actually become more engaged in how the government spends money because they dont assume that there is an endless amount of it. And this, I actually find somewhat convincing, because like, you know what the federal deficit is right now?"
## [1] " I would not try to say it on air."
## [1] " Do you have any idea how the deficit affects the government functions?"
## [1] " Generally, like debt ceiling shut downs is the main time I hear about it."
## [1] " Nobody knows any of this. Like nobody knows actually how much money the United States government has. Nobody actually understands how it, every once in a while its like USA today will make a cool infographic that shows how much of its military spending or whatever. But thats it, you know. And he says that if money is scarce, if it is on the block chain, if it is very transparent, then the government will be forced into only making prudent decisions. He says that that will actually cut down military spending, that because while people will feel a certain need to do things like improve health care or whatever like that, what they wont do is sort of say, hey we should fund this small operation in Yemen. And we should fund this small operation in the in the Philippines. And this one in the Sudan. That once people are actually aware of how much money is being spent on those types of things, that they will backlash and they will vote people out of office. Do you find that convincing?"
## [1] " I think the government stuff is the final leap, where I dont quite understand how Bitcoin works as a governmental currency."
## [1] " Well, it would just be the money that everybody uses around the world, right, so then-"
## [1] " So the US federal reserve would be-"
## [1] " Would be Bitcoin."
## [1] " 10 million Bitcoin. [crosstalk 00:40:06]"
## [1] " Yeah, well that would be a lot."
## [1] " If were doing really well. Thats an American maximalist scenario."
## [1] " Exactly, thats Aaron the imperialist talking."
## [1] " You know, Trumplandia, of course."
## [1] " I mean, I think that its more just what happens psychologically when money is scarce and transparent, is what hes talking about."
## [1] " Right, know I under-"
## [1] " That people would really track it a lot harder. And that theyd be more interested in short term personal outcomes instead of these sort of abstract campaigns that toss them personally money and that they would be more prone to push for things like healthcare or you know, like social security than they would be to push for like a campaign in Yemen that they dont know why were doing it."
## [1] " Right, and the counterargument to all this would be the argument that we talked about. That a Bitcoin economy would be unkind, perhaps even cruel. And all the engineering that is done on the economy would be undone to disastrous effects for human life in America."
## [1] " 95 percent of the people in America would be too poor to even get themselves to a polling station is the alternative."
## [1] " Yeah, and I think that theres usually a lot of guns in these scenarios. Like when I really start playing them out in my mind, Im like, I believe in that world I think Im also long on gun stocks."
## [1] " All right, well is that a good place to end?"
## [1] " Yeah, thats not a world I want to live in. But Id still buy some Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yes, the answer is always we should buy Bitcoin."
## [1] " Okay, so Jay, this was great, I enjoyed talking about this book with you."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Were going to get you a real copy of the book for next week."
## [1] " Ive already ordered it."
## [1] " And people at home, order the book. We kind of did like the first couple chapters, a little bit of maybe chapter three there. So four through seven well try and do next week. Let us know if you are listening and you have questions in your reading, comments. Wed love to hear from you, were going to talk to the author of this book, Saifedean Ammous, on the last episode. So listen along, catch up if you can. And well be there in a few weeks. Yeah, thanks for listening. You got anything you want to talk about Jay, anything you want to promo?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Push that show man!"
## [1] " What show?"
## [1] " Oh you mean this show! Thats right, thats what Im talking about."

## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron"
## [1] "Aaron: Welcome, Nathaniel Popper."
## [1] "Aaron: Hows your Consensus going?"
## [1] "Aaron: You only got to go to one of the two Snoop concerts?"
## [1] "Aaron: Is this, like, the biggest week of the year for you? Is this like Fashion Week if you work at T Magazine?"
## [1] "Aaron: I saw a lot of tweets coming out from it that, like, Wow, this is surprisingly legit this year. The whole production value seems like its stepped up a notch."
## [1] "Aaron: I read your book this week."
## [1] "Aaron: Which was kind of an unusual experience, because its new enough to be pretty new, but then there was a mental block I had against reading it because it was over a year old and I was like, Eh, this is all old hat. And it was a surprisingly emotional journey reading back through this sequence in these different peoples lies. And it strikes me-"
## [1] "Aaron: I laughed, I cried, I learned a little something. And it had struck me that youve been on this journey. When did you first get exposed to the coin world?"
## [1] "Aaron: Its funny thinking back. That story is, like, perfect buzzword SEO magic. These minor celebrities you know from a movie, like, nascent technology and massive financial gain."
## [1] "Aaron: The bonus."
## [1] "Aaron: Trifecta?"
## [1] "Aaron: At what point did writing about Bitcoin become part of your week-to-week life?"
## [1] "Aaron: Those stories feel, comparatively, pretty small [crosstalk 00:36:07]."
## [1] "Aaron: Like, those people are getting in line and just merging into your story so you dont have to cover them separately?"
## [1] "Aaron: I wanted to ask you about that, because if there was a point in time where it felt like, Wow, this isnt enough for a full-time job, right now, like, covering ICOs and covering Bitcoin core I mean, these are, like, disparate fields."
## [1] "Aaron: It feels like you want a team if you are going to cover all of this stuff."
## [1] "Aaron: Warring worlds, really."
## [1] "Aaron: Thats a consistent theme. You can just say that after any statement and everyone thinks everyone else is an idiot."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah. Do people think that, when youre hanging out with Bitcoin Cash advocates theyre like, Oh, Nathaniel is clearly more into Bitcoin Cash than the regular Bitcoin."
## [1] "Aaron: Ah, youre like a ref?"
## [1] "Aaron: Youre like an NBA playoffs rep."
## [1] "Aaron: And youre in the tank for Silicon Valley and really want Coinbase, Ethereum world to thrive."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah, I mean, one thing I really like about the coverage that you do in the New York Times is, if youre going to write about something like, say Ripple, it seems like youre trying to write the definitive article about Ripple, more than the, like, 97th 300-word blog post about some new Ripple test program-"
## [1] "Aaron: With DHL and Malaysia or Theres a level to which the news is being generated constantly, but I dont know that reading 100 news items about Ripple actually tells you that much about what Ripple is. And the way that youre able to focus in on sort of the general, like, What is happening here? Is helpful for someone like me whos interested in this, but I dont want to dedicate two or three hours of my day every day to reading about it. Are you reading about it two or three hours every day?"
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah. Often not very elegantly put out news."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah, even exist in three to five years."
## [1] "Aaron: I would consider it successful if a lot of these projects made an existing product that fell on deaf ears. That would be, like, a huge accomplishment for the majority of coins."
## [1] "Aaron: Thats like making it to the conference finals and its like, We can all go home proud here. People didnt want our Ethereum-based casino."
## [1] "Aaron: What would a company that was trying to behave honestly and for the longterm, like, how would we sort of know? I feel like we have a lot of tools for trying to understand whats dishonest, but I dont even know how I would know if there was a legitimate project out there."
## [1] "Aaron: Not that Im asking you for investment advice, but you do sort through a million people who would like you to write about them."
## [1] "Aaron: And even if you were a computer scientist, you would be not an economist, and you would be not a cryptographer. Theres no way you would master all of these skills."
## [1] "Aaron: Or its like, Youll be able to use this to make more things that can then themselves generate more-"
## [1] "Aaron: Theres a huge amount of projects, a huge amount of the best-known projects basically are to create more projects with. I would even say that Ethereum could be categorized this way."
## [1] "Aaron: Yes, CryptoKitties are real. You can really create them on the blockchain."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah. In reading back through your book, one of the things that struck me was how long it took for people to realize that the truly non-anonymous nature of Bitcoin was going to be a pretty big issue; the fact that you could just I mean, people bring it up early on and are like, Hey, its actually a terrible criminal currency because theres a paper trace of every single thing thats ever happened on it. But it goes along this really long path and then, eventually, like, in the last year, that becomes a major issue leading up to, like, Zcash is now being listed on Gemini."
## [1] "Aaron: Oh, interesting."
## [1] "Aaron: Caught old-school."
## [1] "Aaron: When you were covering the Bitcoin story early on, I noticed a real contrast between writing about something like Ripple. Ripples a company. You can be like, That guy, hes the CEO. Theyve got a PR person who will respond to your queries. And then Bitcoin is this weird, amorphous theres no quote from Satoshi Nakamoto, even the Bitcoin Foundation and Bitcoin Core are these kind of weird, more nonprofit-y type entities than a true company. What were the challenges of trying to cover something that had no central authority or central voice?"
## [1] "Aaron: Having seen a limited amount of Roger Ver videos, these people are not media-trained."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah. I was going to ask you. I mean, I assume you do not hold cryptocurrencies yourself?"
## [1] "Aaron: Thats policy most places where people are covering this stuff, or I would have seen a disclosure from you. Do you ever feel like youre missing out or youre not getting I think of Bitcoin as such an experiential thing. Like, when you think back on Roger Ver going and putting it on peoples phones. Like, part of the whole first wave of Bitcoin, ideologically, was that you had to try it for yourself, hold your own private keys. Im curious, like, what going through all of that period was like for you as someone who was not doing any of those things that were supposed to teach you what it was really like."
## [1] "Aaron: Are you short everything youre not in in the entire market?"
## [1] "Aaron: This has come up repeatedly on the show, because we decided, not because we thought it was some genius idea just because we were already speculating on coins that we would do a show about our misadventures in this, and we havent even been in it that long. Ive only been in for maybe a year. I already have nostalgic associations with alt coins like they were Super Nintendo games I was into. Where Im like, Im still holding Sumokoin because I made this joke on the show for a long time about all this Sumokoin I was holding. I mean, as a test of irrational thought, you can get yourself from 0 to 60 pretty fast the minute you start putting some real money into these kind of investments."
## [1] "Aaron: I mean, sometimes it even goes a step further than that, which is a lot of these, like, micro cap coins, when theres a revelation that its just an outright scam people are like, I dont know. I think it might come back though."
## [1] "Aaron: People are, like, scamming is not off the table. Like, a good scam is still a good investment."
## [1] "Aaron: Photoshopped."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah, I mean, how are you covering the story of all these people all over the country who are buying into crypto? I think we generally see crypto from the top down, like, the creators and sort of the guys who bought low. But really, in America, the story of crypto is people making a Coinbase account and going and putting $500 in. I mean, I guess thats not I often struggle to be like, Is most of the money in this or is most of the money in a Peter Thiel, like, Xapo vault?"
## [1] "Aaron: We refer to them as the Ethereum Teens, because theres, like, a lot of teen investment groups there."
## [1] "Aaron: They werent wrong in that first wave though. We were like, Ha ha, I bet people are going to bid Ripple up to $1 from $0.30 because, you know, psychology. And I was like, Oh shit. This is happening?"
## [1] "Aaron: Their dumb psychology turned out to be a human dumb psychology."
## [1] "Aaron: Im just starting to really wrap my head around Bitcoin maximalism taken literally rather than sort of figuratively. Were doing a book club on the show and Ive been reading Saifedean Ammouss book, The Bitcoin Standard, which is sort of, like, its laying out the case for Bitcoin maximalism."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah. I recommend it. I think its very good. I was sort of comparing it, because at the same time I was reading your book Digital Gold and switching back and forth. Theres lots of long-term questions about Bitcoin that existed three years ago, still exist, that I can sort of move my head around, like, Oh, the electricity. But Im like, Oh, but we actually have more electricity than we need on Earth. Theres a lot of these things that Im like, Yeah, people are going to figure this out."
## [1] "Aaron: The one lingering one of why its hard for me to really embrace the idea of a Bitcoin maximalist worldview is this idea that a very small group of people, many of whom you probably have personally, socially encountered, would inherit, lets just say 10% of the wealth of the world, not inherit, would possess that. Thats the part thats hard for me to sort of project into the future. Even thinking as a reporter, how do you tell the story of, like, If this works, Peter Thiel has 3% of the money in the world.?"
## [1] "Aaron: I dont have a good answer for that question."
## [1] "Aaron: It seems more likely the opposite would happen, which is as Bitcoin becomes more legitimate, a greater share of the Bitcoin would be possessed by, like, funds and various entities that hold large amounts of wealth."
## [1] "Aaron: Continues, yeah, always has worked."
## [1] "Aaron: Just happen to own basically, like, three or four countries worth of money now, just them and professional poker players, as far as Ive come to tell. A lot of people who were playing online poker did very well over the last few years."
## [1] "Aaron: PayPal money becomes venture money, and Uber becomes money that got dumped into Bitcoin, becomes money that ends up in Ethereum. 300% might be conservative in terms of some of the exponential economics."
## [1] "Aaron: What does it mean that the first big idea since the internet, like, really the first thing that competes with the internet in terms of how big it could be didnt really come from Silicon Valley, did not come from the venture capital world, the YCombinator startup world? What does it tell us and how do you think the Valley is reacting to the fact that this one isnt really on their scorecard?"
## [1] "Aaron: Right. We assume Satoshi did not go through YCombinator."
## [1] "Aaron: As an outsider, it feels like, while many people in Silicon Valley profiteered greatly from this, that this idea came without a center authority, in some ways subverts the very idea of a company being behind the big technological leap. I dont know. I guess it sort of starts to feel like a battle for the soul of what it is. Like, is Bitcoin the protocol or is it Coinbase? Is it the consumer vision or is it some essential, ideological core?"
## [1] "Aaron: My final question to you: Whats the big story that excites you now? I feel like each year has this kind of dominant theme. Like, last year was the fork year. Everything was all about forks. What do you see as the most important thing to be keeping your eye on right now?"
## [1] "Aaron: When is something going to happen?"
## [1] "Aaron: Well, thank you so much for doing this interview."
