## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] " You ready for some book club?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Is this your first book club-"
## [1] " What book club?"
## [1] " the book club that you and I are in here? Have you been in a book club before?"
## [1] " Ive never been in a book club."
## [1] " Ive never been in a book club either. Im actually I would say violently against book clubs/."
## [1] " Okay. I have a question. Is it a book club if its two people?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " No, its definitely not a book club."
## [1] " Its a book club."
## [1] " That is two friends reading a book."
## [1] " Well, for starters, its not just us. Its the thousands and thousands of listeners and us."
## [1] " I feel like it needs some sort of snack element, and it needs to be people who want to hang out but dont ever hang out who are drawn together by a book. That doesnt apply for any of us."
## [1] " Well, I would at least say this is an e-Book club, but lowercase e-dash-uppercase-B book club, e-Book club. And we thank all the listeners out there for making this duo an army. Shout out to the Coin Talk World out there, Coin Talk Nation."
## [1] " Is that your way of trying to make Coin World catch on?"
## [1] " Im just gonna keep pushing Coin World.-"
## [1] " For those who dont know, last week Aaron and I went and we recorded a podcast with our friends from Lifehacker."
## [1] " Yeah, The Upgrade."
## [1] " The Upgrade. And Aaron tried to make this phrase Coin World stick the entire podcast."
## [1] " I know. It was fantastic because they were like, the first question was like, What is Bitcoin? And within 30 seconds, I had shilled SUMO and tried to get Coinworld to happen."
## [1] " Does Coin Talk LLC have Coinworld trademarked?"
## [1] " If not, we should definitely. I feel like-"
## [1] " Okay, as long as Im cut in on this, Im fine with Coin World."
## [1] " Im gonna say that the long-term vision of Coin World is that eventually its an amusement park outside Orlando in which you can take a hologram tour through crypto history."
## [1] " Or you can take a ride in the Bitcoin and Ethereum Aston Martins."
## [1] " Yeah. You can talk to Wizard of Oz style talk to Satoshi."
## [1] " Talk to Satoshi. Theres a roller coaster thats like the price of Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yes [crosstalk 00:03:20]-"
## [1] " Its the meme come to life."
## [1] " Thats the kind of sharp catches Im looking for from you."
## [1] " Thank you, thank you."
## [1] " So, the reason Ive never been in a book club I dont even need to ask why youve never been in a book club because your personality in a book club I just-"
## [1] " Itd be terrible."
## [1] " I imagine you would walk out of the first meeting in a huff."
## [1] " I would either say nothing and leave 20 minutes in, or I would become horrible and I would start lecturing everybody."
## [1] " The idea of reading fiction in a group and then being subject to other adults opinion My parents had a book club, and I would always hear people talking about how they did or did not like the characters in the book. That was pretty much all they talked about. Id blow a fuse."
## [1] " Yeah, well, thats why you and I are in a basement right now in our late 30s and are talking about Bitcoin. Thats exactly why."
## [1] " Yeah. Weve been reduced to this."
## [1] " All right, so, this book."
## [1] " This book. Lets pick up with Chapter Four. Im gonna flip to it here. Chapter Four I believe is Government Money."
## [1] " Should we recap a little bit?"
## [1] " To recap last weeks, we talked a lot about the history of stores of value, the history of gold, basically how people have been trying to make money out of objects since time not immemorial but for quite a while."
## [1] " Some of these examples were wampum, which was a bunch of shells. I think it was a type of shell that Native Americans used as currency, or an island, I forget where, I think it was off the coast of Ireland or something like that, where they had big stones with circles in the middle of it. And all these things have been used as currencies in the past. And for reasons that Saifedean Ammous explains, they became flooded. So, somebody figured out a way to dredge a bunch of wampum off the ocean floor I think. And that flooded that market, so that currency was devalued. And it was his way of saying that you need a currency that cant have a massive influx of new currency coming in to devalue it because that screws up all sorts of things."
## [1] " Yeah, I think one of the examples that comes up not only in that chapter but across the book is this colonial example of African societies where cowry beads were traded, and then European traders came in and used the mass production of cowry beads that was available to them and ships to basically take all of the existent wealth out of the country in exchange for a bunch of cowry beads, which rapidly became worthless because of the influx of cowry beads by the colonial invaders."
## [1] " Yeah, white people."
## [1] " Yeah. I would say, yeah, this whole book is, white people."
## [1] " Its a lot of, sigh, white people in this book."
## [1] " Well, its always a little hard to read some of the politics of this book, too, because Saifedean Ammous is Lebanese I believe, which is one of the more complicated I dont even know, someone whos Lebanese could come from many, many backgrounds."
## [1] " Yeah, well, this is our obligatory shout out to Nassim Taleb, also very complicated family history."
## [1] " Also Lebanese."
## [1] " And Lebanese, yeah. He wrote about it quite a bit in The Black Swan, which I still maintain is a good book even though Nassim has blocked me on Twitter."
## [1] " Hopefully we can have a truth and reconciliation episode in which Nassim Taleb ceremonially unblocks you on the show. But talking about government money, we pick up this story at the tail end of the gold standard. So, were talking World War One era, early 20th century here."
## [1] " Yeah, and we want to, I want to at least emphasize that it was at this point in the book where it really becomes a polemic. The first part is a accounting of history. And this part is when he starts making arguments. And one of the arguments that he makes is that World War One became World War One not because necessarily this conflict between a Serbian separatist group and whoever had so many ties to everybody else that they all got drawn in. I think when you and I were probably in history class, there was probably some sort of weird flow chart that showed why World War One happened from the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand."
## [1] " I dont even remember the why. I just remember the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand."
## [1] " Do you remember that because of the band, or do you remember that because of history class?"
## [1] " I think I remember it just because I like that story."
## [1] " Yeah. Its the like the defenestration of Prague, which I vaguely remember."
## [1] " I think also didnt Franz Ferdinands assassin pee his pants before he shot him?"
## [1] " I have no idea."
## [1] " I think he peed his pants. People were like, Look at that man! Hes peed his pants!"
## [1] " Thats something that you-"
## [1] " Then he leapt out and shot him."
## [1] " That mightve been on the curriculum at Berkeley High School but was not at Chapel Hill High School."
## [1] " So, this did dovetail with things that weve talked about before on the show that I didnt totally understand. One of the arguments about moving away from fiat money and towards crypto is that it will stop the war machine, that if individual citizens can choose to fund or not fund wars, we will have less wars. And I think weve generally mocked that argument or found it somewhat specious, and I think he makes a decent case here first that the break with the gold standard generally occurs during a war. Most people are on the gold standard up until theyre in the war, and then they print a bunch of money to fund the war."
## [1] " Yeah. He does explain it here. I have it right here. Lets hear it. This is about World War One. Within a few weeks of the war starting, all major belligerents has suspended gold convertibility, effectively going off the gold standard and putting their population on a fiat standard, wherein the money they used was government-issued paper that was not redeemable for gold. With a simple suspension of gold redeemability, governments war efforts were no longer limited to the money that they had in their own treasuries, but extended virtually to the entire wealth of the population. For as long as the government could print more money and have that money accepted by its citizens and foreigners, it could keep financing the war."
## [1] " Previously, under a monetary system where gold as money was in the hands of the people, government only has its own treasuries to sustain its war effort along with any taxation or bond issues to finance a war. So, that seems to be a clear argument saying that at some point, if you have a limited store of money or you have a limited amount of money, at some point, that money runs out, right?"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " At some point, you and I sitting here or you and I in our apartments are like, Okay, well give this, this, and this to the war. Well give our baby high chairs. Well give a certain ration of Cheerios. Well give a certain ration, well give up this appliance. Our dishwashers can go. But at some point-"
## [1] " Yeah, I think the war efforts really wants your SodaStream, Jay."
## [1] " Its a very loaded SodaStream thing. But at some point, youre just like, Actually, Im not gonna give you my SodaStream, and then people stop giving money to the war. And the government cant fund the war anymore because the public has said, No more, right?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " That cant happen when theres a deflation of currency. It can only happen when the government can print more money."
## [1] " This concepts always been a little confusing to me because it makes out like in a Bitcoin maximalist world that individual citizens are just going to vote constantly with their checkbook, that theyre just gonna say yay or nay to everything the government does. And I can tell you, Im the head of a small co-op."
## [1] " You are? Oh, yeah, thats right."
## [1] " Were sitting in it right now."
## [1] " Yeah, we are."
## [1] " Im the Keynesian manager here. Not everyones gonna agree on anything. We have to move forward as a group. And I think a direct democracy, whether its a war-torn Bitcoin wasteland or its Occupy Wall Street, I think theres a lot of problems with everyone having a vote on everything. And I dont really understand how this idea is gonna work in practice. I understand his counterargument, which is that inflationary currencies make it really easy to go to war. Im not sure I totally wrap my head around why a deflationary currency would stop war unless literally theres some sort of a system, and the only thing I can think of thats working this way now is Are you familiar at all with the Five Star Movement in Italy?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Google Five Star Movement. Im not encouraging people to get into it, but basically its a political party in Italy that has a central computer called Rousseau thats controlled by this one guy."
## [1] " Oh, God."
## [1] " They just started to control the Italian parliament. And Bitcoin is supposedly spiking this morning on the news of them forming this government because all the Italian bonds went way down. But basically its a form of direct democracy in which people in the party vote for who theyre gonna run and various other things using this computer. And most people think that the guy who controls the computer is secretly controlling the entire party, though he is not a politician himself. I think its a fascinating story."
## [1] " So, its like a Oz guy?"
## [1] " Kind of, yeah."
## [1] " Or is it like a guy who is like Milton from Office Space and hes like, Im just the custodian of the computer, but actually hes the guy who controls the whole thing?"
## [1] " Thats basically what it is. I think its actually the son of the guy who started the party. Hes a computer scientist that no one knows about. But Five Star Movement is not decentralized, leading to widespread suspicions of the person whos running it. Even if it was decentralized, its a little hard for me to imagine direct democracy stopping war. But I do find the idea of inflationary currencies perhaps encouraging wars to be a compelling one."
## [1] " Okay. Heres the way that I saw it breaking down, which is essentially that at some point, the government is gonna come in and take my SodaStream anyway. That would be the argument that somebody would say, being like, I cant just say no if they come in and take it."
## [1] " Well, if they come in and try and tax and you dont pay, eventually theyre gonna take your bank account and then your SodaStream"
## [1] " Yeah. Exactly."
## [1] " gonna repossess that SodaStream."
## [1] " And his argument would be those types of, that is actually much harder to implement on a population because theyre gonna resist that harder than theyre gonna resist some arbitrary inflationary currency tax increase if that makes sense."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " So, you can trick the populace into believing youre not jacking them to do this war for longer if you have a inflationary currency. If you have a gold standard currency and every single loss is felt immediately, then essentially the pain of taxation is gonna be much clearer to the public."
## [1] " Yeah, which I think starts to come in to the stuff that I want to talk about in the second part of this episode around time preference and how people are thinking about money over time. One of the things I thought was cool in this chapter was to read Part of the reason that these inflationary currencies are dangerous in a war situation is not just that you can print more money and inflate your currency. Your adversary can do the same. And it becomes something of a money-burning competition, like in the World War One case, where its like, Well, we have to inflate our currency to build a bigger war machine to fight their bigger war machine. And it can lead to a situation of mutually assured destruction."
## [1] " Sure. Thats his argument. He basically in this chapter says that every massive conflict from World War One on was the result of going off of the gold standard."
## [1] " Pretty much, yeah."
## [1] " And I found that to be difficult to swallow. Hes a good polemicist in that sort of way. Hes not doing half-baked takes here, right? Hes basically doing Skip Bayless of economics."
## [1] " There was a few takes I found a little undercooked with some raw meat."
## [1] " Like what?"
## [1] " Maybe Ill get to it when we pass that part. His writing about art is not the writing of someone who knows very much about art."
## [1] " Yeah, actually. I would agree with that. We can get there. But, look, if you look at all into this, theres a lot of people who would argue that this sort of Mises school, thats the Austrian school, thinking and the ways in which they construct these narratives, generally theyre built almost on conspiracy theories, that this is not how the war effort was funded. Theres a lot of pushback. I would encourage anyone who is part of our book club to look at that. I read a couple of them. And, look, the idea that essentially the governments made a conscious decision at that point to be like, Holy shit, now we can do it, thats always a bit troubling to me. But then again, have you read The Shock Doctrine?"
## [1] " I have not."
## [1] " The Naomi Klein book? Theres this part where it starts and its about Hurricane Katrina and that a lot of people who are pro-charter schools realize that this disaster was necessary for them to implement a massive regime change all at once and that they used Katrina to turn the entire New Orleans school system into charter schools basically. And Naomi Klein was much more thorough than Saifedean Ammous, and I tend to trust her history a little bit more."
## [1] " So, there are points where these sorts of things happen. The thing that I found less convincing about this is that the entire world collectively decided at once, Hey, now is the time to go off the gold standard, and lets do it so that we can fund these wars forever and destroy one another. Theres no real motive there. And certainly I think I find the motives for World War One that are more historically accepted to be a little bit more convincing."
## [1] " Yeah. I mean I like the book, so I dont want to shit on it, but he cites the example that its like come on, man, this is just as clich as the tulips thing about the soldiers crossing the lines and playing soccer on Christmas Eve, which is the one scene in every movie set during the war. And he uses that to extrapolate that the soldiers all really liked each other and there was no actual conflict between them, which is I dont know, bro. Theres a little more complexity. I mean even as an extreme amateur historian, I dont totally buy that ethnic tensions did not contribute to the first World War."
## [1] " Yeah. It is essentially, in a lot of ways, hes a pure market economist, right?"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " He believes that there is no input or output that you cant see within economic decisions made by the state. And his conclusion from this is that the state should make no economic decisions at all."
## [1] " The most interesting chart in this chapter I found was the chart of all of these European currencies against the Swiss franc in the 1910s. Basically everyone rest themself against the Swiss franc during the 1910s. So, I think hes right that the Swiss strategy there is probably better for your currency. Now, if youre a Jew in 1940s Europe, you might not appreciate the Swiss strategy of banking everyone and not giving a shit."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " I sort of agree with his standpoint that if you resist the urge to inflationary currency printing, your currency will probably perform well against the people who are printing all of that currency. I dont-"
## [1] " Yeah, to try and save their countries."
## [1] " I dont feel like everyone can do that at once."
## [1] " Nope."
## [1] " And that is something I do think about Bitcoin and crypto maximalism is its very different to put the world on a standard versus to put Switzerland on a standard. Its always made sense to have this banking enclave that serves war criminals and honorable people alike. Thats always made sense from a financial standpoint. But what would happen if all of Europe were to embrace a Swiss style government? I dont know."
## [1] " From war, he goes on to explain Keynesian economics, right?"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " Should we talk about that next?"
## [1] " Im gonna just out myself as a really ignorant person here and say many of the things he says are Keynesian economics I just took as generally-accepted economic though."
## [1] " Sure. But thats his argument, right-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " that now Keynesian, its almost like a Borges story where one idea takes over the world because of the symmetry that it provides and that because the world essentially collapses around the thrall of one idea. And that idea might be bad, and that thats what his argument is. So, he lays it out here, too. And thisll be a much shorter passage. But he says This is after Keynes comes out and makes his argument. And he goes to great pains to say that Keynes is not a real economist, and paints him as a charlatan, and hes-"
## [1] " He likes the personal attack on the economists he doesnt like."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. The Keynesian deluge from which the world has yet to recover had begun. Universities lost their independence and became part and parcel of the governments ruling apparatus. Academic and economics stopped being an intellectual discipline focused on understanding human choices under scarcity to improve their conditions. Instead, it became an arm of the government meant to direct policy makers towards the best policies for managing economic activities."
## [1] " So, he is essentially saying that what governments were waiting for was an ideology that would allow them to escape the tyranny of the gold standard that was actually a more direct democracy that allowed people to have some sort of personal freedom to do things like say, Hey, if you take my SodaStream, Im gonna have a gun here, and Im gonna shoot whoever comes through the door. Hes saying that essentially the entire world thinking changed because of this."
## [1] " Yeah. And he paints it as sort of a international conspiracy that not only were these ideas implemented, but a larger apparatus was to put in place to make people think that this was the only solution to economies."
## [1] " Okay, and throughout this entire period, right, Aaron, and this is something I wanted to ask you, which was he does not mention for many, many pages the words Bitcoin, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Did you draw the parallels through this part as to why these were arguments for Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Im glad you brought this up because one of the things that I was thinking while I was reading this was crypto people are always giving gold bugs shit on Twitter."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " No one argues more on Twitter than gold bugs and cryptomaniacs. And if you read this chapter, you would think that gold bugs and cryptomaniacs should get along with each other and be supporting each other. In many ways, hes basically just saying Bitcoin is 21st century gold. And hes advocating for going onto the Bitcoin Standard like we used to be on the gold standard. And part of me wondered why we even need Bitcoin so desperately if we could just Gold seems almost as good in this worldview."
## [1] " Yeah. I had the same thought. I was like-"
## [1] " Other than the portability issue. But it seems like now with all the Amazon one-day delivery, Send the gold over here. Send him two flakes. Two flakes for you."
## [1] " Yeah. I kind of felt the same way. I was like, Man, this is a great argument for gold. And I dont know if we need to adopt Bitcoin and all of its attendant problems at this point. Why not just go back on the gold standard if thats Every argument he is making in this book is an argument to go back onto the gold standard. And maybe we havent gotten to the point why we cant do that. But I dont understand how Bitcoin is just a perfect corollary to the gold standard."
## [1] " Well, one difference is that when we had the gold standard, gold was held in national reserves, and then we printed currency based on it. I dont think that the Bitcoin standard is advocating for the U.S. Government holding Bitcoin and then printing fiat currency backed by Bitcoin. I think that Bitcoin maximalism is hold your own keys. Everyones got their own money. So, those are pretty different outcomes. There was one sentence that really caught my eye here. Hes talking about the shift towards Keynesian thinking. It says, Central planning sought to achieve what the gold standard had achieved spontaneously. So, hes basically saying that the gold standard, everyone just spontaneously organized themselves into a efficient, frictionless economic system and that central planning has to do all this work."
## [1] " And it struck me that part of this libertarian world view isnt simply that we need to achieve a specific outcome, but that we need to do so through spontaneous human principles and organic growth, that part of the power of Bitcoin is that, for people who think this way, that people dont have to be told to do this, that people spontaneously choose to do so. And that was something I hadnt really thought of as a major part of the appeal of Bitcoin to people who maybe wouldve been into gold 100 years ago."
## [1] " You and I, just to lay a few things bare, were from very similar backgrounds in that we both grew up in ultra-liberal college towns, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Our politics probably reflect-"
## [1] " Youre Korean. Im Samoan."
## [1] " Yeah. Look, I try to be race-blind. Our show is now, we dont see color. We dont see race. Our politics generally reflect a lot of those backgrounds, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Did you find this This is pretty hard-right thinking. And its not hard-right socially, but it is certainly hard-right economically and is affiliated with people like Ron Paul,"
## [1] " Yeah, definitely the first person I heard advocating for a gold standard is Ron Paul."
## [1] " Yeah. And do you find this to be repelling at all in your interest in Bitcoin, this sort of laying out of Austrian school economics?"
## [1] " It didnt bother me at this point, but it bothered me later, so Ill say when it bothered me. But once it started bothering me, Im able to see I dont know enough about economics to be offended by some of these ideas. But I do know enough about art, and then when I see the way that he writes about art, it makes me go, Oh, what-"
## [1] " Okay, I cant wait to get to the art section."
## [1] "  were these economics dumb and simplistic as the way youre writing about art? Because I wouldnt know, I mean honestly. I know that you say we have similar politics, etc., but politics, particularly as they pertain to economic policies, is really not something that I have focused my life on."
## [1] " Sure. And I only started thinking about it because I was writing an article that never came out about Dread Pirate Roberts. And Dread Pirate Roberts, Ross Ulbricht, went to the Ludwig von Mises Academy for part of his education. So, he was very hardcore into this, and it actually makes sense that he was one of the early Bitcoiners, right-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " because of that. And I remember at the time thinking that, I dont like people telling me what to do in general, and I felt like this was probably-"
## [1] " Wait, you dont like people telling you what to do?"
## [1] " Yeah, I really dont."
## [1] " Is that how you ended up in a book club of two?"
## [1] " Yeah, in a basement with the president of the co-op of the building. But I did find parts of it appealing, but essentially in the end, all of the logic is essentially about accumulation and why accumulation is good and why we should incentive smart people to accumulate more. And, look, theres always a downside to this. We talked about this when we talked about Decentral and the Jaxx Liberty Coin or whatever, which is that essentially this guys vision for the world is that people who have the Jaxx Liberty Coin are gonna profit and live in this wonderful utopia of prepaid cards and weird stadiums in which they all sit and watch, whatever his vision was, and that everyone else who doesnt do it, then screw them."
## [1] " And I found a lot of that in Saifedeans book to this point that were at right now, which is that even he discusses the Stanford marshmallow test quite a bit, right?"
## [1] " The marshmallow thing, for people who havent read it, is, youve heard this story before, a bunch of kids are gathered together. Theyre told, You can have a treat now, or if you wait 15 minutes, Im gonna come back, and everyone who hasnt eaten their treat gets two treats."
## [1] " Yeah. And then they tracked all the kids, and they found that the kids who essentially said, all the kids who waited for the second treat generally had higher SAT scores, did better in life."
## [1] " Well, I think the three things he said were SAT score, body mass index, and drug addiction."
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Yes, they were."
## [1] " Oh, really?"
## [1] " I have the quote here. Hold on. Hold on, listeners. Those who could wait did better on the SAT, had lower body mass index, and lacked addiction to drugs. So, I brought this up because I personally, no one better illustrates the kid who eats the treat than me."
## [1] " Howd you do on the SAT?"
## [1] " Of those three things, only one of thems off. I did very well on the SAT. Ive not done well on low body mass index. I dont know which kind of drugs I mean I dont know if theyre counting weed in there."
## [1] " You host a weed podcast."
## [1] " I host a weed podcast. So, I guess maybe theyre right on some of these things."
## [1] " Well, okay, I did pretty well on the SAT. My body mass index fluctuates wildly. I-"
## [1] " Yeah, gamblings a drug, Jay."
## [1] " If gambling is a drug, then Im fucked. I think I wouldve taken that marshmallow immediately."
## [1] " Gambling is a hell of a drug."
## [1] " Yeah, it really is. So-"
## [1] " Also, Ive always heard that story as a cookie. Do you think marshmallow is the Lebanese variant on that experiment?"
## [1] " No, no, I think it was always a marshmallow."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " But you-"
## [1] " I feel like its gotta be a higher-value treat than a marshmallow, like, Oh, you got one marshmallow or two."
## [1] " Kids love marshmallows."
## [1] " Who cares? Thats not enough marshmallows. Now, if youre talking about a slice of cake-"
## [1] " You would go even further. You would not only eat the marshmallow immediately, but you would pound on the window again, like, I would like a slice of cake. So, you and I both scoring I think what he would say, Aaron, is that you and I as both people who would clearly have failed the Stanford marshmallow experiment. I dont think theres any doubt about this."
## [1] " Theres no passing or failing. Its to learn. I became an SAT instructor after eating the marshmallow."
## [1] " Really? Whod you instruct."
## [1] " Did some Princeton Review over there in the East Bay."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " Yeah. So, the whole marshmallow thing is actually a pretty good introduction to the idea of time preference, which is a big thing and why you might think that going to a Bitcoin standard or going off of the fiat world would be a good idea. Time preference is basically about whether youre a short- or a long-term thinker with regards to value, so-"
## [1] " You and I are short-term."
## [1] " Im actually kind of long I think, because I like to do-"
## [1] " No, no, no."
## [1] " No, no. I like to do, I make a podcast and it doesnt make any money for the first couple years, and then it starts making money because it builds up an audience."
## [1] " Yeah, you also sell the bottom and or-"
## [1] " In crypto?"
## [1] " Yeah, sell the bottom and buy the top-"
## [1] " In crypto-"
## [1] " all the time, and you have 20 shit coins."
## [1] " In crypto, Im extremely high time preference. In life, Im a little lower time preference. So, he gives the example of two people, and it takes a day to fish to get enough food. You can either just keep fishing to get your food, or you can build a fishing rod, which you lose some of your fishing time, but then you can fish more efficiently, which means that you have more extra time in your day. And now that youve built a fishing rod, you can build a boat. And eventually you build a boat fleet. And this also relates to how wealth passes across generations and how people regard money."
## [1] " And his overall point is if you think your money is gonna be valuable in the future, you will probably have a low time preference. If you think your money is gonna devalue fast, YOLO, high time preference. Spend that shit."
## [1] " Yeah, and-"
## [1] " Ball out."
## [1] " his argument then is that if you are the person who is taking two hours out of each fishing day to build a fishing rod to plan for the future, you cant be incentivized if you believe that the fish are gonna run out or that the entire world is not gonna exist. That is going to make you profit from your own enterprise."
## [1] " Yeah. Isnt this also kind of like a moralistic, idle hands are the devils work kind of argument?"
## [1] " Yeah, but thats why I was saying that hes judging us for being bad at the Stanford marshmallow test."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " All of this is moralizing basically saying that you and I as a-"
## [1] " I know Im bad at it."
## [1] " highly-impulsive people are idiots."
## [1] " I know that Im bad at it."
## [1] " Every page, I was like, This guy thinks Im an idiot."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " He looks at my five-team parlay that I just laid on baseball and is like, Man, that guy is really dumb. And Im like, Listen, I hit one of these six months ago."
## [1] " Well, it was interesting that this idea of time preference comes up in a book about crypto because under these ideas, crypto people should be the ultimate high time preferencers, right? Thats why you would want to buy a deflationary currency. But in practice, maybe not Bitcoin maximalists, but I havent exactly seen a lot of high time preference activity in crypto. Ive seen a lot of people chasing fast money, and I indict myself here, a lot of people starting in Bitcoin getting into alts thinking they could even get more Bitcoin more quickly, and generally turbocharging the whole thing."
## [1] " Yeah, but Saifedean, to be fair, half of his Twitter presence is hating those people."
## [1] " Thats true."
## [1] " And thats why he thinks that every coin, including Ethereum, is a shit coin and it should go away because it is deflecting from Bitcoins true, true vision of being the one deflationary world economy."
## [1] " I think that makes sense, and those two things align with each other. I do think it slightly undercuts what weve learned from human psychology in crypto to say, Its deflationary, so everyones just gonna hold on to it and save it and not spend it. I think what weve actually seen is that people are very interested in short-term profits and are also very willing to sell when the time is right."
## [1] " Yeah, I dont think thats a problem for him. I think he would say, Those people are all dumb, and theyre all hurting themselves. And what you should do is you should just buy a little bit of Bitcoin every single week or something like that so that you keep accumulating."
## [1] " Right. Yeah, hodling is high-time preference activity. Hodl forever is basically saying become a high-time preference wizard."
## [1] " And I actually, to play the other side, Aaron, Im actually much more sympathetic to him in these moments. I feel like if you believe in Bitcoin and you really think that it is going to change the world that the only thing you should ever do is accumulate Bitcoin, and that you shouldnt look it as a fast-track thing. You should look at it as real estate, like physical real estate for new world order. And I-"
## [1] " Wait, physical real estate?"
## [1] " What do you mean? It is essentially you are charting out part of, you are mapping out these keys occupy this percentage of the new world economy, and I am going to keep it forever, and Im only going to be increasing it bit by bit by bit, right? Its like hoarding gold, for example. Im glad that he goes full maximalist on this, and the examples that he gives I think are essentially right. I do think they are moralistic, but I think the moral that hes trying to say is that if youre into Bitcoin, be into Bitcoin. Be into it for these reasons because you believe these things. And dont be into it just because its a cool thing and you think its going to build a few cool apps and Ethereum is gonna build some DApps and its going to create some sort of new Google and you can be part of that new Google."
## [1] " Hes saying, No, actually, the entire world is fucked because of fiat currency, and it went out with the gold standard. We have an opportunity to reclaim the world economy. And you can do it by buying Bitcoin. That is actually a gospel that I dont agree with but I can identify as being a heartfelt and sincere gospel."
## [1] " If you live in a country thats functional and prosperous and the government does a good job of managing that economy, I think youd probably want to stay there. If youre in Sweden right now, I would not try and overthrow the government if youre living in Sweden right now. Pretty chill over there. If youre living in Venezuela, you may feel more pull to the Austrian school. And your interest in replacing your wealth, moving your wealth from your local fiat to Bitcoin I think gets higher and higher depending on how shitty the government of where you live is."
## [1] " I agree, but I think Saifedean would argue that those of us who dont feel like were in Venezuela have wool over our eyes, and were all in Venezuela because any place that has government-controlled currency is a totalitarian state to him."
## [1] " Yeah, and I mean I would ask the questions, how much does your government suck, and how much future sucking do you expect? Based on that basic premise, Im not surprised that a crypto bull run occurred in the first year of the Trump presidency. For me, I get closer and closer to this thinking the more I think Americas fucked no matter what, regardless of what school of economics Im in."
## [1] " Yeah. Thats where you and I are aligned. Were aligned on almost nothing in terms of buying crypto and the value of crypto, but were completely aligned in that we are only interested in crypto because we fear the apocalypse, right? Look, the fact that Bitcoin reliably, like you said this morning even, the fact that Bitcoin prices in specific countries that are under severe economic or political duress, the fact that it spikes every single time when that happens, that is something. And that is something that people should think about. And even if you hate Bitcoin, you actually have to, you should acknowledge at least that there is a correlative effect at this point."
## [1] " And he writes that, We, and I think hes talking about me and you, are the first generation in the Western world since the demise of the Roman Empire to come into the world with less capital than their parents. This is a profound idea. People have basically been assuming that each generation has a better life and more capital and is able to do more things than their parents did. And even if that retracts one time out of 50 generations, that could shatter the entire world. I dont think its just Trump. I mean crypto predates Trump. But I think the general feeling that the world is spinning into chaos is a bullish sign for Bitcoin. And I also think its always felt like the world is spinning into chaos, which maybe makes this kind of a historical development seductive."
## [1] " And then he started writing about art, and then I was like, I dont know. Now, were really-"
## [1] " Okay. Lets hear your I want to hear your art take."
## [1] " So, he starts writing about, hes basically saying that, Wealthy patrons would want to commission artwork, like say the Sistine Chapel, because it would outlive them. In the same way capital outlives you, these artistic expressions and that the artists who made them were master craftsmen who knew that their work had to stand test of time. Similarly, the musical works of Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, and the composers of the Renaissance, Classical, and Romantic eras put to shame todays animalistic noises recorded in batches of a few minutes, churned out by the ton by studios profiting from selling to man the titillation of his basest instincts."
## [1] " First of all, Jay, would you like to line-edit that sentence a little bit with me?"
## [1] " No, I dont. No. No, thank you. I pass."
## [1] " Titillations."
## [1] " Is there an assistant editor that I can pass this on to?"
## [1] " What word would you replace titillations with?"
## [1] " I think that I would circle the whole thing, and I would say, I think we could go without this paragraph about art."
## [1] " Whereas the music of the Golden Era spoke to mans soul and awakened him to think of higher callings than the mundane grind of daily life, todays musical noises speak to mans most based animalistic instincts, distracting him from the realities of life by inviting him to indulge in immediate sensory pleasures with no concern for long-term consequences or anything more profound. I feel like he was talking about meth, not music here."
## [1] " Yeah. Or I think that this is all just boy bands and pop music is terrible."
## [1] " This strikes me as the writings of a person who has a free Pandora account."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Common, man. First of all-"
## [1] " Okay, look, its ahistorical, first of all, right?"
## [1] " This is exactly how people wrote about art during the Renaissance. They were like, This is some barbaric animal shit."
## [1] " Exactly. And its also thoroughly ahistorical. Mozart The Magic Flute is written as a low-brow comedy that was playing because he needed money. A lot of Mozarts operas are vulgar things that were played in basically beer halls because he needed money. Dostoyevsky wrote books because he was in gambling debt. A lot of the books were about a character in gambling debt. They are not very good books. They are things that were created exactly for the reasons that he said. The idea that these artists back then were somehow sitting around and touched by God because they knew that they had to outlive their own lives, its insanely ahistorical."
## [1] " Every time someone makes this type of argument, I go crazy because it essentially takes the artist out of his context and makes him into a pulsing brain that is only existing to create the great art that you consider great right now. Its not true. These people are people just like anybody else is people. You put out a bad album from time to time. Some of your albums are good."
## [1] " People have been trying to make great transcendent art since people have been able to draw in caves. I know musicians. They are not being titillated by the base instincts. Its also funny to be like, Its all of these studios and labels just churning it out. Dude, you know that theres no money No one is churning out music for the dough."
## [1] " That shits gone. Yeah."
## [1] " But even his example of the Renaissance Im reading right now this book about Caravaggio. What all these patrons were doing-"
## [1] " Are you in a Caravaggio book club?"
## [1] " A Caravaggio book club of one. All these quote/unquote patrons who were seeking higher whatever, these guys were all just gambling speculators. They were commissioning art, pumping it, being like, Caravaggio is the shit. In a couple years, you wont be able to get one of these Caravaggios for under 1,000 scudi. The money that they used then is called the scudi, or the scudi."
## [1] " This is the most esoteric-"
## [1] " And theyre like horse trading the shit out of these paintings with each other, in a particularly Bitcoinian twist, because paying someone a bunch of money whos your cardinal would be considered sinful. But getting some political concessions and giving him a religious painting that might or might not be worth a ton of money, totally acceptable. These were people who wanted to pass generational wealth on, not people who were seeking transcendent, Godly art."
## [1] " Yeah. Its just like the art market now. It was money laundering."
## [1] " Yeah. Art is the greatest If you want to understand Bitcoin, study art history. Its all been a giant pump-and-dump scheme."
## [1] " So, is that what Saifedean was trying to do in this part?"
## [1] " No. He was trying to say that people used to have these higher time preference ideas of art that art used to be based on higher time preference. And now, its just peoples base instinct. And then he gets on to modern art."
## [1] " And hes talking about the Ying Yang Twins Whisper Song here."
## [1] " Here, Im gonna read a little bit of his takes on modern art. A stroll through a modern art gallery shows artistic works whose production requires no more effort or talent than can be mustered by a bored six-year-old. Modern artists have replaced craft and long hours of practice with pretentiousness, shock value, indignation, and existential angst as ways to cow audiences into appreciating the art and often added some pretense of political ideals usually of the puerile Marxist variety to pretend play profundity."
## [1] " Im with him fully through this. I agree with almost everything he just said."
## [1] " Okay, a couple things. If youre gonna shit on modernism and postmodernism, which Kang will join you for-"
## [1] " No, no, no, no, no."
## [1] " you should at least note that all of these artistic movements that youre shitting on are caused by the same technological shifts that youre writing about with regard to the gold standard. Why did art become consumerist? Because America is consumerist. These things arent happening in a vacuum. People arent like, Ive got a great get-rich-quick scheme, abstract art."
## [1] " Look, he and many other people right now, theyre traditionalists. And every argument that hes making is a traditionalist argument. And for economics, he wants to go back to essentially the 1910s or 1890s. And for art, he wants to go back I guess to the 1550s or something like that. It is all this nostalgic-"
## [1] " Yeah, 1500-ish."
## [1] " Its all this nostalgic looking back at great times. Its the same thing that these Identity Evropa guys do about Western civilization by looking at statues and they say, We need to restore the glory of Western civilization. It is a very hazy ahistorical looking back at it. This is all a pretense of we are doing this book club. But I found that all to be predictable and boring in the same way that I find the Identity Evropa arguments to be about Western civilization to be predictable and boring."
## [1] " I feel like he is bending the truth to fit into this neat bucket that hes built. And I didnt notice when he was talking about economics. I dont know jack shit about economics. I know a little bit about art history. And the part about art history is so patently wrong that its even wrong if you have the most conservative world view. Youre just simply wrong about how art works."
## [1] " Thats what I mean. Its ahistorical. Hes saying things that were not true about art at the time."
## [1] " Hes talking about basically the National Endowment for Arts and the way that in a planned economy, the government commissions art. And he says, When government is in charge of deciding winners and losers, the sort of people who have nothing better to do with their life than work as government bureaucrats are the arbiters of taste and beauty. Instead of art success being determined by the people who have succeeded in attaining wealth through several generations of intelligence and low time preference, it is instead determined by the people with the opportunism to rise in the political and bureaucratic system best."
## [1] " That is a bonkers thing to say. For starters, intelligence is not carried across generations. Anyone who went to a fancy private school can tell you about how much intelligence is passed along with wealth across generations. Furthermore, very little of the art America is funded by the government, like a preposterously small amount of the art. And none of the taste in art in America is decided by the government."
## [1] " No, its funded by the not-smart kids at the private school."
## [1] " Its funded by all the people who are profiteering across generations from collecting art."
## [1] " Yeah. It is literally that kid who youre like, Wow, that kid is a Rockefeller. That kid is a Vanderbilt, and hes at school. And then youre like, Wow, that kid is an idiot. And then they become an art history major. And then theyre running the familys art trust at the age of 28. And those are the people who fund art."
## [1] " The only market for art is people who inherited wealth, inherited wealth or attained wealth through the management of other peoples money who inherited wealth. Those are the two people who buy a million-dollar-plus art."
## [1] " And now Bitcoin rich people who buy blockchain art."
## [1] " And crypto kitties."
## [1] " I find these, and this is the resistance that I felt when I read Mises in the first place and when I read parts of this book, which is essentially that again it is a socially Darwinist thinking that says that if you decide in one generation that I am just gonna stop fishing with my hands and Im gonna build a rod, five generations later, that sort of inequality that is built up is okay, that it in fact is better and it is moral because five generations ago my great-great-great-grandfather decided that hes gonna spend two hours of his day making a fishing rod and your great-great-great-grandfather fished with his hands because he was stupid. And therefore, actually I am the more intelligent, moral, and bright one. And you deserve your suffering."
## [1] " That is the undercurrent of this. I dont understand how anyone could argue that is not undercurrent of that. And I think if we had Saifedean here, or any Mises thinker, they would say, Yes, I agree with that. And that is a very difficult thing for us cucked SJWs from liberal college towns to get our heads around. But I think that is what the Bitcoin argument is, and it should always be identified as such because it is a difficult argument. But if you buy into it, then youre buying into it."
## [1] " That isnt my primary objection, though I understand your point and I agree with you. I think Im too dumb to even get quite that far. I just want a cogent argument for the Austrian school of economics. And its troublesome for me when the one time it passes something I know about, just some fucking half-ass bullshit where youre like, Rap music sucks. Bitcoin maximalism."
## [1] " Yeah. That was basically it. It was, Rap sucks. Mozart good."
## [1] " SoundCloud rap is why you should not manage your economy."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah. I would say that recognizing a couple more things than you do that that sort of thinking is endemic in a lot of it. And yet, I will say he makes a compelling point. You and I are very pro-takes here, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And we dont take shame. And it is a take."
## [1] " Well, I want to bring this up with you because this idea of politics comes up a lot, and you referred to us as SJWcucks. If my own personal politics are gonna disqualify me from believing in crypto, then I probably, A, shouldnt buy crypto, and I shouldnt do this show. Im generally a more curious, dont-really-give-a-shit person. So, that political disconnect doesnt totally exclude me from it. But Im interested in what you think about it. So, if you hold the viewpoints that you just described about generational wealth, and you think the world is going to hell in a handbasket, theres how the world should be, which I guess is the SJW world-"
## [1] " Well, just an egalitarian world."
## [1] " but what happens if you think, Hey, I want an egalitarian world, but I think the world is actually headed for even less egalitarianess and possibly tribal savagery and warfare to gain control of the Xapo bunker? What are you supposed to do then? Because sometimes I think the world I want and the world thats coming are almost polar opposites of each other. And part of my interest in crypto is hedging myself against this terrible world that I do believe may come."
## [1] " Do you feel then that you should morally divest then? Do you feel like youre helping crypto by doing this podcast, or even holding Bitcoin then? Because the divestment protest that happened in the 80s and 90s across the United States, across the world, about Apartheid South Africa and companies investing in them, specifically universities in the United States having part of their endowment invested in South Africa, they would argue that you should then divest from Bitcoin."
## [1] " I dont feel that way. And this comes back to what we talked about earlier in terms of does your government suck? We can argue about whether our government sucks or not. Our government is definitely better than the government in Venezuela. So, I dont see crypto as a universal good or bad. It kind of depends what your passport says and where youre living right now. And I certainly wouldnt want to deny people in Venezuela the right to crypto because I think it might also undermine America."
## [1] " Yeah, but you dont live in Venezuela."
## [1] " Well, no, but crypto is an international system where if I declare crypto Apartheid and try to fight it, I hurt people who are mining in Venezuela."
## [1] " Okay. Follow-up question, less serious. We agree that Ethereum World is stupid."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Okay. Do we as-"
## [1] " Im not even gonna go that far. I dont understand it well enough to call it stupid."
## [1] " Okay. Aaron is hedging. He definitely thinks its stupid, as do I."
## [1] " Jay, if you were in an ERC20 casino, would you be shit-talking Ethereum World right now?"
## [1] " Do you think that we should divest from something that we find to be so stupid and whose vision of the world is so bad that I think that you and I would maybe move to Venezuela instead of living in Ethereum World?"
## [1] " I am cool with Ethereum World. I would draw the line at Bitcoin Cash World. If Roger Ver-"
## [1] " Oh, come on. Thats the cop out."
## [1] " gets any political power, then Ill leave the country."
## [1] " Okay. I have one more thing I want to talk about."
## [1] " Yeah, and I have one more thing I want to talk about, too."
## [1] " Okay. All right. While reading about this, I found a fascinating example as to why Austrian, and it was a huge debate in economics, it was one started by Paul Krugman, or was at least pushed forward by Paul Krugman, and it is a debate between the modern way in which the American economy works and Austrian school economics. And it revolved around, interestingly enough, a babysitting co-op."
## [1] " I know about this babysitting co-op."
## [1] " You do? Okay. So, the Capitol Hill Babysitting Co-op, it was in D.C., and it was basically You and I actually we both have kids. So, I would babysit your kid, and I would give you a thing called scrip. It was their currency. And I have 20 scrip, you have 20 scrip when we both start. So, the idea was if I babysit your kid for an hour, I give you a scrip, and then you give the scrip back to me if you babysit my kid for an hour."
## [1] " Its supposed to be an open market for babysitting scrip."
## [1] " And the problem is that everyone got 20 at the beginning. So, it is a lot like Bitcoin in that there is a extremely set number."
## [1] " Well, its even, its almost pre-mined."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah. Its like a ERC20 token. So, they had a certain type of conversion for it. I think it was that each scrip was about a half hour or so. And the thing that happened, the second that they released this is that parents decided that they should save their scrip and that they should be like, Okay, Im only gonna babysit so I can save this up for a rainy day when I need to leave for a long period of time. Im not doing anything right now. And so, I might as well not actually go out to this movie. I should take care of another kids who wants to go to the movie so I can cash it into them later. And they instantly had a depression-"
## [1] " This reminds-"
## [1] " and that there was no demand."
## [1] " This reminds me of through a series of miscommunications in which the AMC Movie Theater chain tried to quadruple charge me for a ticket to an IMAX movie. They gave me 10 free IMAX passes. They were on paper."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " Theyre in my wallet. Now, an IMAX pass could get you into a regular movie or an IMAX movie. And I was like, Fuck this. Im not gonna use this for a regular movie. Thats terrible value. So, I just let them sit, festering in my wallet for years and years until they deteriorated and never used them because I didnt want to use them for lower value on that. This feels to me like people think that theyre gonna be desperate and need babysitting and they are like, Well, I want to hoard my babysitting until then. And no one goes off and just casually spends their scrip because theyre like, How am I ever gonna get it back? Because theres no liquidity in the babysitting market."
## [1] " They were all hoarding. So, it was like the beginning of Bitcoin, for example, and they were like, I am not buying that Bitcoin pizza because this thing, at some point Im gonna need this Bitcoin. So, Im just gonna hoard it. So, there was no liquidity at all in this market. And then they changed the rules, and then they began allowing, when you would come in, you would have 30 scrip. So, they completely screwed up the entire economy. And essentially they went through fluctuations of wild recessions, and every type of economic problem that went wrong, went wrong."
## [1] " So, Krugman brings this up and he says, According to Krugman, this is from the Wikipedia page, the key problem is that the scrips value is fixed. Couples know that each scrip they save in the winter can be redeemed in the same amount of time in the summer, giving them incentive to save because psychologically speaking, each scrips value is worth more to them in the summer than in the winter. Instead, if the co-op modified the system so that the scrip is redeemable for less time in the upcoming summer than in the winter, there would be less incentive to save because members would get less bang for their buck, in quotes, this is a Wikipedia author, if they chose to hold on to the scrip until the summer."
## [1] " In other words, Krugman is suggesting that the co-op shouldve had an inflationary monetary policy, that the value of each scrip would change. The most common criticism of Krugmans interpretation was given by Austrian economics is that the problem is the fixed price of babysitting, not of the scrip, alleging that the correct solution is to let couples decide how much they charge for babysitting on their own. When there is high demand or low supply of babysitters, couples would be more willing to babysit if they were given more scrip for their services. So, essentially surge-charging on an individual basis, where every single person is Uber."
## [1] " I found this to be totally fascinating, and I found that it really crystallized the difference between inflationary currency and the Austrian idea to me perfectly."
## [1] " Im kind of with them that its like, Hey, Im a super-sitter here. I get 2X on my babysitting."
## [1] " So, you do some co-op stuff, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Would you be try and become a scrip baron, or would you try and make the system work by actually participating in the economy that it was intended to do?"
## [1] " I used to get criticized when I was a kid because wed get Dungeness crab in the Bay Area. And what I would do is Id get the whole crab and Id crack it. I dont know why. This is, it goes against my marshmallow thing. I like to get all of the meat-"
## [1] " Youre a complicated man."
## [1] " out of the crab first and then eat it, which would mean I was hoarding a lot of the available crab by not eating while people were eating. And then at the end of the meal, Id have a huge pile of crab,"
## [1] " Right, but you all had the same amount of crab."
## [1] " No, no, no, no. The crabs in a bowl. You can take as much as you want. Its as fast as you can shuck."
## [1] " So, you would shuck them, and you would-"
## [1] " I would shuck before Id eat."
## [1] " cut out the eating time."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Youre a dick."
## [1] " Oh, yeah."
## [1] " You are a dick."
## [1] " It wasnt intentional. Its just how I eat a crab."
## [1] " Youre a dick."
## [1] " Just came naturally to me."
## [1] " Now, I totally understand your interest in Bitcoin."
## [1] " Another great example for people listening that have some of these economic ideas in place, theres an article I think the guy is named I want to say R.A. Radford or something. He was in a POW camp in the final months of World War Two. And he was a trained economist, and he wrote about the cigarette economy in the POW camp, which is many of the same things where people start hoarding cigarettes, and all these people who smoke cigarettes are like, Oh, no, cigarettes are too expensive for me to smoke now! And then a guy came around with a cigarette rolling machine. He just started rolling cigarettes out."
## [1] " He was the guy who dumped the wampum [inaudible 01:00:12]-"
## [1] " Yeah, he dumped wampum hard. Its fascinating how, if its that hard to manage a babysitting collective, think about how hard it is to manage a national economy."
## [1] " But Saifedean in his book, he does bring this up, not in terms of this example, but he essentially talks about how there was a copper mine crash after an earthquake in Chile, and that essentially what happened was that the price went way up because access to the copper mines was cut down. So, at some point-"
## [1] " International copper production went down."
## [1] " Yeah, it went up 6% or something like that. And that if you are in lets say Iceland, you dont really need to know that Chile had a earthquake and that copper supply was cut down. You just start adjusting things because the price of copper went up. And eventually itll normalize, right?"
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " So, thats what theyre arguing will happen in the babysitter co-op-"
## [1] " Markets will figure themselves out."
## [1] " which is that this market if individuals are allowed to be themselves will figure themselves out. The problem is that the babysitting co-op has an administrative thing that everyone had to basically pay scrip taxes into that would make arbitrary decisions like, Okay, now new members have 30 scrip because were trying to solve this, and that the entire thing got fucked because the administration had too much control over the actual economy and set all those rules."
## [1] " Well, even outside of the printing of more scrip, even if you take that element out of the story, theres an element to which that economy doesnt thrive because people dont want to be a dick, right? If youre like, Hey, Aaron, Id like to send my kid over to your house here, I got some scrip, and Im like, Ooh, Im gonna need three scrip to babysit your child, hes kind of difficult, that would create the perfect open marketplace. But I would have to interpersonally be like, My babysitting services are worth more than anyone elses."
## [1] " Yeah, but then I feel like even in an open system that there would be normalizing things that would happen. For example, if you were a massive dick and everyone knew that you were hoarding the scrip and that you were basically trying to price gouge all the other parents, we just wouldnt go to you, and that we would just create scrip or mine it ourselves."
## [1] " Well, this is like what happens-"
## [1] " You would be frozen out."
## [1] " This is what happens to me when I play Catan. Have we ever played Do you play Catan?"
## [1] " Yeah, but I hate that game."
## [1] " I love Catan."
## [1] " Its the most overrated game."
## [1] " People get really mad at me when were playing Catan because I will very rarely do a one-card-for-one-card trade. I want a two-for-one. And then eventually people all just get mad at me and wont trade with me. And it fucks up the game when you wont trade with someone. But this is how trade really works. Its not just a frictionless, decentralized Ethereum market."
## [1] " Are you good at Catan?"
## [1] " Im pretty decent."
## [1] " Okay, so does this theory, does this work for you?"
## [1] " Well, its a spoiler on everyone if [inaudible 01:02:57] stopped trading."
## [1] " Because if I was playing you, I would immediately start turning everyone against you."
## [1] " That is generally People turn against me quite naturally. My wife gets really mad at me."
## [1] " Your wife and I, who are friends, would before the game started freeze you out, and we would immediately socially pressure the other person playing to not trade with you. I dont know if thats a good theory. I mean I guess the social pressures I think do level this stuff out. Now, its harder to say that over the world economy than it is in a babysitting co-op where you can just say, Aaron, dont go to Aaron because hes a real dick about this scrip thing. Its a little bit harder, but I can understand why you would believe that over time that all this spreads out and it still normalizes."
## [1] " The last thing I want to talk about was hyperinflation, which is something he writes about. And he says that there was since the end of the first World War, shortly after the end of the gold standard, there has been 67 instances of hyperinflation as defined by prices rising more than 50% in one month. Now, you and I have never experienced hyperinflation."
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Nor do I think we ever will in this country."
## [1] " No. The closest thing I can think about is fantasy baseball players or something like that."
## [1] " Wow. Its incredible to me that you hate Catan but are willing to play fantasy baseball."
## [1] " Really bad at fantasy baseball, and Catan. You know what, Im basically bad at all games except Im pretty good at Scrabble. I think I could probably beat almost every single person that we know in Scrabble."
## [1] " Im pretty good at Scrabble, too. And we can settle that on a future podcast. Right now, in Venezuela, Venezuela is the most recent incarnation of the hyperinflation. And as I understand it, there is free electricity right now in Venezuela. They have a huge amount of power, so its not something theyre short on. And individuals are crypto mining, people have said almost everyone. I dont know what that actually means, but-"
## [1] " Yeah, I find that very hard to believe, for sure."
## [1] " lots of people are mining crypto as a way to meet their basic needs. And the government is also confiscating miners and is supposedly mining itself."
## [1] " And they released their own crypto, we should say, Petro Coin."
## [1] " Yes. They released their own crypto. And actually ironically, he writes about one of the guarantees of the value of fiat is that you can always pay your taxes in it. And that was the big selling point of Petro Coin was if nothing else, you can pay your Venezuelan taxes with Petro Coin."
## [1] " Well, thats how the government basically normalizes any sort of currency is that they say you have to pay your taxes in this."
## [1] " Yes. I think that will be when we see true crypto acceptance worldwide is when crypto is an accepted tax form, if it happened."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So, you and I have grown up and lived without the fear of hyperinflation, and were seeing already that Bitcoin is a powerful tool for individual citizens living in a society thats experiencing hyperinflation. Does it change your view on crypto at all that it can be such a powerful tool in the hands of people whose wealth is basically being erased in a month?"
## [1] " Well, let me answer it by answering the question that I asked you, which is whether or not I should divest from crypto."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " And I would say that-"
## [1] " I thought you did. We got a lot of different stories about."
## [1] " First of all, Im doing that because you -"
## [1] " Jays bag is just like a massive black hole. You peer into it, and you never see the bottom of it."
## [1] " Yeah. Its a quantum state."
## [1] " Its like in Interstellar when he is ifloating through time and he sees his daughters room. Thats whats inside Jays bag."
## [1] " Its whatever you think it is. Its actually pretty true. I actually dont know whats in my bag right now. That is actually the gospel truth. I have no idea. But I would say that should I divest from crypto because I feel like these sorts of economic policies and these sorts of politics are bad? And I would say that it is too early in crypto to know ultimately what its going to be and that there are many things that have started out with troubling political ideologies from its founders and from its great acolytes that went on to be very useful, and that crypto in itself I dont think, its hard to say that it is completely apolitical because obviously it has things baked in, like a deflationary currency maybe cant be apolitical. But it doesnt mean that it hast to take over the entire world, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " It doesnt mean that things cant be built on top of it that are useful, which is something that you and I talk about quite a bit. So, I would say that while I find some of these ideas troubling, I still think its worthwhile to at least be curious about it. And thats what you and I basically do here. We find this world fascinating. And were curious people, and so we like to talk about it."
## [1] " Yeah. I also draw a slight distinction between American politics and the whole world. I dont want what it means for American politics to mean that I cant embrace what it means for the world. And like a lot of issues, its gonna hurt some people, and its gonna help some people, and its going to rebuild the world in a different image in the same way that war did. After this period of money printing, we changed what a lot of the borders were. We changed who was governing what area. Its a shakeup no matter how you take it."
## [1] " I do think its important at least for me to balance my own skepticism around it in America with how powerful can it be worldwide because life is pretty good in America."
## [1] " Yeah, but you and I now have been doing this podcast during two inflationary crises-"
## [1] " At least two hyperinflation crises."
## [1] " one in Venezuela and the other one in Zimbabwe. Both places had massive spikes in the demand for Bitcoin. It is very difficult for us to be like, I believe in a egalitarian world, and I dont believe in Austrian school economics because I feel like its socially Darwinist, and then place those morals onto somebody in Zimbabwe whos just like, Hey, the system that existed sucks. And also all this money that I had is gone. And I need to do something else about it. In that way, I think if Bitcoin keeps evolving because of that, then I feel like it will become much more politically heterodox than what Saifedean Ammous is arguing because youll have a lot of different people making the decision to buy into crypto for very different reasons. And I think that actually is a good thing."
## [1] " And I actually think that if we asked him or when hes on here, we will ask him. I think that he would also argue that that is a good thing."
## [1] " I would say weve been paranoid about the idea that few of these billionaires who are putting money into the Xapo bunker that has 10% of the worlds Bitcoin will become the feudal lords of [crosstalk 01:09:49]-"
## [1] " I dont think that thats wrong, though."
## [1] " Well, I think thats a real fear, but I just want to put something on the other side of the scale, which is another group thats buying Bitcoin heavily are Venezuelans and Zimbabweans whose life savings are being erased, and theyre putting it into Bitcoin. So, there can be two routes at once. I mean I still have the problem that those feudal lords are buying 10,000 times more than the Zimbabweans and Venezuelans, but-"
## [1] " 10 million times more."
## [1] " 10 million but I guess I just think that there are multiple stories that are happening at once. And I hope on the show we can keep track of all the stories without just saying, Im in favor of this, or, Im against this."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, no. And, look, I dont think that our listeners would think that you and I are politically aligned in anything. Weve talked about the Zimbabwean crisis in half of our episodes because it is the one thing that you and I keep going back to by saying, In a geopolitical sense, this is the most interesting part about Bitcoin for us."
## [1] " I also think, as an American patriot"
## [1] " Are you? Berkeley, California, dammit. Youre gonna be like the alt-right guy who repudiates his liberal past and says, Im from Berkeley, California. I know how these libs think."
## [1] " I know a few of those guys. I do think, if you are an American patriot, theres this moment in history where the gold reserve, the U.S. Federal Reserve of gold becomes something of an international standard. And the U.S. can more or less print money, then go give that to people around the world in exchange for gold and hold all the gold in the U.S. Federal Reserve and have the fiat currency out there circulating around the world. And thats a power play. Thats a power play and a half. That may have been peak America when that was happening. I dont think this is a task for America, but its a task for some country."
## [1] " The first country that does go to a Bitcoin standard and a Bitcoin reserve and does issue money backed by Bitcoin I think will do very well. I think someone, I dont know, in Estonia, out there is just gonna go all in on this stuff."
## [1] " I think itll be Saint Kitts or something like that or one of these small island countries, tax-haven,"
## [1] " Well, we hear-"
## [1] " like the Marshall Islands."
## [1] " Its always people who want to do an ICO and issue money, which Im just like, fuck, I dont want your Saint Kitts ICO. However, if you want to put 100,000 Bitcoin in a bank and then issue some sort of money thats backed by the Bitcoin, Id be kind of interested in that."
## [1] " Yeah, I actually would buy that. I mean, yeah, I would buy that, especially if it was tokenized."
## [1] " Yeah. Its weird. Stable coins are generally trying to just be like peg the coin to the dollar. But when are we gonna get the stable coin thats pegged to Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Yeah. Fair."
## [1] " I guess Bitcoin is that, though."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Did I just create a logic loop thats now gonna fry my own brain?"
## [1] " No. I think what you did is actually too dumb. You said, Why isnt there a Bitcoin thats worth one Bitcoin? Okay. On that note-"
## [1] " We gotta stop. We gotta stop. Cut that out. We gotta stop."
## [1] " Please do not cut that out."
