## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Jay. In the Crypto Cave"
## [1] " We are in the Crypto Cave."
## [1] " I feel like we tapped that life hacker show and it was a whole different vibe in the sunlight."
## [1] " Yeah, I know. You were like on one. You had a checklist in your head of things that you had to shill. Sumokoin to the term coin world."
## [1] " Yes. Actually I have some Sumokoin related news. Some sad Sumokoin related news."
## [1] " What I really hope You know when you look at things on Twitter and you see that someone is trending and you assume that they are dead?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Okay, now it might seem a little bit grim to say, but every time you bring up Sumokoin and say, I have Sumokoin news. Or when you text me and say, We should talk about Sumokoin. My hope is that its dead so that we never have to talk about it."
## [1] " Ill say a few things. 1, Sumokoin is not nearly popular enough to get on Twitter trending if it dies. Even people we know who work professionally in coin world have gone a straight blank when Ive mentioned Sumokoin. People how have dedicated their lives to crypto currencies dont even know what Sumokoin is."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Should we just get it out of the way and burry Sumokoin?"
## [1] " Yes, is it dead?"
## [1] " I wouldnt say its like torn to a million pieces, but it is not presently trading."
## [1] " Oh really?"
## [1] " Oh yeah, its bad."
## [1] " They took it off the exchange?"
## [1] " Im going to put a huge disclaimer out there. None of this is investment advice. If youve already bought Sumo, youve already disobeyed that warning."
## [1] " I do like how this is not investment advice has been creeping up earlier, and earlier in our podcast."
## [1] " Well, someone emailed me and Max, my co-host on Longform podcast, saying that he had lost a bunch of money based on my Crypto Calls, and could he get a free Longform podcast T-shirt. So Im sorry-"
## [1] " The only investment advice weve ever given is to fade our picks. To do the opposite of what we-"
## [1] " Theres no short market for Sumokoins."
## [1] " Thats true."
## [1] " I guess to short Sumokoin, you would just delete your Cryptopia account and stay as far away from Micro cap Coin. I wanted to give people a little history of my involvement in Sumokoin. Me and you both got into Crypto around the same time. Maybe me a little bit before you. We started off buying on Coinbase, we eventually migrated to Bit tracks and some part of my curiosity just made me want to go as far down the spiral as I could."
## [1] " Thats a very generous way of saying it to yourself."
## [1] " Thank you."
## [1] " Youve been very kind to yourself there."
## [1] " Thank you. I got on Cryptopia, I was already a Monera fan, naturally I found the low cap Monera clone that was available on there, Sumo. Ive been showing it pretty aggressively on this show, I established my futile lordship over the Sumo lands by buying a big bag and I experienced my first moon shot with Sumo."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " You all remember that."
## [1] " Thats the actual relevant piece of information here, which is right after you bought it, it went up 10x."
## [1] " And I had a very significant opportunity to sell it at 9x, 8x, even be happy with a 5x stop loss, and because I had no idea what I was doing I rode it all the way up and I was like, Well, if its 10x now, wait until it gets to 100x. I saw big stars in my future. So I held onto it and I rode it all the way down, not quite to where I bought it, but to below a 2x. At that point someone kept trying to hack my Cryptopia account, and so I sold it just because I didnt want to get hacked and then I got into some deep FOMO. Remember when we did our alt season on the campus quad episode?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Like all the other alt sumo shows, the little life, and so I bought it at like spring high."
## [1] " What is spring high?"
## [1] " It wasnt the 10x high, but it was the high during the alt season fake out that happened."
## [1] " Oh yeah."
## [1] " Very bad decision. Very bad decision."
## [1] " Did it crash again?"
## [1] " Oh yeah."
## [1] " Just tell me what happened."
## [1] " Okay, so what happened was Im sorry, this story is going to take a second just because its very complicated. We had a quick mention of Sumo, that they were rebranding as Ryo Coin."
## [1] " Yeah, and we decided it was a terrible idea."
## [1] " A terrible idea, and should have been a red flag that there was something I took it as a positive sign. I was like, Oh. Well, theyre doing something. Its alive and so far someone has redone the logo. Once I get there, all Hell is breaking loose in the Sumokoin telegram channel."
## [1] " How many people are in the Sumokoin telegram channel?"
## [1] " I would say there is like 100 people, but there is like 2 people who are doing most of the talking."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " And other people are just yelling at them. Like, How do I get my coins off the exchange?"
## [1] " Oh, okay, so its like two people are represented as a Sumokoin."
## [1] " Kind of, but its harder to tell whats a real representative and whats a non real representative. All these peoples names are weird 90s AOL handles, to boot. The explanation that was being made in the telegram channel was they had discovered that the developers of Sumokoin were not real people and were puppets. All the accounts were being controlled, there was supposedly four Japanese people, which was actually one Vietnamese guy named, Vu Quang, I believe."
## [1] " At what point did they decide to rebrand?"
## [1] " Okay, so Im going to get to that. They brought in an outside developer, this guy Fire Ice UK, who I think has done some open source Monero stack work. And this guy was behind the rebrand, wanted 30% of the re mined coins in exchange for doing a bunch of work on the code. When he started working on the code he discovered, this is in his accounting, that the six hundred thousand coins for 2018 that were supposed to go to developers, had actually become one million coins, which is to say they were paying themselves"
## [1] " Was it an actual project? What is the project to take over? This whole thing is a scam?"
## [1] " Just a Monero clone. Its to keep working on this Monero clone."
## [1] " Are people sure that the Monero clone exists?"
## [1] " I mean, yeah it exists, its Sumokoin."
## [1] " And how do you have any faith that this is anything except a completely bullshit [inaudible 00:09:10] token?"
## [1] " Its on the RC22."
## [1] " No, but-"
## [1] " Oh I see."
## [1] " How do you know its anything? Its not just complete vaporware?"
## [1] " We dont."
## [1] " So why are people asking [crosstalk 00:09:19]."
## [1] " So people were asking that in the telegram channel. People were like, Is it over? Should I dump my coins? Sell them? People were like, This is the bottom. If we can recover from this, we can go to the moon. People would not accept it."
## [1] " And by people you mean you."
## [1] " Yeah, people were like, This could be a great buying opportunity, the revelation of this scam."
## [1] " Oh my God."
## [1] " So now there is two factions that both claim to be Ryo/Sumokoin. It would have been simpler if these two factions had just chosen one of them to be Sumokoin and one of them to be Ryo coin. Instead, they both claim to represent both Sumo and Ryo coin. It seems to me that a couple days after that trading stopped on Cryptopia and the price is frozen and the people on the telegram are saying that you cant actually send transfers anymore. Basically both factions are trying to get people to use their, Im going to mispronounce this word, Damon and Wallet and I dont understand exactly how that enforces a fork, but theyre both basically trying to create proprietary wallet systems which will define which one controls the project."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Jay seems very interested in this topic."
## [1] " No, okay, heres the question that I have for you. I dont understand in what world you did not assume that Sumokoin was a scam that did not have real developers. It was all this guy named Vu, who is pretending to be four Japanese people."
## [1] " Okay, so in my opinion looking back, Im not sure that Vu is a scammer, so much as really incompetent."
## [1] " Alright, he is pretending to be four Japanese people-"
## [1] " He had an explanation for that."
## [1] " To make a Sumokoin. He is not Japanese, in itself at the very least cultural appropriation."
## [1] " To be fair, at least one of these fake Japanese people is named Sumoji Tenaka."
## [1] " Yeah, but hes the one-"
## [1] " Which is totally the name in a video game of the Japanese-"
## [1] " Totally, its like Piston Hondos brother."
## [1] " Yeah, its like the power hitter on the Japanese baseball team in an NES game."
## [1] " World NES Baseball. Baseball Stars 2000."
## [1] " I didnt think that Sumoji Tenaka was a real person, and obviously I had not done enough research to see if there was any real people associated with I didnt even really think that a clone coin needed much development, since its just, more or less, tailing on the wind behind Monera."
## [1] " I dont understand how this is not a scam though."
## [1] " Its kind of a scam."
## [1] " Youre saying that Vu is not a scammer. I think that when you look at the-"
## [1] " It was a long play scam, is what Im saying."
## [1] " When you look at these coins on Cryptopia or these micro cap places Look, no judgment, I owned a lot of these coins, I never owned Sumo, but that was just because I felt like that was your thing and I wanted you to have your thing."
## [1] " Thank you."
## [1] " But, I just assume theyre all scams."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " What evidence has there been that theyre not all scams? I think that probably I even kind of thing Litecoin was a scam."
## [1] " That is what I was going to say. Is Sumokoin more a scam than Litecoin in your opinion? Theyre both clones of better known projects."
## [1] " Charlie Lee, as far as I could tell, never pretended to be four Japanese people."
## [1] " Thats true."
## [1] " So in that way he has a leg up. However, I would say-"
## [1] " Although ironically, Charlie Lee also sounds like a fake character who was supposed to represent a developer."
## [1] " Or a character from a fighting game from 1996. Charlie Lee."
## [1] " Charlie Lee."
## [1] " I can say it because-"
## [1] " Tiger Boom."
## [1] " Tiger Boom?"
## [1] " Its like an off brand, Mortal Kombat, Street Fighter 2 ripoff."
## [1] " Charlie Lee with his Tiger Boom. I will say that Litecoin does have some differences with Bitcoin, but not really that much to the point where it actually should matter in any sort of a way. So yeah, I think its less of a scam, but look, were talking about gradations of stuff."
## [1] " I think both of them are like, Hey, wouldnt it be cool if there was another thing that was just like this, but it was cheaper and we could use it for development or whatever? It seems like a lot of what makes it a scammer nod is the intention of the developer, so Ill agree with you that it seems like Charlie Lees intentions with Litecoin were more noble than Vu Quangs intentions with Sumokoin, but anyone who is cloning a coin is in some ways just creating a bunch of cloned money and trying to get other people to think its valuable, right?"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " And so I guess were saying if youre transparent about that, its cool, but its a scam if youre lying about it."
## [1] " If you pretend to be four people, its a scam."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Going onto to scams-"
## [1] " Wait, I have one more thing to say-"
## [1] " No, please, stop."
## [1] " I sold most of my bag, but I still have some."
## [1] " You still have some."
## [1] " So its not like this story is totally awful."
## [1] " You can put it next to [crosstalk 00:14:37]."
## [1] " If youve been listening to the show purely for my Sumo updates, dont unsubscribe. I still have my bag, hold onto your bag. Oh, one other thing is I did try to get them to make me the new leader of Sumokoins."
## [1] " What did they say?"
## [1] " I could not get any traction in the telegram room."
## [1] " Yeah, well I would have supported that."
## [1] " Do you think if I would have became the leader of Sumo it would spike immediately?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Based on my high profile?"
## [1] " No. I think some ripple of people, who you are now the king of, would maybe buy it. Alright, so moving on. Monster This is another scam I think. Do you remember Monster cables?"
## [1] " Im using some in this room."
## [1] " Okay, I always assume they were a scam because its the type of thing where you used to go to Best Buy and you would buy a new TV or DVD player or something like that and the guy would be like, Would you like the warranty? And youre like, No, I know thats a scam. And theyre like, Would you like some Monster cables and pay $115 for the blue and red things that connect your TV? I always just assumed it was a scam. Why would it actually matter what the build quality of those cables are? They cost like 15 times more than the regular cables that you get."
## [1] " To be fair, all of the cables at Best Buy are overpriced."
## [1] " Yeah, but not a $115 for a HDMI cord or something like that."
## [1] " Thats correct, thats correct."
## [1] " And so Monster I always thought was a scam, however, Monster in their spirit of You know much more about audio stuff than I do. Electronics."
## [1] " You know that Monster were the people who were originally the developers of the Beats headphones?"
## [1] " Yes, I do know that."
## [1] " So they already missed out on one moon shot."
## [1] " Yeah. Well they made enough money selling dumb cords with little gold tips to idiots at Best Buy, so I dont feel that bad for them. They are launching an ICO of three hundred million dollars."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I have read through some of the description of it and it seems to literally be a Disney bucks project in which you can buy Monster stuff with the Monster ICO."
## [1] " I almost dont know when we have to stop covering these things because theyre all so transparently pointless."
## [1] " That is my question out if it, right? Which is, essentially is there a point where the public is no longer snowed in by any of this? Is there a point where this stops working? Do you think that this is going to work at all? What do you think the CMO or the CEO of these companies is thinking when they are doing something that is as transparently stupid and pointless as this that is essentially a one time cash grab?"
## [1] " Well its not stupid if you get the three hundred million dollars."
## [1] " Something that is just a cash grab."
## [1] " Heres how I think of it. I think a lot of people dont really know where the ICO is going as a fundraising technique. There is probably some business consultants out there who are like, Look, you guys need to raise some money. This is how you would do it traditionally, you have to go do a dog and pony show at all these banks and family investment offices and the terms are going to be owneress and theyre going to want a board seat. I dont really know that much about this world."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Then theyre like, Or you can just issue some Disney bucks and get suckers to give it to you. Which one of those is preferable? If you can easily raise money, you just raise money. We saw this with telegrams, people just want to give you money, take the money. But if its going to be hard to get the money, and theres a bunch of people who would buy your token out there It reminds me a little bit of the era of Uber, where Uber came in and just started disobeying regulation, and then everyone behind them who was starting startups were like, Oh yeah, thats the growth hacker way. Just dont obey the rules. Start things that dont obey the rules."
## [1] " What would incentivize anyone to buy the Monster ICO?"
## [1] " Look, I bought Sumokoin."
## [1] " Yeah, but that was because things like Z Classic and other clone privacy coins were moon shoting, right?"
## [1] " Yeah, but look how well the telegram sale did. It just sold out to a bunch of rich people."
## [1] " But that was pretty adjacent to Crypto in general too."
## [1] " Im just saying named products have done well."
## [1] " But those are Crypto products. Monster headphones, or whatever it is now, are absolutely no connection to Cryptos. Its just a random electronics company."
## [1] " Yeah, its a stretch."
## [1] " Heres the other thing that I dont quite understand, which is, you know when you go to Target and youre in the aisle and theres all these cards and you have no idea what the cards are for so its like a $15 gift card to Applebees that you can buy?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " First of all, what the fuck is that?"
## [1] " Ive stared at those for a while too."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Its also like, some of those things you wouldnt give this as a gift, per se."
## [1] " $15 to Applebees? They stock it so obviously they feel like somebody might buy it at some point, but is that a money laundry technique? I have no idea who would buy some of these cards."
## [1] " Okay, so this brings up an interesting topic that Ive wanted to talk to you about on this show."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Have you ever checked out Purseio?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Okay, so for people who are listening, Purseio is basically this service where you want something on Amazon, you list that you want it and what percent discount youre willing to buy it at in Bitcoin, and then you send in Bitcoin, someone buys it with their Amazon credit and sells it to you at seventy-five, eighty cents on the dollar and youve paid in Bitcoin and theyve paid in Amazon, they pocket the Bitcoin. This is also not some dark website, this is like an IOS app that you can do this from."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Is there any explanation for why this exits other than money laundering?"
## [1] " I dont know. Somebody might have jacked a surplus of Amazon credit or something."
## [1] " How could you have that much Amazon credit? Also, its not like one person has all the Amazon credit, its like lots of people running lots of transactions."
## [1] " Of course thats money laundering."
## [1] " Yeah, its text book money laundering."
## [1] " People saying, Well the people want to consolidate Bitcoin. They could just buy Bitcoin with the money that they spend on Amazon credit. That makes no sense."
## [1] " Store credit has always been a potent money laundering tool."
## [1] " Is it used? Because I would understand it if theres a massive shortage of Bitcoin that you could buy, but there isnt. You know what I mean? You can buy it on Coinbase right now, if you want."
## [1] " Well what it is, is the stuff is not used, its new. Its shipped directly from Amazon to you. It works exactly like a normal Amazon transaction. There is not a shortage of Bitcoin, but there is a shortage of Bitcoin that is not attached to know your customer records. So if you do this transaction, and send the person Bitcoin, there is no record of that Bitcoin purchase."
## [1] " Oh, so its laundering."
## [1] " Its clean Bitcoin is what it is. And you can go buy Bitcoin for a buck over at Coinbase. This is like unanamo Bitcoin."
## [1] " Okay, so thats money laundering."
## [1] " Its interesting, its kine of cleaning the Bitcoin and coin scrambling it. Its like, Where did that Bitcoin came from? Well, it came from a swap for Amazon credit."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I think this is a fascinating world, and I wouldnt be surprised if there was some revelation that a quarter of the Bitcoin transactions going on were like weird money laundering swaps like this."
## [1] " Toilet paper headphones or Apple chargers or something like that."
## [1] " The best thing to do is on a big ticket item where you can get a huge discount, right? If you go and buy a computer for two grand, you can get like twenty percent off by paying in Bitcoin."
## [1] " You can do that?"
## [1] " Yeah, you can buy anything thats listed on Amazon."
## [1] " And its totally legal?"
## [1] " That I cannot comment on."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " It totally works. I can guarantee that people I know who have used it, have gotten the products."
## [1] " I actually remember Oh, my point was, I actually thank you for that diversion, because I did not know about that very well, but I had heard about it."
## [1] " Jay has just ordered some stuff on Purseio."
## [1] " My point was, and this is the last thing I want to say about these ICOs that these companies are doing, what is the difference between what theyre offering and the $15 Applebees card that you get at Target, that you dont get, but everyone has seen at Target and puzzled about being like, what the fuck is that? Theres no difference, right? Theyre just essentially offering a Disney buck."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I just dont get it. I dont understand how this is even a I dont understand, other than to dupe really stupid people, how this is a fundraising technique for these companies."
## [1] " So you dont get any ownership of the company? You just get free money?"
## [1] " Yeah, you get like money to buy Monster stuff."
## [1] " At a discount?"
## [1] " Unclear."
## [1] " Also, how much Monster stuff do you really need? Unless youre in the Crypto Cave, which is replete with one thousand cords. Yeah, Im very interested in the whole world of those prepaid cards and money cards, because I think thats, in many ways, the universe that Crypto is creeping out of."
## [1] " Yeah, not according to the Jacks Liberty vision."
## [1] " Yeah, or the hole theyre going to jump into, but clearly there is some use for these cards that hold value for specific store, because you see those everywhere now."
## [1] " I know, and I kind of get it for Amazon."
## [1] " Yeah, you give it to your grandson for Christmas, its Amazon."
## [1] " I swear to God they have it for stuff like Kmart and Walmart and Sears."
## [1] " Even those make sense. Starbucks makes sense. What I dont get is when you see the super specific one for a store that youd shop at once every ten years."
## [1] " Like Levis or something like that."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Which I think Ive seen that card too. And why do they sell them all at Target? Who is going to buy a Could you imagine getting a present and its like $150 Levis card? And youre just like, What am I going to do with this? Why didnt you just give me $150? It is a very bizarre thing. And you know what? Im convinced right now from us talking about it, that its all money laundering. I feel like the Applebees cards are money laundering cards."
## [1] " Im going to inject a new conspiracy into it, which is, do you know what green dot cards are?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Green dot is the one thats for sale thats just money-money. You can swipe it like a debit card. Instead of it being Kmart credit, its just like you pay fifty bucks and you get like forty-two bucks on a debit card."
## [1] " What?"
## [1] " Yeah, its crazy."
## [1] " Who would ever do that?"
## [1] " People who dont have, well like homeless people. People who dont have any-"
## [1] " For what? To buy airline tickets?"
## [1] " Yeah, to do things that you can only buy with a swipe able card. Green dot cards were really popular. Theyre also popular in prison."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Theyre traded and theyre literal stores of value."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " I think they got investigated and I dont know if green dot itself, but green dot S cards have all gotten shut down because theyre just obviously used for money laundering. So I wonder if the explosion in the Applebees cards is to replace some of the vacuum of the green dot style cards that you cant do anymore. Youre not really supposed to just issue a money card thats just anonymous, no know your customer, untraceable money. Visa does do those prepaid debit cards, but I think those are a link to your identity in some way."
## [1] " So when did green dot cards end?"
## [1] " I dont think theyre like totally over, theyve just gotten investigated a bunch of times and a bunch of them have gotten shut down. Heres a popular scam. I dont even have to surprise you with this one. You start up a greed dot style company, sell a bunch of cards, turn off the network, none of them are worth money anymore."
## [1] " Yeah, thats very efficient."
## [1] " Very Crypto, its a very Crypto move."
## [1] " Yeah. You dont have to set up four fake Japanese aliases at all there. You just shut it off."
## [1] " Yeah, it seems like a lot of the Crypto scam ideas are just updates on pre-Crypto scams."
## [1] " Oh yeah. Like weird gambling world scams."
## [1] " One of my favorite, Im sorry as long as were on [inaudible 00:27:32] credit, one of my favorite Longform journalism stories ever is the story about a bunch of Irish travelers, you know travelers. Theyre kind of the gypsies of Ireland but theyre not actually ethnically gypsies."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " They came to America and ran this scam that netted over a million dollars in Home Depot credit, where they would go to a Home Depot, buy up two hundred cheap sinks that almost looked exactly like really expensive sinks and they had a barcode printer. Then they would go to a Home Depot in another state, return them all with the fancy sink Barcode on them. So they would spend like ten thousand dollars, get back like two hundred thousand dollars in Home Depot credit, and then they would sell that to loca contractors like eighty cents on the dollar, because contractors will always buy Home Depot credit."
## [1] " Oh they were selling their Home Depot credit?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Wow."
## [1] " So they would turn cash into sinks, the sinks into way more Home Depot credit, and then trade that back for cash."
## [1] " How much money did they-"
## [1] " They netted over a million dollars in three months."
## [1] " Oh my God. Thats an amazing scam."
## [1] " They were caught by this one dogged Home Depot investigator."
## [1] " Fuck that guy."
## [1] " He was like, Ill take them down."
## [1] " Whoa. Thats a great scam."
## [1] " Its a great scam."
## [1] " Heres my other question; how were they not caught very easily? It seems like it would be very easy to catch them where youre just like, Okay, these guys bought this sink. These same guys brought these sinks back. Lets just trace them."
## [1] " Home Depot is another place that has no, know your customer policies. This is partially because contracting is a shady, non tax big world."
## [1] " Oh, so they just bought cash."
## [1] " They would go and buy them with cash in one state, return them for credit in another state. One of the big Home Depot things is that you can always return anything with a receipt. So, when the return would come in, no one would know where the sinks were from. And so there is no national network of Home Depots to be like, where did those sinks come from? Then theyd pop up three states over and pull the scam again."
## [1] " Oh, wow."
## [1] " Yeah, they were pretty good. They were all living out of a van together."
## [1] " The thing that Im more impressed with than these Irish roamers or whatever theyre called."
## [1] " Travelers."
## [1] " Travelers. Is how shady Home Depot is."
## [1] " This is what Im saying. Anything where youve got these cash credit economies Money laundering is worth 20 to 30% of the money. So wherever you can take money in and out of cash. Into Bitcoin, into Monero, any of those transforms are worth a 20, 30% premium, which is a lot of money in many of these cases."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Hey, speaking of a lot of money, do you remember when Kik did that ICO last year?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " So Kik, which is a messaging app, some might say its the poor cousin of Telegram, raised a hundred million dollars and in an ICO with their own token, which I believe is called, confusingly, Kin. I think Brady Dale actually talked about this."
## [1] " Yeah, we had no idea why Kik and Kin were different."
## [1] " Yeah, he talked about Kin for like two minutes, before me and you were like, Excuse me, what is the relationship between Kin and Kik?"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " The guy who is the head of Kik was at some kind of a conference this week and was basically negging the Blockchain. He was like, Yeah, I dont know if its really that useful for very much. He was like, Maybe for currencies, but doing anything else on the Blockchain seems like a huge pain in the ass."
## [1] " Fair, fair."
## [1] " I feel like thats maybe what happens when youve hit the open bar a little bit before you go onto the panel. But it doesnt bring up the question of how many of these people who are raising money for previously non Blockchain ventures, do-"
## [1] " You mean like Monster-"
## [1] " Yeah. Launching them, do all those people actually believe in the Blockchain."
## [1] " No, I dont think so."
## [1] " And working on the Blockchain?"
## [1] " Look, the theme of todays show seems to be scams and whether or not we can take these things in good faith or not and I would argue over and over again, that we should just assume bad faith."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " It is a huge cash opportunity. I dont think that all the people are like, Ha, ha, ha. Im going to cashout and Im going to end up in St. Kit. But I do think that they say, Well, this is legal right now and we do plan on being a huge company."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Is there a tiny bit of scamming to what were doing? Yes. But will the people eventually profit? Yes. I think that probably best case scenario for what people kind of think. I dont think that people go in with eyes completely blind and say, This is the best way to raise money and were doing this because we think the Blockchain is great. Its the future and we are Im not talking about coin projects. Im talking about existing companies that are ICO-ing. You do remember one of the first shows we did, we talked about Kodak Coin?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Yeah, what the fuck happened to Kodak Coin? Guess what happened? It was a scam. I dont know if it exists or does not exist, but even that at least had a use case, remember? Because it was going to be used to use the Blockchain to do photo rights, or something like that."
## [1] " Who fucking knows."
## [1] " I just cant imagine that any of these companies are doing this in complete good faith."
## [1] " Can I ask you a question? We talked about Sumo, we talked about Monster, we talked about Kik. None of them seem like theyre in good faith. Does all of this bad faith Crypto stuff make you believe in Bitcoin?"
## [1] " It has no effect."
## [1] " Okay. I think, ultimately for me, seeing all these people try all these other things makes me go, Wow, Bitcoin seems like a really good idea comparatively."
## [1] " Yeah, for me it has absolutely no effect. It seems like its a completely Its almost like something is happening with the same name, but is not the same things and is happening in another state or something like that."
## [1] " Apples to oranges."
## [1] " Huh?"
## [1] " Apples to oranges in your opinion?"
## [1] " Yeah, it feels like its similar things but the people who are invested in Bitcoin, they dont really care that Monster is doing some bullshit ICO, you know? Even the big money Wall Street investors, who are investing in Bitcoin and real Blockchain projects, if somebody is doing a bullshit thing its a little bit annoying, but I dont think that it changes anything. Its not like the people are interfacing with any of the real Bitcoin people at all."
## [1] " I was caught up in the Blockchain hype, and what a lot of people feel like theyre saying when they speak honestly, like this guy from Kik when hes like, I think Blockchain is a really effective way to issue a currency, and it may not be that useful for much else."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The fact that people are trying other things and keep coming back to currencies and Bitcoin is the leading currency, does seem to suggest that first time magic. The formula was hit upon. It wasnt just Blockchain. It was this whole system that Satoshi hit upon and no one has been able to come up with a better idea in the last ten years, even knowing what Satoshis idea was."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " He came up with that idea in a vacuum, and you cant get a better idea even by copying him."
## [1] " Yeah. That sounds kind of bad for Bitcoin."
## [1] " Okay, I see how you can read-"
## [1] " Theres been no innovation since this ray of doom [crosstalk 00:35:23]."
## [1] " Both directions."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Can we go back to making fun of ripple on this show?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Why do you have a sponsorship deal in the works?"
## [1] " No, but I do feel like its better to have Ripple people as listeners."
## [1] " I still want them to listen. We have to give them the good cop, bad cop."
## [1] " Okay, Ill be good cop."
## [1] " We rile them up and then we insult them, then we flatter them."
## [1] " Ill be good cop. Ask that question again."
## [1] " Jay, am I allowed to make fun of Ripple anymore?"
## [1] " Oh man, you know we better not."
## [1] " But Jay, its centralized."
## [1] " I understand that, but the Ripple people, they listen too. Its like Michael Jordan said, Republicans buy sneakers too."
## [1] " Is this country fried Jay? I dont even know what this voice is. Its like mid-western Ripple fan."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Alright, so weve given Ripple some shit. We decided when they gave us shit back and [inaudible 00:36:29] mentions, we should hear them out. We did a great interview with a Ripple fan."
## [1] " That was very Trumpian by the way. Great interview by me."
## [1] " Great questions, many people are saying it was great."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly."
## [1] " Jay didnt listen to it. Sad."
## [1] " I did listen to it. Very charming British guy."
## [1] " After we posted that, our mentions on Twitter are 100% about Ripple. Its just like Ripple people high fiving each other. Tipping each other. Oh, shouts to all the Ripple tips we got. We both are now holding a lot of Ripple."
## [1] " How much Ripple did you get?"
## [1] " I think we got like 20 or 30 Ripple."
## [1] " Really? So how much money is that?"
## [1] " Its not a collective pot either. Me and you each tipped it individually and I got more tips than you."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Im just saying, we dont pool tips and then split them at the end of the shift in Ripple. We each take our own Ripple tips. Were agreed on that, right?"
## [1] " No. No, no, no."
## [1] " Youre going to have to bet me to get this Ripple off of me."
## [1] " Okay, I dont care about the Ripple thing, go ahead."
## [1] " Alright, so I was shocked by what a unified body these Ripple people are. They like move as a group, they move as a tribe. Whether you think of it as a beautiful, friendly tribe, or an angry mob, they move in lock step and I think that probably has something to do with the fact that Ripple, XRP was put out by the company, Ripple. It has a more unified face. One if the things I like about Bitcoin, is you can kind of project whatever world view you have onto it. You could be a socialist whos into Bitcoin."
## [1] " I dont think you can."
## [1] " You cant?"
## [1] " No, I dont think you can."
## [1] " Why not?"
## [1] " Because the whole point of it is to destabilize [inaudible 00:38:17] currency and emergency spending so that you get cut down on things like entitlements and welfare, for example."
## [1] " Thats the safe amuse version of Bitcoin [crosstalk 00:38:30]."
## [1] " That also the white paper version of Bitcoin."
## [1] " Thats true. Its true."
## [1] " I dont know any socialist Bitcoiners, except for those dudes at the New Inquiry, or something like that, and they also think that Bitcoin is stupid, they just find it to be useful."
## [1] " Yeah, shouldnt those guys be standing for Monero really anyway? Thats what theyre mining."
## [1] " I dont even know if they are still mining Monero, but I think for a while they were. I also say, regarding the Ripple thing, I dont know if it necessary because its all centralization. This might be two sides of the same coin though. I think that part of it is because all of them buy into Ripple for the same exact reason. Its not that its like one company, its like one product, and its one ideology. It is literally, there is only one real reason to like Ripple, so if youre the type of person who likes coins for that reason, then youre going to like Ripple and then the people around you are going to be like minded and youre going to be like, Wow, its so pragmatic. You know?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I can imagine the world in which its in. All arguments you and I had and talks that we had and points that we chalked up for Ripple, I dont know, a year ago or something like that?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I think thats part of the reason why the move as a hive."
## [1] " One of the things that really fascinated me about my experience in Ripple land, was you made the analogy to MLS fans, Major League Soccer fans."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Which is, I would say, deeply insulting. And the Ripple people took it as a compliment."
## [1] " What?"
## [1] " Yeah, they were like, Its kind of right on. That is how we see ourselves. Most people are like, MLS is going to overtake the premier league in a decade? Yeah right. And its a long shot dream but someones got to believe in it in Seattle."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah."
## [1] " And I think thats how the Ripple fans see themselves. I think sports is a really good way to understand Tribalism and Crypto. I think people pick a team for whatever reason, these Ripple people pick it because of the way they feel about bank transfers, Bitcoin people feel a certain way about eating all meat or whatever. You pick your team, and you just have to dig in your heels and really fight for that team. Which is interesting to me, because this is not how people outside of Crypto think of Crypto. People think, Oh someone is into Crypto or not into Crypto. But within Crypto, it seems almost impossible not to have a strong, tribal, team based identity."
## [1] " Well what team are you on?"
## [1] " I was on team Sumo, but we just got relegated below the first division, so Im on team Monero really."
## [1] " You arent really in team Sumo, you were always on team Privacy Coin."
## [1] " Well, were like coin moderates, where we can stomach a little diversity of coin."
## [1] " Yeah, but even from the very beginning you were into Privacy Coins."
## [1] " I was, yes. Yeah."
## [1] " I would say that your interests mostly lay in Privacy coins."
## [1] " You can see the same thing in Ripple. A lot of people are Ripple. Theres some Stellar people in there, because Stellar is the original founder of Ripple, is a Stellar person. So its not like you cant have a second or a third coin, but you have this strong coin identity, and I think it must be really hard to shift those coin identities."
## [1] " Yeah, Im just trying to think about what my coin identity was. I dont know if I had one."
## [1] " As soon as theres, Fuck you guys, Im going home. Coin, you can like Your coin identity is exiting the market."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Your coin identity is Fiat currency."
## [1] " [crosstalk 00:42:14]."
## [1] " US dollars. I believe your coin identity is Amazon stock."
## [1] " Amazon stock? Thats true."
## [1] " I do think thats an interesting way to see this whole world. Remember when we were starting off, we were like, Well, what is the psychology of these new buyers going to be? Theyre going to go from Bitcoin to Ethereum and Litecoin and Coin Banks, theyll eventually go to Bittrack."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So what is the psychology of this tribal, sports fan based-"
## [1] " Yeah, you know, thats actually an interesting thing because we havent talked about that in a long time, and part of the reason is because you and I dont talk about the market anymore."
## [1] " We should."
## [1] " And we dont talk about buying and selling as much anymore, and I think that there is two reason for that. The first is that we got bored of talking about the market."
## [1] " Well, because we lost money."
## [1] " Yeah, but also because the market has been pretty flat."
## [1] " It was fun to talk about while it was going on."
## [1] " Yeah, and it was fun to talk about when it was crashing."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " But it is not fun to talk about when it is just totally flat and just kind of gets-"
## [1] " Well, theres no news. I have to start off every episode and be like, Jay, Bitcoin, still around seventy-five hundred this week."
## [1] " So the one thing that we do know is that there is a flood of people that came in, in November and December."
## [1] " Yeah, Thanksgiving babies."
## [1] " And they exhibit a pattern of behavior that was very easily trackable for anybody who is in Crypto for longer than them."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Some of those people are still around, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Some of those people are still interested in Crypto, and I feel like I have no idea what theyre doing. Are they just sitting on coins and waiting for the next bull run? Thats kind of what Im doing. I have a small amount of coin, and some Fiat and Im just waiting for things to shake out. Or have they sort of joined some of these tribes? Have they found, as they do research, as they get more and more into it think we can charitably say that a lot of these people are probably very smart, you know?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Do they find something that they believe in, and they just sort of become part of those next tribes?"
## [1] " One thing I have always wondered is, can you buy If you bought Ripple at three dollars, and really believed in it and now its at sixty cents, would you stay in that tribe?"
## [1] " No, but I dont think that the people are Ripple stands did that. Because the amount of time where Ripple was at three dollars was very short lived."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And the amount of time that it went from eight cents to twenty cents was very, very long lived, you know?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " You and I both could have bought Ripple at twenty fucking cents, you know? I think we both did buy Ripple at twenty cents."
## [1] " I think if we had bought Ripple at twenty cents, we would have still been wrecked to Bitcoin thought. Bitcoin has gone up more than Ripple in that space."
## [1] " It went up 10x?"
## [1] " No, Ripples at like sixty cents now dude."
## [1] " No, Im talking about the spike to three dollars."
## [1] " Oh yeah, if we had sold the [inaudible 00:45:12]."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Well you can see what my track record is on selling double digit multiples, high."
## [1] " I sold zero, I think I sold zero-"
## [1] " Even my fantasy scenarios I assume that I ride it all the way up and all the way down. Im just like, It would have been thrilling to break even after a wild rollercoaster."
## [1] " That is true. That actually did happen, where you could not conceive of a world in which you sold the top."
## [1] " I dont even think about selling tops anymore, but I do think that Crypto generations are real, and I think that first wavers are more fanatical and more tribe than second wavers, so I think Bitcoin has actually been moderated by its own popularity."
## [1] " Yeah, but now its on its 15th wave."
## [1] " Yeah, its like each wave the Bitcoin cash fork washed out a few crazies. A few people became ETH Maximalist when ETH came out and the people who are left over are being diluted by new people who are more reasonable than them, and less knowledgeable than them."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I guess what Im asking is, starting from that tribal standpoint, and moving towards a more moderate world view, where does that psychology lead you as an investor?"
## [1] " Im not really a Crypto investor."
## [1] " Well, Im not really a journalist, but we both pretend to be."
## [1] " Alright. I think that it makes me less excited about the market because I want a rationality, right? I want massive spikes, I want this market to behave in ways that the stock market does not. Otherwise, if its just about reasonable gains over time, there are a lot more stable things and a lot less shady things to invest in that have clear tax codes, and which dont require you to worry every single time that the whole things is gone."
## [1] " Is that a little bit the poker player in you also, where youre like, If people arent going to be betting crazy at this table-"
## [1] " Im out."
## [1] " Yeah, if everyone is going to be play pretty conservatively well, let me find another table."
## [1] " Yeah, because what is the point of investing in Crypto if its not spiking wildly or if there is no potential for it to spike wildly? Is it to use it? No, no one would argue that its to use it. Even Saifedean Ammous would be like, No you should get it at store value. But if there is no reason right now to buy it at store value, you might as well not buy it as store value, because you can assume that later on you might be able to buy more."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Thats sort of where I am right now with it, where I dont see a psychological reason why in the next few months it will spike. That doesnt mean I dont think it will ever spike, or it wont spike maybe even this year, but I just have a hard time trying to figure out whats going to cause it to jump. The fact that it is stable, the fact that it is behaving a lot more like a reasonable thing right now, does sort of bring more credence to the idea that a lot of the things that were happening with price spiking over the past six months, seven months, were due to mass market manipulation."
## [1] " Yeah, you really want that to be true."
## [1] " Yeah, the DOJ is investing-"
## [1] " You and the DOJ just wont let go of this idea. No, I think thats right. People have been like, Bitcoin wont have arrived until its stable for a long time. But I dont think that many people have actually thought through what a stable Bitcoin world is."
## [1] " I agree. Thats true. Theyre just saying some words there. They happen also to be right I think."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The reality is that stable Bitcoin means that were between six and eight thousand dollars for maybe like nine months."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Thats not a bad thing I dont think."
## [1] " One of the things that, I think Marty Bent tweeted this, about how as societies like Venezuela, economy crash, people convert their money into Bitcoin, the whole idea of central planning becomes pointless so people arent using your currency. You cant centrally plan Bitcoin. If enough people in those markets start pushing into them, and we have Zimbabwe, Venezuela, or whatever, there almost become a shadow world economy thats the linked economy of Venezuela, Zimbabwe and these places where people are holding a lot of their wealth in Bitcoin, and in that case, I think stability is better and in some ways I know weve been worried about this world where these futile overlords hold ten percent of the worlds wealth in a bunker. A stable Bitcoin and a flow from crashing currencies into Bitcoin is a different narrative outcome that could occur."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah, yeah. For sure. Maybe Peter Teal actually wants that to happen and maybe he doesnt consolidate because it just means if he doesnt steal all the Bitcoin then his Bitcoin is worth more."
## [1] " Well, the best hedge against Bitcoin tyranny, is to spread the Bitcoin out and have small individual investors invested in Bitcoin. So everyone do your part. By a little Bitcoin. That includes you, Jay."
## [1] " Yeah. I do have a I think youre right. At some point they have to understand that too much consolidation will lead to a drop in adoption."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " And there is an optimized place where they can be like extremely wealthy and still have the thing work."
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " And have a bunch of worthless Bitcoin."
## [1] " I mean, it doesnt really matter what the price of Bitcoin is if youre in Venezuela and youre trying to get out of the Bolivar, youre going to buy it. I still think no matter what the price of Bitcoin, these sort of economic shifts are there, but I think that not the first or second, but the fifteenth country that has hyper inflation and goes to Bitcoin, that starts to become the actual market for Bitcoin. I dont know how much of the world right now is that."
## [1] " Warrant, those two countries do a lot of business between one another."
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " And that this is an affinity point between two countries that might not have any sort of affinity point before. It opens a new pathway for new economy stuff."
## [1] " Yeah, it will be interesting to see if countries really go Bitcoin. Will they have Bitcoin trade agreements? You could see Central America going Bitcoin and then having open Bitcoin borders. Sort of in the same way that the Euro functioned."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " And the Euro is falling apart right now while this is happening. I think actually, if there is one thing that has been a positive story for Bitcoin this week, it was the collapse of the Italian bond market, in relation to the politics that are happening there. If truly the Euro were to split apart, the Euro is the closest to a utopian cross boarder currency that weve come up with."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Exciting times to live in."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So youre not buying though?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " What would make you buy?"
## [1] " I dont know."
## [1] " Really good news?"
## [1] " I think that Two things would make me buy. The first would be that if some sort of sustained upward motion and spike and interest in Bitcoin. If it dropped to three thousand I would insta buy."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I dont care what the news is. It could be like Someone could come out with an article that said that every single Bitcoin ever used was done for murder or drugs. And then I would think about it, but any reasonable amount of news that came out that dropped it to three thousand, I would just insta buy at three thousand."
## [1] " I think I know whats going to get you back into Bitcoin."
## [1] " What?"
## [1] " Pursio purchasing."
## [1] " Buy a bunch of dumb rugs and sound equipment, camera lenses."
## [1] " Yeah. Alright cool. Well back again next week."

## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] " Chris Dannen, here in the crypto cave."
## [1] " Welcome."
## [1] " The last time I saw you, you were an editor at Fast Company magazine."
## [1] " And you sent me an email that you had gotten into a little mining, among other crypto related pursuits. So how did you go from being a technology editor to jumping into the technology yourself?"
## [1] " Just to say, journalism is not a profitable endeavor if you can predict the future."
## [1] " If youve got the back to the future-"
## [1] " Almanac, dont just use it for journalistic purposes."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Its interesting, I hadnt really thought of this literally until you said it, but I think, without GitHub, I dont believe crypto could have happened."
## [1] " Certainly not alt coins, at least. At their core, alt coin projects are GitHub reposts."
## [1] " And I knew about open source software before hand, but the idea of people just merging in and out of a project in that way, I mean I guess you just need Git, but without the hub, what do you just like roll your own? You know? And for people listening, GitHub was acquired by Microsoft a few days ago now, huh?"
## [1] " I really think that GitHub is an interesting model for where crypto could be going. You have the Git protocol, which is open, it predates GitHub."
## [1] " And then GitHub comes alone, and makes it really easy to use Git, gets a lot of people on it, makes the central communication for Git-based projects GitHub. And this seems to me like its more or less where were going to end up with the Coinbases and Geminis of the world. Which is, weve created this open protocol in Bitcoin, and you can keep your private keys, and you can like print them on a piece of paper, and hide them in a secret Swiss vault, or you can pay someone to make it pretty easy for you, and maybe never even think about private keys. Do you think that we will see in the next iteration of these companies one of these coin custodian companies acquired by one of these tech giants?"
## [1] " Its funny, every time Xapo comes up on this show, we discuss a post apocalyptic Bitcoin movie situation. So you can imagine a bunch of people trying to cross Europe in a frozen tundra to get to Xapo to unlock the Bitcoin of the future. Youre someone who has studied companies where user experience is a big part of the offering. Do you think that a truly easy user experience can be built without that custodian later?"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " The difference to me there, would be, I think you could say the same thing about the graphic user interface as the car, which is, if you are just starting cold and I showed you OS 10, youd be like What? Click? Whats Clicking? To use a computer is to build on a lifetime of knowledge about how computers work. So the people who are coming to crypto now, they are used to services like Gmail and Uber, for these things to just work out of the gate."
## [1] " I was going to ask if you were referring to Decred."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " Okay, tell people who are listening, were on an airplane together, and Im like, What is Decred?"
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " And it also allows even non-technical team members to interact with the people who are creating the code."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " The thing that originally actually got me interested in Decred was, when I very first encountered crypto, I didnt even really know what most of these projects were. I was looking at it as basically a pure game. And I was like, its weird. Decred goes up when Bitcoin goes down. Almost nothing else was, I dont know if thats held true, because Im not currently holding Decred, so I dont see its movements as closely. But its very unusual in crypto markets, for something to move the opposite direction of Bitcoin."
## [1] " And a lot of people look at stuff like Decred as a hedge against Bitcoin. I also think of mining as a hedge against the volatility of Bitcoin. Its certainly more predictable than the price of Bitcoin next month. How did you originally get into mining?"
## [1] " When someone says they got into mining, like I get objectively why a fund would want to be in mining. Its maybe got less upside than pure coin speculation, but way less downside also. And as you described, its more predictable, you could explain to someone who is investing what theyre investing in. If I was going to use your money to buy Decred, Im not sure I could, I could kind of explain why I was doing it, but I was like, I dont what to expect? Do you? Mining is a bit more predictable. But how does a fund get into mining? Does that literally mean like buying racks of shelves and GPUS, does that get outsourced?"
## [1] " What do you mean by data center environment?"
## [1] " I remember my first exposure to crypto was going on craigslist, in the Bay area, this was probably also like circa 2012. And I always am able to judge a little bit where the state of Bitcoin is by how many rigs are for sale on craigslist. And you would always, I could do a great photo essay of where the rig is in the photo of someone who is selling a rig on craigslist. Its like usually next to a fish tank. Or you can see a bunch of dirty laundry behind it."
## [1] " For people listening, tell me what the difference is between an GPU and Asic miner is."
## [1] " Probably the biggest controversy around this recently has been Monero, which has changed its core code to make itself more resistant to a planned Asic miner."
## [1] " Actually not planned, they made it, right? It exists."
## [1] " Is that like a bargain basement sale now?"
## [1] " Can you mine anything, I guess you could mine some of the Monero clones that hadnt updated?"
## [1] " My beloved Sumo coin? RIP."
## [1] " Right, so some of the things you mine succeed, some of them never even reach Cryptopia, and you just write those off as totally valueless."
## [1] " Much like my Sumo coin investment."
## [1] " I mean, Sumo coin is actually a great example of the kind of thing, you would end up mining, under the circumstances you described. So youve already done the work of figuring out Monero, you kind of know how that works. Okay, theres some Monero clones. Lets just find the smallest one of these, and start mining it. Are you like looking at coin prices, Bitcoin Talk all the time, and adjusting on the fly what youre mining?"
## [1] " Is that a job, like mining strategist? Like what should we mine strategist?"
## [1] " Are they doing that kind of micro cap mining that I described in China, also? I always assumed most of those factories were just playing it pretty straight."
## [1] " Or just the mega-mines. I mean."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " How big was the first mining facility that you set up?"
## [1] " So thats not like toe dip material."
## [1] " Thats like set the block on fire material. Why the big jump, I mean, is it not worth it to, would the same thesis work with one miner, 10 miners, 100 miners, 1000 miners? Is there some level you need to be at, where the work evens out?"
## [1] " So do you have a strategy for how long you want to hold these coins after you mine them? Are you holding them for an extended period, or going pretty much straight to Bitcoin or Fiat?"
## [1] " Interesting."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " My assumption is generally, if the market goes up, I will make money. If the market goes down, I will lose money. Is your venture on fund set up so that, lets say, Im not saying this is going to happen listeners, but lets say on January 1st, 2019, Bitcoin is at $3,000 and you can project where all these alt coins are, if thats true. Is your fund set up to try to make money in a down market also?"
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " I mean, some of this stuff is a little terrifying to me, to be honest. When I think of the apocalyptic scenarios in which were like tunneling through frozen Europe to the Zappo bunker, a lot of them are basically like, I think some people are like, Oh its scary that Bitcoin would not work. And to me, the scary idea is that it does work. And these miners would be sitting on a political economic power that the world has never foreseen. Im extrapolating, but its like, lets say you started mining heavily in 2011. And become the biggest miners in the world, like youre Ji-hun Woo, say. And you just hold, hold, hold, hold, hold, you probably could be controlling over 1% of the worlds Bitcoin. Maybe. Anytime I say something like you can take it up or down by a scale of 100, Im not exactly sure. But like, you know if they say that Zappo itself has like 10% of the worlds Bitcoin, its not crazy to think that more than 10% is in the hands of miners who have been holding."
## [1] " What do you think about that? In terms of also, the long term investment? Bitcoin also wont work if its just consolidated in a Zappo bunker and like a mining account."
## [1] " You wrote a couple books about Ethereum. I think ones about building games in Ethereum, and the other one is just about solidity?"
## [1] " I almost brought this up earlier, but it was weird that I would crash the conversation onto the shore if I did, but theres a feeling that a layman can get in crypto right now, and I think Ethereum is the source of this, and it has many descendants. That everything were building, its a Matryoshka Doll, and youre like, you use the Ethereum to buy this other coin, which itself is a platform, for issuing other coins. And that the whole thing, and much of whats been built, is basically the infrastructure to coins to issue more coins with. Projects that will power more projects. And when I think of actual, usable, you can go and do something today, particularly with smart contracts. I think weve got cryptokitties, Im sure you could name a couple other examples. But, we could definitely count them on our collective hands. Do you agree with that notion? And why do you think it has taken that course?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " This is like when people try to describe ETH world, its what we call it on the show. No one can describe, people can kind of be like, yeah, over there, theres a casino, and frictionless. And its very hard. When Brian Armstrong came out with Toshi, and he tried to describe it, that was the worst product description I can imagine. You just described a dystopian hell hole. Heres what you can do with Toshi. You will be doing some mechanical turk work. And then youll get Ethereum and youll use it to educate yourself, to get better level. Youre basically talking about a matrix pod people situation. And then you hear other people talk about Ethereum, and its like, the utopia in Ready Player One."
## [1] " Its like games, and everyone is getting paid for games."
## [1] " I literally, like cryptokitties barely works. Cryptokitties is a janky game. I think its really interesting, but its like a project you do in computer science for your beginning project. Its not world class software that I would power a jet with."
## [1] " Whats going on with ETH world? Is it a limitation of the programming language itself? It seems really hard to build things with smart contracts. Or I would think that thousands of people would be doing it."
## [1] " This is literally like wandering through a casino. Its like black."
## [1] " Yeah, thats my feeling. [crosstalk 00:35:29] if you walk outside into the sunlight and youre like, oh I should have never gone in there in the first place, the world is pretty great."
## [1] " Idea viruses."
## [1] " I feel like multi-level, you see a lot of people who have been involved in multi-level marketing."
## [1] " And I think its the best metaphor, because its like, well how is this going to work? Its like we are all going to win, if I can recruit 100 more people."
## [1] " If it keeps growing, you keep getting more and more people, and you keep telling them, well it will all work when we have all of the people. When enough people have joined, then the Utopia will be achieved. And really, the whole point was just to recruit people. There wasnt even a little pot of gold at the end, there was zero. It was an empty garage, where the products that you showed to your neighbors, used to live, no one won. Only the person who invented it won. So its a pretty dark view of Ethereum for someone who has written two books on it. When did you become disillusioned with Ethereum?"
## [1] " Thin skin, much here?"
## [1] " I mean this is how I feel any time I read any journalistic take on a crypto, but particularly Ethereum and its descendants. Which is, if you really want to upend the world economy, youre going to need to have a slightly hide here. And you need to learn things like, the things you say are on the record, if you dont say otherwise. If you were unaware of this previously, I question your leadership for a world economic role."
## [1] " Vitalik tweeted last week, Whats up the Rothschilds? Can anyone give me background info? Is it good that theyre in crypto? And Im like, bro, youre telling me you have the superior view of economic history, and youre like, whats up with the Elders of the Protocol Zion? Good book? You know? Its like, be a little savvier about the world. You sound like a 22 year old, which is kind of like, everyone is how old they are when they got famous. People seem a little frozen, and Im like, youre on the big stage. Youve got to be able to take it if someone insults you."
## [1] " So where do we go from here then? Youve come to this conclusion about Ethereum, but you still mine Ethereum. Do you let these kind of things guide your investment and mining hypotheses? Or youre kind of like, Hey, I have my criticisms about the code, but I think the price is going to be good."
## [1] " I believe that too."
## [1] " Ethereum has over 10,000 co founders."
## [1] " Each of them has over 100 advisory roles."
## [1] " If this was the music industry, we would say he was an industry plant."
## [1] " That he wasnt, I mean, Vitalik is a real person, but maybe the back story had been crafted a little bit. And this is my ultimate, I keep coming back to whats my binary for identifying what I like and dont like? I think the thing that really sold me on Bitcoin is that people were mining it when it was worth nothing. People thought it was interesting enough, that with no financial incentive, they were like, Ah, Ill leave my computer running at night."
## [1] " Hoard a few of these. And Ethereum sort of wants you to believe that its origins are similar to that, but youre just describing one cultural example of the difference, and it was pre-mined. There was something to give people who put $200, $300,000 into Ethereum. And you could say like, whats the difference now, theyre both being mined heavily? But even if you pre-mined a little bit, its not the same thing to me."
## [1] " Theres a long gradient from the most to the least pre-mined."
## [1] " And certainly, Ethereum is not the worst offender."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " And the IBM block chain is the scam that they went in on together."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " Most crypto scams, are crypto takes on long standing scams. Its really hard to do an original scam."
## [1] " Like people have really thought, in all of the ways that Ethereum doesnt really work yet, the scams have been honed and perfected over time. This is not our first time around humanity getting into scamming, speculation. All of these, I actually think in the Bitcoin Standard, one of the best sections in the book is realizing just, people basically descend into a speculative mania, no matter what. Tulips isnt a cautionary tale about speculative mania. History is a cautionary tale that everyone gets involved in speculative mania."
## [1] " Yeah, the economy is Tulips."
## [1] " So, what excites you now, going forward? You starting point was Ethereum, Bitcoin. Do you see a second wave of stuff that is more exciting, or are you kind of focused on the big players?"
## [1] " When you say that, the immediate emotional reaction I had is like when someone is saying theyre going to make a two of a movie I didnt really enjoy. Like, oh great. EOS two, electric boogaloo. You know?"
## [1] " Didnt we already have the crazy ICO era? ICO era?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Did you watch that video, I think it happened during consensus. There was a party on a boat for Jax, whats the parent company of Jax called?"
## [1] " Yeah, Decentral. Were you at that party, or did you see the video that was shown at that?"
## [1] " All right. Well we talked about it on the show, so our listeners have already heard a 30 minute of the video."
## [1] " But, the thing it reminded me the most of, was Scientology."
## [1] " I was like, literally, I dont even know what this is for. Its like a 3-D animated, a guys got a penguin jet pack, and hes pitching products that range from, okay I understand what that is, like a crypto wallet. Like, I have the Jax wallet in my phone, I understand what that is. And then it was like, its also going to be a set top box that connects to various block chains. And its also going to be a prepaid card, and were also going to have a Magic the Gathering style game on top of it. And I was just like, first of all, you need to go look at some of these Apple product launches. They dont just announce everything theyre ever going to do at the first event."
## [1] " You know? None of it is things you can use now, and it felt like in that Scientology way, religion is the wrong word, it felt cult-y. It felt like the foundational document for a cult. Some of these things, we at least can criticize Ethereum. Like we can say, This is what it is. I dont even know what the fuck this guy was talking about. And I watched a 30 minute video, and I knew less at the end than at the beginning, other than, its really big, and its going to encompass the whole world. You know? What the hell was going on? That guy was also an Ethereum founder, the guy from Decentral."
## [1] " What is this shit? How can a lay person read this kind of like, bullshit Scientology language that is coming out? Is it because we came from scam world?"
## [1] " Well, because, crypto is so perfect for scams, eventually, I think it will have to internalize a lot of the language and culture of multi-level marketing, or scams. So you can see that crypto is influenced by multi-level marketing schemes."
## [1] " And the way people talk. Also the thing about, everything is FUD."
## [1] " You know? Thats a thing scammers tell you. Is that people are going to come to you, and try to express skepticism. Thats also what people in cults tell you."
## [1] " Your family is going to tell you that this is a cult. Its following a lot of these mind tricks. And yet, I still weirdly kind of believe in it. I guess I wonder, there was really no question there, but you should watch this video, its insane."
## [1] " Yeah, great timing."
## [1] " Its another perfect storm scenario."
## [1] " But Donald Trump has not been president during any of the other runs where it came out all right for America. [crosstalk 00:53:46]"
## [1] " Whether you love or hate Trump, all of these things are setting the stage for us, well if there was some kind of calamitous world event, that led to Bitcoin world, I could see Donald Trump being the president in the movie about it."
## [1] " Yeah, its all cinematic."
## [1] " I totally agree. I mean, if nothing else, I think its a game that gets people to know more about how government and money works, which, thats cool, I think."
## [1] " But further, a lot of people will come out, you hear a lot of, its not Bitcoin, its the block chain."
## [1] " The enterprise block chain, its like wait, what if the profound idea is stateless money. Thats a very profound idea. To me, that idea is much more profound than Ethereum."
## [1] " And once you start talking about it, I think you were going down this direction, what you were saying. If you imagine that stateless money can exist, you can imagine that stateless people exist."
## [1] " Now thats a new idea in the world. [crosstalk 00:56:13]"
## [1] " Im not sure if smart contracts are that new an idea, in the world. Theyre kind of a new idea. But to me, the idea that somehow this ushers in a post national era is both the most terrifying and exciting part of it."
## [1] " And Im ready. I could at least see how that could be cool."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Isnt state competition kind of a disaster though?"
## [1] " If you talk to anyone who is, my friend Jake is a film director. So the way that these tax incentives work, basically its like, hey come shoot a movie in Louisiana. Actually the state will pay you to shoot a movie here. And its like, wait a minute, youre paying out tax money to get people to shoot movies here? Why is this a good idea nationally that were losing government money to encourage bayou film production?"
## [1] " I went to Wesleyan, Im very, very familiar."
## [1] " Connecticut must have the strongest blue laws in the country. I think it was like 8 PM on Friday. I just remember people hoarding. Its also a totally proven social experiment that getting people to hoard booze on Friday night, knowing that it will not be open, just encourages people to get more alcohol."
## [1] " Theres a way that it allows for greater radical moves by the states, like marijuana legalization, where its like, that might be 25 years away, nationally, but California decided it was time in California. And that does, for good and bad, create a blueprint for like, if you want to live in weed crypto state, you transfer your coins over here."
## [1] " I think thats cool. Okay. I think we found somewhere positive. I think now that weve found a positive idea, we have to stop. Because otherwise were going to go back into like some sort of a disastrous ETH hole."
## [1] " Last question."
## [1] " I know that youre investing as a fund and mining and stuff. Do you maintain a personal wallet also?"
## [1] " Oh okay."
## [1] " I was going to say, no one really understands how personal coins are taxed. I dont get it. We were just talking in the last show about, you know, Perseo? Have you seen Perseo?"
## [1] " So Jay was like, hey, you just have to pay taxes on everything you buy from Coinbase. And I was like, but what if I buy something. Hes like, theyre just going to tax you on what you bought and how much Bitcoin and what not. And Im like, how does the government know if I bought something with Bitcoin? I dont have it anymore."
## [1] " I dont understand how this tax system could possibly encompass Bitcoin."
## [1] " Okay. Well I cant ask you then whats in your personal bag. If you did keep a personal bag, what would be in it right now?"
## [1] " [No, and hey look, youre a no coiner. Who would take investment advice from you? You have no coins."
## [1] " Yeah, what are the big pools? Like, Ill say, like privacy coins are my primary focus. I like buy from the top to the bottom, privacy coins."
## [1] " Is Zencash like a Z case narcs project also?"
## [1] " Oh its a Zclassic."
## [1] " Z classic, one of the classic pumps. Wow. That pump was spectacular."
## [1] " Yeah, so how can people find you online?"
## [1] " Thank you so much for doing this, will you come back on sometime and chap it up again?"
## [1] " Much appreciated."
