## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Aaron Lammer"
## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] " Jay, its been a while. Were back here in the Crypto Cave."
## [1] " Hot day today in New York but the Crypto Cave is very cool down here."
## [1] " Youll notice I installed an air conditioner in the Crypto Cave."
## [1] " That air conditioner looks like you stole it from a Bodega."
## [1] " Well, its hard to get an air conditioner-"
## [1] " Its definitely a Bodega air conditioner."
## [1] " For people listening at home, the Crypto Cave has approximately three square feet of window space."
## [1] " Thats generous."
## [1] " 50% of which is now occupied by a Bodega air conditioner, which we cant run while were taping. Its gonna be a hot summer in here."
## [1] " Lets hope for Im hoping that prices start going up cause were gonna need some good news if were gonna be forced to sit in this room in the middle of June."
## [1] " Yeah. Heat. Us being poor and hot at the recording of this podcast is not as fun as us being slightly richer and sweltering hot."
## [1] " Well, not that its hot, I kind of wanna We did that Remember we did that episode where we took stock of our experience so far? I feel like this is another good time to take stock. Lets wait and do that in a bit."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Cause I wanna do a little bit of Every time theres a scam that I hear about, I dont wanna talk too much more about scams, but this one is so good that we have to talk about it. I think we may have gotten the ultimate scam coin unfolding story this week."
## [1] " I think that this scam, at the very least is directly in the intersection of all of our interests."
## [1] " And I also would say, its amazing to me how much of the crypto news, the first time Ill hear about a coin is as it goes down in flames."
## [1] " Why else would you hear about it?"
## [1] " What I mean, its like, theyre like, what kind of alt coins are you into? Im gonna be like, Privacy coins and coins that are in meshed in a horrific scandal that I can read about in real time."
## [1] " What presentative coins do you think that you know about are from stories about how theyve been revealed as scams?"
## [1] " I would say 50% of the alt coins that I know about."
## [1] " Yeah, I think so too."
## [1] " At least have had their image tarnished at least once."
## [1] " I would say I know much more about the scam coins than I know about the coins that Ive invested in."
## [1] " Oh yeah. Im like, I could talk for like an hour about Bit Connect, and if you were like, Project Aragon, I was like, I dont know, somebody respectable said that word once on a basement tape."
## [1] " Same. Same. Its like when I was heavily invested in Zero X and youre like, what is Zero X? And youre like, It seems to be platform of platforms something, something. ERC 20. Any scam Id be like sit down."
## [1] " Yeah. I didnt mu familiar with Skycoin?"
## [1] " I am familiar with Skynet."
## [1] " Skynet. I feel like youre already playing with fire, any kind of the sky name. I was not previously familiar with Skycoin and this one of these stories thats all like posted as a giant image thats cut up of different Telegrams. I think this whole thing happened more or less on Telegram. There was some echos here of the Sumocoin collapse, although I would say this one is more hilarious."
## [1] " They say, Skycoin staff were alerted to large coin balances that were being dumped and driving down the price. We investigated and found the stolen coins originated from the distribution wallets traced the stolen coins to the Chinese marketing team."
## [1] " The first thing that catches your eye here is Chinese marketing team."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Now, this is how a lot of these ICO alt coins projects start up. They have an initial coin allotment for the development and another initial coin allotment for marketing."
## [1] " I dont really have any insight into what these marketing teams are doing. Do you?"
## [1] " I think they send out a lot of emails."
## [1] " Theyre probably emailing us. Cause we get a lot of broken English, we wanna talk about our ICO on your show emails and someone has to be getting paid to send those."
## [1] " Yeah, and theres a lot of, Would you like to meet the founder of Xcoin, which neither of us has ever heard of. Theres no explanation outside of that. It does feel like This is something that everyone whos in crypto has said, the volume of emails that you get from being in crypto is insane. Even when I was doing running a tech blog for the New Yorker, I probably get 15 emails a day from PR people."
## [1] " Crypto is almost more than that. You and I have a podcast about crypto. Its not like the New Yorker."
## [1] " Ill say this in terms of things that I dont really like. Some of the money I invest in a software project being used to spam people by Chinese marketers, it doesnt seem like a good use of funds, if you are actually doing something."
## [1] " If youre not actually planning to do anything and youre just trying to get coins to pump them up, maybe the Chinese marketing things not a terrible idea."
## [1] " It seems like a very good idea actually."
## [1] " Okay. Jays in favor of it."
## [1] " No, no. Im not in favor of it from an ethical stand point. Im in favor of it if your project is fake and all you wanna do is con some people into buying it. Then a Chinese marketing team doesnt really seem like that bad of an idea."
## [1] " Okay, so it feels like at this point of the story, its fair to say, what is Skycoin?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Im just gonna read you the one paragraph description. The Skycoin platform is the most advanced blockchain in the world. Shouldve read that in Trump voice."
## [1] " Developed by early contributors to both Bitcoin and Ethereum, Skycoins platform is completely secure, infinitely scalable in ISP, independent, backed by bandwidth, storage, and computational power. Skycoin is built to fulfill Satoshis original vision."
## [1] " I think you can take pretty much any clause in that entire paragraph and move it to a different sentence without changing the meaning."
## [1] " Yeah. I do like the word contributors to the original Bitcoin and Ethereum project. I wonder what their threshold for that was."
## [1] " Basically, its the most generic blockchain project in the world."
## [1] " But also the best."
## [1] " Yeah. Its also the best and its the most generic. They claim that the Chinese marketing team was taking more money than they were supposed to and they also claimed that some of the coins that were supposed to go as employee bonuses to the Chinese marketing team were being held by management."
## [1] " Not only were they claiming that the Chinese Marketing team somehow defrauded them, they claim they were also not giving their employees money they were supposed to get."
## [1] " Can I just deposit here, I do not know the outcome of this story, you are telling it to me for the first time."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Im very suspicious that these employees exist."
## [1] " I am also suspicious these employees exist. One of the things that the Skycoin team accused them of is invoice fraud, which I dont know if thats a technical accounting term or what."
## [1] " We should telling people who email us asking for sponsorships on the show that we have a 12 person team that we have to pay for."
## [1] " The Chinese marketings team response to these accusations of invoice fraud is maybe the greatest sentence Ive come across in crypto and potentially what we should change the tagline of this show to."
## [1] " When you eat at the restaurant and you order vegetables, you do not ask how much the restaurant paid for the vegetables."
## [1] " Wow. Wow."
## [1] " Kind of deep."
## [1] " Yeah it is true."
## [1] " Its true."
## [1] " Ive never done that have you?"
## [1] " No. And theyre like, Hey, you want some Chinese marketing? Give us the coin wallet. Well underpay our employees as we see fit."
## [1] " In order to stop the Chinese marketing team from profiteering from invoice fraud, they immediately went to a hard fork to freeze the coins that they had."
## [1] " This is-"
## [1] " So its kind of like the DAO Ethereum thing?"
## [1] " Its like a very shitty, tiny, petty, version of the Ethereum DAO hack. Although, theyre only talking about 100,000 coin. Its not like it wouldve crippled the project. This is a deep spite move."
## [1] " It seems that they I dont know what the phrase is, but they cut off their nose to spite their face."
## [1] " Well, I feel like this is one of the overall asterisks on all of these claims of being the best blockchain in the world and the most decentralized ever. Until the people immediately do a hard fork because they are in a dispute with their Chinese marketing team. You know?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Who may or may not even exist."
## [1] " Yeah, its very hard to explain to your investors."
## [1] " Actually, the way that I originally came across this, was someone said on Reddit, Im in the Skycoin Telegram and something seems to be happening with a few of the members, including one of the main guys Synth, and another founder admin on the project. Im not sure if their fake mad at each other, but someone is dumping Skycoin, and I have suspicions it may be the Div team and theyre being fake mad at each other."
## [1] " Members of the team are having arguments on Telegram and even throwing words calling each other autistic."
## [1] " Okay. Is Skycoin on an exchange?"
## [1] " Thats a good question. I think it is, yeah. Lets see. Hold on one sec."
## [1] " I have one guess to which exchange its on. And it ends in topia."
## [1] " I mean, its definitely on some exchange, as youre about to see in the story. They start getting involved in trying to manipulate the trading of it, fairly up Oh wow, its down another 15% since I was prepping for the show an hour ago."
## [1] " Okay, that undercuts one of the points Im gonna bring up in a second. Lets see. Okay. Its on two exchanges. Youre already correct on one out of two."
## [1] " Cryptopia."
## [1] " Yes. Guess what the other one is."
## [1] " Im gonna go with that one that I signed up with that I cant remember the name of."
## [1] " Its biggest volume. On Cryptopia its 24 hour volume is only $189,000. But it did about 10 million dollars in volume on Binance."
## [1] " Oh, its on Binance."
## [1] " Its on Binance. I think Binance is embracing a high low strategy of we could make the most money if we let people trade everything. Do you see how much money Binance has been making?"
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah."
## [1] " A lot. Theyre making more money than Deutsche Bank."
## [1] " Yeah. No, no, no, no. Also, its like for people so CZ is rich as hell."
## [1] " Synth, which I believe is the same person as Steve, hes referred to alternately as Synth and Steve. After Steve froze the coins, nine people and five gang members showed up to my home and kidnapped and threatened me."
## [1] " They asked for 10,000 Bitcoin."
## [1] " Who is saying this?"
## [1] " This is the guy whos like the Skycoin guy."
## [1] " Synth."
## [1] " Synth. So he says that nine people and five gang members, I dont know if the gang members are the same people as the nine people, are they included?"
## [1] " Its either 14 or nine showed up to his house."
## [1] " Nine to 14 people, some of whom were gang members showed up at his house and kidnapped, threatened him, and asked for 10,000 Bitcoin."
## [1] " Now, Id like to say-"
## [1] " 10,000 Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Even in this extremely depressed market that were currently in, that is 65 million dollars."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Who has 65 million dollars just waiting to transfer if theyre getting Who would break in and really thing they were gonna get 10,000 Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Does Synth really have 10,000 Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Theres actually a different account for this on the Skycoin website. Says, At 9:30 PM on June 13th, nine individuals including and led by marketing team members Samsung, Fong, Mary Lee, Shong Dong Yan, and Jesse San Fe burglarized Synths home. They proceeded to hold Synth and his wife against their will for six hours over the course of which they threatened, beaten, robbed them. Thanks to wallets security measures, the group was only able to extract 18 Bitcoin and 6500 Skycoins. This gang also attempted and failed to steal the design framework for the Skycoin ecosystem."
## [1] " Okay, so this is clearly written by someone whos seen some movies. Seen some Hong Kong action movies. The idea that someone broke into someones house to get the designs for Skycoin."
## [1] " Where are they? Wheres the flash drive?"
## [1] " Give me the Skycoin designs."
## [1] " Wheres the flash drive?"
## [1] " Yeah, and hes like Now, Ill say, our apologies to the entire Skycoin team if this guy really was kidnapped and beaten."
## [1] " Yeah, you know what, Im gonna just say that I feel like theres very small amount of chance that were going to have to actually issue that apology, but yes."
## [1] " So Steve says, After the kidnapping, we released the coins until all of the And this is a hilarious misspelling. Until all these Skycon employees were safe. Always a problem if youre typing coin stuff quickly, you may have a few cons in your own explanation."
## [1] " It might just be auto complete because they call it Skycon amongst themselves."
## [1] " They did a hard fork, froze the coins, then some Triad members showed up and as a result they had to unfreeze the coins until all of their team members, who may or may not exist, were safe. At which point they say the thieves started massively dumping the coin."
## [1] " Ill say the crazy part of this story hasnt even happened yet."
## [1] " Okay. So we have a kidnapping alleged."
## [1] " Now hes safe. Synth is safe. He says, Everyones safe now. We actually did pretty well on the market too. Even during the dump we had an early investor sell 100,000 coin and the price did not drop."
## [1] " This is the first person who immediately after being released by Triad members has been like, And the coins doing pretty well."
## [1] " Hes just looking after investor confidence."
## [1] " Okay. He says, Since they are dumping the stolen coins and we cant stop them, we informed all the investors to completely pull out all price support. ## [1] " Yeah. Okay."
## [1] " This is a wild thing to do is tell everyone to sell their coins so that they can get back the stolen coins and that they will just be able to inflate the price back to its original level. I mean, to say that theres manipulation happening on the price here is to not even to begin to get into it."
## [1] " No. I mean, what he has essentially described is an incredible Ponzi scheme."

## [1] " They kind of faked people element. The money reserved for the development It seems like a common We can agree, you and I can agree, that of all the alt coins, at least 90% are totally bogus."
## [1] " Yeah, Id go a little higher."

## [1] " He was like, Well, depends where you draw the scam line. He said, Theres people who are just outright scammers and there are well meaning but incompetent people trying to do things that they couldnt possibly pull off."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " If we just draw the line at outright scammers, I still think were talking about 90%."
## [1] " Were above 90."
## [1] " Above 90%. Okay. That is how most Once we know that. Once we know that most of these actors are acting in bad faith, how do they act in bad faith, it seems like these allotments of coins that are reserved for the team are the place where you start really getting into some funny business."
## [1] " Yeah, because theres no They just printed money, essentially. All they need is a slight bounce and they can do whatever they want with their fake printed money."
## [1] " It seems like when you have in your tool kit freezing coins, hard forks, fake kidnappings, telling all the original investors to dump their coins, and that you can bounce the price back after that, youve got a lot of tools at your disposal."
## [1] " If you can do things that are on page one of any sort of market or SCC guideline that says, You can not do this, or, Maybe well just get rid of page one cause its so obvious this is illegal. The fact that you can post about it, Hey, lets do this. That is an incredible tool."
## [1] " I think the fact that you can do all that stuff in a 48 hour period suggests that decentralization is mostly in name. I dont think this reflects on the entire Bitcoin world, but at the bottom, in the shit, and what were seeing is even most of the coins on Binance are in the shit."
## [1] " Yeah. I do wonder how a place like Binance will eventually respond to this because it seems like more and more of these things are getting exposed, mostly because I think Well, I think its two reasons. The first is that obviously members of the media are interested in scams, but also, I think a lot of it just sort of self policing at this point that people are waking up and are starting to say, Hey, we need to get rid of some of this stuff."
## [1] " Anything that seems scammy is immediately surface, whereas before, I think that mightve been suppressed even."
## [1] " I think that maybe the people who were doing the initial ones were better at it, and now were seeing such growth in scammy coins that were seeing people that dont really have their shit together and are like, Okay, my first idea here is, Ill fake a kidnapping."

## [1] " Yeah."

## [1] " Yeah. Just like I made the case for the Bitcoin stable coin."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " You just made the case for, what will it be? All right, so maybe its Ripple. Maybe its something else. But, two Apples to Apples things competing rather than what I see is Bitcoin and Ethereum, Apples to Oranges."
## [1] " Totally."
## [1] " When someone is like, Why are you in Bitcoin? You should be in Ethereum. Im like, Maybe Id be in both, but one doesnt really make me think the other one  I guess you would think that if Bitcoin works, thats probably gonna be good for Ethereum. Because, if youre gonna do a bunch of the internet runs and smart contracts, then its helpful if theres already a currency."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " But mostly I see them on divergent paths, which is not reflected in the market which I just moving in total lock step right now. Which is crazy that this week Ethereum was declared more or less not a security."
## [1] " Yeah, surprising development too."
## [1] " The way that they defined I think is really good, not just for Ethereum, but for anyone who wants a Matryoshka doll coin, which is they said, Ethereums not a security, the initial presale of Ethereum tokens may have been a security sale, wag your finger, bad boys. You shouldnt have done that."
## [1] " It doesnt fundamentally corrupt the coin itself."
## [1] " Yeah, it was the best possible news that Ethereum couldve gotten."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Literally nothing wouldve been better news."
## [1] " And if you think somehow Bitcoin and Ethereum are competing against each other, I wouldve thought that Ethereum shouldve made a move against Bitcoin there. Did not happen."
## [1] " So why do you think that didnt happen? Im fascinated by it cause I read that same news and I was like, Whoa, maybe I should actually buy some crypto. I didnt, but I couldnt actually conceive of a better piece of news other than What would be better news?"
## [1] " If Metallicas dating one of the Jenner kids or something."
## [1] " You heard it here first."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Yeah no, its great news. I mean, and look, theres been great news in Bitcoin land also. Like Square got a Bit license, Fidelitys in it. Were getting extremely bullish macro news at a really steady clip here and its not moving the market at all."
## [1] " Theres a few ways to read it I think. I tend to read it in the way that I was describing re-climbing the mountain where I think people are really worried about the ability to make a big bull push and no one wants to be the first person to jump in."
## [1] " Then theres the significant view that it could go lower here. A lot of people are like, Ill get in when its moving."
## [1] " Yeah. The my dad thesis."
## [1] " Yeah. And, additionally, it seems like everyone does see themselves as standing behind Bitcoin in line, that Ethereums not gonna run until something positive happens to Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yeah, okay. So I have two theories. The first is similar to your first theory which is that we are in such a funk right now that nothing can snap us out of it."
## [1] " Were in a deep funk."
## [1] " The second thing that I would say is that, we might be having a sort of missed connections type of thing, right? Where before we thought that the input of news and the input of hype and the input of good things that happen in crypto inflates the price, right?"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " It could be that the price is completely an independent thing that is manipulated by a small group of people and that those people are starting to run out of tools to manipulate that market or have lost interest or whatever, moved on."
## [1] " Yeah, theyre all at like the same party in the Caribbean."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And the WiFis out and no one printing tenor."
## [1] " Yeah, theyre the only people with power in Puerto Rico."
## [1] " What happened to Bitfinex? He disappeared, right?"
## [1] " He disappeared. He mightve been"
## [1] " Hes probably dead."
## [1] " Yeah. The Triads who stormed into Steves house mightve gone to visit Bitfinex."
## [1] " It could be that no input actually influences the price ever and maybe it never did and that the two are operating completely separately."
## [1] " That is hard to wrap your head around because it suggests the price of Bitcoin is just a totally, totally, totally made up thing and I mean, you have to have a really, no faith in markets to believe that."
## [1] " Would you be No, no. I think that it can make small adjustments, but I dont think that it can kick off massive things, like what we saw before. The only thing that can kick off massive movement is actual price movement. If that makes sense."
## [1] " Yeah. I see what youre saying."
## [1] " So like, if it doesnt matter what the news is, if Bitcoin jumps $1200 today, who knows, maybe itll happen."
## [1] " Could happen."
## [1] " That matters. You know?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And that might get more people to buy back in. No amount of news is going to influence it."
## [1] " I agree with you a little bit in the sense of like, you know how in the NBA playoffs theres like extreme regency bias."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Someone has a really a team has a really bad game and their overall chance of winning the finals psychologically can swing really far."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " That doesnt really make sense. Its irrational. Theres a lot of variance, lets say especially in a three point heavy game. I think the Bitcoin bull rush bearishness has a real recency bias where no one wants to buy right after it went down and everyone wants to buy right after it went up, which is exactly the opposite of how math should work in this situation."
## [1] " Yeah, its the Coin Talk investment strategy."
## [1] " Yeah. Its the buy high sell low strategy. Its very real. We know that Bitcoin buyers and Bitcoin markets are immature and some may say inexperienced. I think that could be real that were waiting for one piece of, one run and that that could set off a mega run. I could believe that hypothesis."
## [1] " But, weve always said that if there is a true breakdown, the go to zero breakdown, that it would start with exchanges."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Im as negative as Ive been in a long time about crypto. I dont know exactly why. Im trying to unpack where I lost the faith, where my belief in god went away. And, I think my central feeling is, Im blown away by the elegance and the incredible foresight of the Satoshi system, but it feels like the biggest flaw in that system right now is that it still has to run through exchanges and even that one crucial link, its totally decentralized, people are running nodes or whatever."
## [1] " The fact that people need exchanges means you cant really believe anything. You cant really know whats going on, because all of it is behind the Wizard of Oz curtain. Behind that curtain is CZ from Binance and everyone who runs an exchange and everyone who can really change the price based on their own software and we would have no insight into whats going on."
## [1] " Okay. I have a question for you then."
## [1] " Not to call out CZ personally. I dont have any belief that Binance is better or worse than anyone."
## [1] " Were fans of CZ."
## [1] " But the whole exchange system has an immense power to make you believe the price is X. Now, that has been shaken. I dont believe that the price was ever $19,000."
## [1] " Oh no. Question for you then. Lets say that somebody very trustworthy who has been in the Bitcoin space forever, so like Adam Back or something like that."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " Or even Sabo."
## [1] " Sure. Way Di."
## [1] " Creates a decentralized exchange and the only thing that it sells is Bitcoin. Do you think that thats possible solution?"
## [1] " I think truly functional decentralized exchanges would be the most bullish thing that could happen for Bitcoin right now."
## [1] " Why do you think that those have not? There are decentralized exchange projects right?"
## [1] " I think that theyre not quite there yet."
## [1] " Okay, but what about this idea that it would only sell Bitcoin?"
## [1] " I think thats an interesting idea. And, I can see the value of it. I also think Atomic swaps are an interesting idea. Atomic swaps have similarities to decentralized exchanges. They allow you to make a transaction without some sort of a middle man. But, I think that theres a big problem and were seeing this a little bit in Eos right now."
## [1] " Eos has this whole voting system where you have to vote with your private keys. But no ones got their private keys cause everyones keys are in custodial accounts."
## [1] " Yeah, theyre all in exchanges. Yeah."
## [1] " I dont know if custodial accounts and decentralized exchanges can really exist in the same space. Additionally, you still need a fiat on road. The decentralized exchanges doesnt solve how do you buy Bitcoin in the first place."
## [1] " Well, it would be direct peer to peer money transfers."
## [1] " But how do you peer to peer transfer fiat for Bitcoin in a decentralized manner? Whos taking the fiat?"
## [1] " The person whos selling you the Bitcoin?"
## [1] " Well, then youre having decentralized fiat swaps without knowing"
## [1] " Well, how else would it work? You think that it would only work with Bitcoin?"
## [1] " I think that the first decentralized exchanges are gonna be for token token swaps. I think the ones that youre talking about now, if youre asking why are we not already there yet, theyre already decentralized exchanges? Theres not decentralized exchanges that allow for fiat trading. As far as I know."
## [1] " This is where I think that really just talking this through with you that Ive I think that the maximists are basically right then. I agree with you that exchanges that we have not had a catastrophic exchange event yet, which is shocking."
## [1] " Or at least since Mount Ox."
## [1] " Exactly, since Ox. If there is another Ox, then were fucked."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " In that given the amount of fraud amongst, and again, Im not trying to call out Trade Ogre what is it called?"
## [1] " Trade Ogre, yeah."
## [1] " Trade Ogre or anything like that, but all these new exchanges are popping up. The chances that one of them are completely fraudulent is very high, right?"
## [1] " Yes. Although Ill say this. I think there wont be another Ox because its so profitable to actually run an exchange now. Its not worth defrauding people."
## [1] " Well, but you dont know. That is assuming that everyone is a rational actor in here, right? When somebody says, Hold your own keys, Bitcoin is the only thing, its kind of a compelling argument I think at this point, right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " We just had now, a year of shit? You and I have both been its been over a year I think."
## [1] " Yep."
## [1] " And, we just have Its just been an explosion of Shitcoins, explosion of exchanges. And none of it seems to be moving towards a product. I think that at some point you just have to kind of scale back and be like, Why am I in this? I think for me, and I think also for you, it is no longer about getting rich quickly, which is what sort of"
## [1] " We sort of just-"
## [1] " Weve gotten poor slowly."
## [1] " Weve gotten poor slowly is right. Very, very slowly, but we have learned a lot. If its not about getting rich quickly, then what its about, its about eventually holding something that you feel like could be a integral part of future economics, right, then you should just hold your own keys and you should just have Bitcoin."
## [1] " Yeah, but theres all sorts of shoulds in the world. Generally in my interest in user experience, you cant say should. Yeah, you should encrypt your email, you should use PGP technology."
## [1] " No, no, no. Im just talking about a personal choice."
## [1] " You shouldnt be on Facebook."
## [1] " Im talking about a personal choice."
## [1] " But I think the problem is, if enough consumers take the easy route, then this utopian future can exist."
## [1] " The last time we were talking where it was going, I thought it was going more in the coin base direction, which is a mega Silicon Valley backed custodial everything. That is one eventuality. But that gets you very deep into the manipulation territory."
## [1] " Yeah. Yeah."
## [1] " Where theres a central player who really can control the market and at least the first generation of central players who can control the market, the Bitfinex, the Oxs have been short term greedy and fucked up a lot. I do believe until we reach that decentralized exchange state, Im not really gonna believe the price as much. Not believing the price, makes me not wanna buy."
## [1] " I know, but I dont understand what that has to do with this idea that as a personal choice that one should if one believes in crypto, that they should just hold their own personal keys."
## [1] " People cant figure out how to use passwords either."
## [1] " But Im just talking about if you should know how to use a keep your own keys if you really believe in crypto."
## [1] " I guess what Im saying is, even if hold my own keys, if I dont believe that the mass of crypto users are gonna hold their keys, it doesnt help me that much that Im holding my keys."
## [1] " I think it does."
## [1] " Not if the price is being massively manipulated and centralized custodial accounts."
## [1] " Yeah, but it does in the sense that you are then free from [crosstalk 00:55:25]."
## [1] " If youre entirely price agnostic, and I will say-"
## [1] " But thats what my argument is, I feel like at this point when we have no idea what the price is because of all this manipulation, that one and look, some of our friends who are super into crypto are like this and I think that theyre ultimately right."
## [1] " Yeah. At least they claim to be."
## [1] " They claim to be, yes. I think that one should be price agnostic right now."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " You shouldnt buy at this level, but you should just hold."
## [1] " My feeling is, let me ask you a question. When we started taping the basement tapes, I think Bitcoin was like 4000ish."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " If Bitcoin was where it is now, 6500, thats not actually a bad return."
## [1] " 50%."
## [1] " Yeah, 50% in a year. Beat mutual funds."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Would it be healthier if we had slowly crawled to 6500 versus speeding to 19,000 and then running the whole way back down?"
## [1] " I dont know, maybe. Again, I think that goes into the question of, that the hype cycle did help in terms of converting a lot of people at once and that a lot of those people now are really mad at Bitcoin, but I think that more people are still happy about Bitcoin, are still believe in Bitcoin than would happen if we had slowly climbed here."
## [1] " I think I think we runed some of that good first wave, although, look, many waves have been runed, the Oxers were runed, Bitcoin has bounced back before. Thats why Im still in because I do believe it can and will rebound."
## [1] " Also, you cant sell right now."
## [1] " I dont wanna sell right now. But, I will say, Im as skeptical and negative as Ive ever been, and I have had angry, swirling, dark visions that we all got scammed. The only people who really The people who succeeded here are all the short term greedy people. They have the right strategy."
## [1] " Yeah, thats what Im saying, Steve is right."
## [1] " The people who ran exchanges-"
## [1] " Steve and Skycoin were right. Theyre just like, they actually saw it for what it was. You know?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I feel like if you look at this landscape and you say, okay, we have a completely open market, there are no regulations, how can I most profit off of it? That probably was the right mentality. I think thats why these Bitcoiners, these maximists are so mad because they feel like something was destroyed and that they got jacked and I think that they cant really come to terms with is the reason why it got jacked was because of their underlying philosophy about all of this."
## [1] " Yeah, I mean. Look, if you believe it was a jacking, basically what happened is, people came along and sold people increasing amounts of Tether in exchange for US dollars that were traded for Bitcoin at like $15,000 and then that popped and like all that it took to do it was just a bunch of Tether."
## [1] " You can trade Shitcoins and double your Bitcoin or whatever. The real winners here are the people who are running the casinos. Those are also the people who are really in control. I dont know if youre ever gonna wrestle control back from them after they centralize this much power."

## [1] " Thats the other thing about these decentralized exchanges. Decentralized exchanges are not gonna be happy about them."
## [1] " Yeah, and I dont understand they hold so much they hold everyones Bitcoin and Shitcoin. How do you leak that out to those places? Its difficult."

## [1] " Thats what I think we need. Thats why I think the reset, given the both the concentration of Bitcoin in the hands of smaller people, which makes the vision for hyper Bitcoinization terrifying. Just all the problems that we have right now."
## [1] " I think that we kind of need it, something that people can believe in. Im not sure if you can really dust these two things off. I think you could with Bitcoin, but I think it would just take a long time."
## [1] " Yeah. I think Bitcoin is almost like a country or like a fiat currency. Its like, its been through some shit. Has some dents in it. Some murders were ordered, but were moving on now."
## [1] " Yeah."

## [1] "Aaron: Welcome, Saifedean Ammous."
## [1] "Aaron: I always like to ask people who are deep into Bitcoin what their initial experiences were like. When did you first come across Bitcoin?"
## [1] "Aaron: For our listeners who might not be aware of why that was an obvious connection, can you explain why there was such an interest in the, I guess, Mises School or the Austrian School of Economics people in Bitcoin at that time?"
## [1] "Aaron: As a academic economist yourself, are you hearing about all kinds of different schemes that try to improve upon money? Is it common to have something like Bitcoin thats a new idea come along?"
## [1] "Aaron: Sure."
## [1] " What happened, like, around 2013 that got you taking it more seriously because, you know, the white paper already existed. I think that some peoples affiliation with the types of economics that you prefer had already been stated, you know, like, that there had already been this connection, so, what happened where you were like, Wow, this is something I should take seriously."
## [1] "Aaron: Sure."
## [1] " I was about to say Rubini."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah, something weve talked about on the show has been that, I was of the same belief that you, that Dark Net markets would ultimately discredit Bitcoin, but looking back over that history, it almost seems like Dark Net markets are just ahead of the curve in technology, which I guess would lead you, at this point, to be interested in projects like Monero that have replaced Bitcoin on the Dark Web. As an economic historian, why do you think there wasnt that kind of a crackdown where people got thrown in Guantanamo? Do you think that was a conscious decision of government?"
## [1] " One thing I was struck by while reading your book was that the first half seems to be a lot of argument in favor of the gold standard. So, for example, you talk about how World War I was accelerated and I think in some ways, I think you would argue, caused by the fact that governments just started funding money to fund this endless war, and that the gold standard was better. Can you just talk about when you started to think that perhaps Bitcoin was an alternative to gold or why it would be a better version of gold?"
## [1] "Aaron: Particularly difficult during wars, to move a bunch of gold."
## [1] "Aaron: You wrote something in the book that captured my imagination, which is, you said that, If youre writing a book about gold, you wouldnt feel need to explain its chemical properties in order to explain gold. And, I think the analogy carries out that perhaps not everyone needs to know about the deep, inter workings of the Bitcoin system, but theres definitely a big part of the Bitcoin culture, which suggests that people should hold their own keys, people should understand the technical stuff."
## [1] " This is a question that Aaron and I talk about quite a bit, which is that, like, you lay out a pretty compelling vision of how this could go forward and what the future might look like, and the one thing that I keep tripping up on is the fact that, you know, the way that Bitcoin is distributed right now is that small numbers of people hold large, large amounts of Bitcoin and that I dont see them sort of relinquishing that percentage of what is a deflation area of currency, which if Bitcoin does become the standard of all currency, means that we have a sort of super rich, super wealthy, almost like Demi-Gods-"
## [1] "Aaron: Feudal lords."
## [1] " In the economy. Is that something that concerns you, as well, about Bitcoin going forward? The fact that like, what you have is not you have somebody who-"
## [1] "Aaron: Bitcoin going forward and the fact that what you have is not you have somebody who would be approximately a thousand times wealthier than Jeff Bezos and you would have maybe five to 10 of them and that they would inevitably have a large amount of power in the world."
## [1] "Aaron: Are we talking about Roger Ver right now?"
## [1] "Aaron: Lets just say that Winklevoss twins, for example, they are not a group that is starting a bunch of other Shitcoins or encouraging forks and slowly bleeding Bitcoin back into the economy. So much of what you write about that I find compelling personally, just because my own politics about individual sovereignty and a new sense of freedom that could arise out of this, the part that I always get tripped up and we talk about Bitcoin philosophically, which is what interests me is that I am not sure in the world in which the Winklevoss twins essentially are a nation state upon themselves that, that would lead to more individual freedoms."
## [1] "Jay: So the example that you brought up in the book is that if you have a person who you have two people who are fishing and one person builds a fishing pole and one person decides to fish by themselves and the person who spent the time to build the fishing pole eventually will build an economy around the ability that he is a bit able to pull out more fish and that will serve more people, right?"
## [1] "Aaron: It strikes me when I read your book that if we truly move to a Bitcoin standard, the whole idea of nations will change. And perhaps the idea of people identifying themselves nationally will change. What kinds of effects do you think that this shift will have on citizenship and how people perceive themselves around the globe?"
## [1] "Aaron: I was actually I was going to ask you about rick kids because one of your analogies about a non-inflationary system is that people who act rationally within this system will accumulate wealth, say in the form of Bitcoin and that, that wealth will be passed across generations, which is a virtuous thing. And I sort of like the idea, but as someone who grew up amongst private school students with extremely rich parents, isnt it a liability to do so? I didnt find those people to be the best arbiters of the world when I encountered them in high school."
## [1] "Aaron: This is basically how monarchies fell, right? Monarchies you have one dud prince thats the end of the monarchy."
## [1] "Aaron: Youre against certain forms of modern art. I get the feeling that you dont particularly like most modern music. Is that correct? Without getting too personal."
## [1] "Aaron: So the part of that, that Im sort of surprised by is, to me, that modern art is the ultimate manifestation of a free market, which is people are choosing to speculate wildly in paintings that most people find no basic aesthetic value in. And this is even true going back 500 years that during the Renaissance people were speculating on art. It was a way to curry favor with the pope was to commission art and to deal in art."
## [1] "Aaron: Please."
## [1] "Aaron: Yeah."
## [1] "Aaron: My grandfather was the exact same way."
## [1] "Aaron: Ill put a link in the show notes."
## [1] "Aaron: I see it in a totally different way because I love a lot of music thats come out in the modern era in the Arab world, but I guess I would say that those art forms are sort of modeled on the culture of their time. So lets say in the Renaissance youre going to hear the early operas. That is the format of the time. Now, we live in the era of Bitcoin and the smartphone and it makes sense that music is more compressed and its more of a quick hit."
## [1] "Aaron: I agree the thing youre describing exists, but I dont think it invalidates the human artistic project that theres a lot of crap art. There is good art thats come out in the last 25 years, in my opinion. In some ways it feels to me like youre describing a Shitcoin and saying, See, its like that. Its like Bitcoin. Im like, No, no. It is not. They have superficial similarities. Theyre both four minute songs, but the whole spectrum is possible within it. And I want to ask you, actually, about that. Thats a good transition since I dont want to argue with you about art forever."
## [1] "Aaron: My whole the whole history of my computer use has been about software dying. And I cant believe how quickly if you told me people wont be running DOS in 10 years Id be like, What? Thats crazy! DOS is great! Languages that have come and go. Its file formats that have come and go. Everything is this massive, this entropy with a really short half-life. And so Im wondering as someone whose lived through the same period of time, theres a certain outlook, I guess its the Myspace outlook, that everything about technology is about to be replaced. Why is this not true of Bitcoin?"
## [1] "Aaron: Yes."
## [1] "Aaron: Making it anonymous, say would be like some people think thats a hugely important feature that needs to be added."
## [1] "Aaron: Okay. Let me push back, though."
## [1] "Aaron: Right."
## [1] "Aaron: They gave people a discount on something that had no value to begin with, something. Yeah."
## [1] "Aaron: Taleb, who wrote the introduction to your book, said something that Ive thought a lot about since. He said that Bitcoin has reached a sufficient state of maturity now that even if something happens and Bitcoin ceases to exist, we know how to make it. Well be able to remake it. It cant be wiped from the face of the earth. So in some ways that its the idea thats a Bitcoin, not necessarily this original chain that exists right now."
## [1] "Aaron: Interesting."
## [1] "Aaron: Right. Theyre centralized by their own founders or their own leaders at least."
## [1] "Aaron: Youre in an interesting position because youre a Bitcoin believer but youre an altcoin skeptic, which in some ways makes your views similar to certain no-coiners, at least about the scammier end, lets say of the ICO spectrum. All the way up to the sort of Ethereum level stuff. As an economist, why do you think Bitcoin and crypto in general has just People like Roubini who you brought up, they almost seem more obsessed with it than the people who are believers. The critics are just as passionate, if not more passionate. Tell me what its like being an economist in this crypto world, and where you think the no-coining viewpoint comes from."
## [1] "Aaron: And thats the end of the friendship?"
## [1] "Aaron: Ill ask you my final question, which you naturally segued to perfectly. As someone who is not personally an Austrian school libertarian, its not how I see the world, I think its fascin Bitcoin is great because its allowed me to see the world through this different prism that doesnt come naturally to me. But I always want to believe that there is someway that these systems can harmoniously co-exist. When I read your book, which I found very convincing, it felt like central planning and Bitcoin standard are in a fight to the death and there can be no in between. One of them has to ultimately destroy the other. Is that your view? Is there any way for us to go to a partially deflationary system or this something that has to come to head and has to get resolved?"
## [1] "Aaron: Thats how I feel. People have asked me, if you dont believe in this stuff, why are you buying Bitcoin? I was like, well, I dont want to be poor after the free market takes it. Like, I still would act within self interest if this was the tsunami I saw coming even if I dont necessarily want it to come."
## [1] "Aaron: It sounds like a fascinating but brutal future. Like I want to see the movie, but Im not totally sure if I want to live it. Maybe like, I like your in the next couple hundred years-"
## [1] "Aaron: Thank you so much for this interview. It was great."

## [1] " Welcome to Coin Talk. Im here with my co-host, Jay Kang-"
## [1] " Hello."
## [1] " And a very, very special guest, Gideon Lewis-Kraus, live here in the crypto cave."
## [1] " Gideon, what do you think about the crypto cave?"
## [1] " Thank you. Thank you."
## [1] " Youre our first full-time guest."
## [1] " Yeah, thats true."
## [1] " Usually we have the guest sit on a stool in the corner."
## [1] " Yeah, youre-"
## [1] " So Adrian and Charlie Warzel were sitting in a [inaudible 00:01:51] stool in the corner. Youre our first full-time guest."
## [1] " Youve been given a position of prominence here. I hope you feel honored."
## [1] " Yeah, either that or a place where we torture people to get their private keys."
## [1] " Its a very manly space, I gotta say, Aaron."
## [1] " Its to compensate. This room is like the poor mans Lamborghini."
## [1] " There are two Do you see two There two Every time Im down here, Im fascinated by the fact that you have two vicious looking crowbars hanging, and [crosstalk 00:02:24]-"
## [1] " Well, Ill say-"
## [1] " What do you need two crowbars for?"
## [1] " Ill say this. What happens if your first crowbar breaks?"
## [1] " Why do you have one crowbar?"
## [1] " Ive used that crowbar before?"
## [1] " Really? Okay."
## [1] " Thats because Im always out there crowbarring in the rain."
## [1] " Oh, okay."
## [1] " Gideon, you wrote an article for Wired about Tezos. Ive never actually been clear. Is that the correct pronunciation?"
## [1] " I remember I cant even remember It was in the article, but where did the name Tezos come from?"
## [1] " Does it use some sort of combining multiple different languages or something?"
## [1] " So he failed, because its tehzos, tayzos, or teezos."
## [1] " How can a made up word be in English?"
## [1] " Not used in English."
## [1] " Pronounceable. Okay, yeah."
## [1] " Well, so that-"
## [1] " Well, the weird thing is that when I first got into crypto, I was always confused by Tezos and Trezor sounding Both having a T and a Z, and I actually, Ill admit, I originally thought that was one thing."
## [1] " Did you think they were both related to Trent Reznor?"
## [1] " The NIN coins still waiting out there to happen."
## [1] " The NIN coin."
## [1] " So I want to get to Tezos and your story, but do you guys want to do a little news first?"
## [1] " Yeah, lets do it."
## [1] " Gideon, we were actually talking about that What is it? The National Bureau-"
## [1] " Economics report. Tell us the basics of what that report said."
## [1] " I mean, weve come back to it a lot of times on this show. Its kind of incredible that the Satoshi elegant system works as well as it does. If you had told me this eight years ago, I would have been like, Itll hit some sort of roadblock. Itll be something that people havent foreseen and itll destroy the whole system. I dont think the fact that its existed for, what, 10 or 11 years now, means that wont happen, but we have passed many similar roadblocks along the way, where I was like, This seems like a fatal problem."
## [1] " Yeah, I mean, this is Were still due Jay, do you want to do a close read of the white paper as our next book club?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I think were overdue, because Im remembering this all from the white paper but hazily, but I do remember that all of the explanation of 51% attacks basically assume that 51% attacks are done by thieves, by people who are financially motivated, and I think youre correct that if we reach possible Bitcoin Maximalist state, and lets say the adversary stops being thieves and starts being the state itself, A, the resources are higher, and B, the game theory inputs are different, and you wouldnt have really thought about that problem in advance. I havent even really thought about the state shutting down Bitcoin through a 51% attack rather than through throwing people in jail, which I think is most peoples baseline assumption of how Bit-"
## [1] " Yeah, I hadnt really thought about that, either, but I dont understand why they wouldnt It seems like thats the silver bullet that the state will always have."
## [1] " Yeah, its going to be like NATO and [inaudible 00:07:53] together to do a 51% attack."
## [1] " I dont At the point where theyre like, Maybe we should kill this thing, they can just pool their money together and be like, Okay. It doesnt exist anymore."
## [1] " Is it possible the state wouldnt be able to get enough chips and computers through that? I mean, is there enough hardware on earth to buy out, to do it?"
## [1] " Some would argue they already have."
## [1] " In terms of countries that would attempt a 51% attack on Bitcoin, who do you think the front riders are? China?"
## [1] " But theyre destroying a lot of the wealth, because a lot of the moneys in China."
## [1] " I dont think that any country right now is incentivized to destroy Bitcoin. The number one is probably Russia, because if they can actually create a competitor coin, and then they destroy Bitcoin, but I dont [crosstalk 00:08:45]-"
## [1] " Ooh, I like this idea."
## [1] " I dont really see Because theres going to be like They want the crypto ruble."
## [1] " Its like a Putin and Vitalik conspiracy to crash Bitcoin."
## [1] " Well, no, because they actually are trying to create a nationalized cryptocurrency, so it does kind of make sense for them to destroy all the other cryptocurrencies, and then have all cryptocurrency enthusiasts kind of begrudgingly, maybe, use a crypto ruble or something like that. I think theyre probably number one."
## [1] " Yeah, and it also assumes that you have all of the hardware and all of that. But it would be interesting to play out a scenario in which certain governments are pushing a 51% attack on the Bitcoin network, and other governments are protecting the Bitcoin network, potentially because their current they have gone to a Bitcoin standard."
## [1] " Yeah, you just described an extremely boring Bitcoin movie."
## [1] " Yeah, I was just like [crosstalk 00:09:58] Who do you think would be leading the 49% resistance? The Swiss would be the kind of country that would be protecting the Bitcoin network."
## [1] " I think theyre too neutral. I think that it would have to be a ragtag group of cipher punks."
## [1] " A Venezuela in resistance?"
## [1] " They have no nation, but they just want to save Bitcoin because they believe in it, and they end up working for the state. Its like Catch Me If You Can, the Leonardo DiCaprio movie where hes a check forger. I think it would be like that."
## [1] " Well, you brought up, Jay, in our last episode, when we were interviewing Saif Ammus, you were like, Do you really think its a good idea for the Winklevoss twins to have more than 1% of the worlds wealth? And he was like, Absolutely. But the people who would truly be able to defend a state 51% attack would be like futile oligarchs of our future, like the Winklevoss twins."
## [1] " Oh, thats true."
## [1] " Oh, interesting. Interesting."
## [1] " Thats true."
## [1] " Yeah, whos got all the power? There are some countries that just have a lot of electricity-"
## [1] " Iceland."
## [1] " And thats going to become more and more pronounced as energy becomes environmental rather than oil-based."
## [1] " This would be a fun board game to play, where were all trying to get electricity and miners."
## [1] " Yeah, Im kind of into it. And you can do like the flag-"
## [1] " You could do like a [crosstalk 00:11:32]-"
## [1] " Yeah, it takes 11 hours to play and has 700 pieces, something like that. Im attacking from Kamchatka with my [inaudible 00:11:42] two."
## [1] " I have started development on nuclear fusion. Will take 245 turns."
## [1] " Yeah, I think this is I think we should just do this Kickstarter, guys. Kickstarters actually a good transition, because I remember, Gideon, that you wrote about a failed hardware Kickstarter."
## [1] " How long ago was that? Three or four years ago?"
## [1] " Three years ago."
## [1] " And theres nothing that the ICO environment resembles to me more than a failed hardware Kickstarter."
## [1] " Just to pause, you guys. Doing a Kickstarter or an ICO with your wife? Easily one of my lowest life priorities. I would never do something like that."
## [1] " Yeah, the challenge was mass producing it."
## [1] " Yeah, its kind of an issue in miners, also."
## [1] " But until mining became a huge industry, most of the early miners were pieces of shit."
## [1] " And this is As weve talked about ICOs on this show, this has been a consistent theme where Ill ask Jay, What percentage of these Altcoins are scams? And Jay will say, More than 95%. And Ill go, Well, I see it more as 90%. And then well be like, Well, the difference in those two figures depends on how you perceive some of these things that are colossal failures but potentially well-intentioned, or at least neutrally intentioned as projects. Which is a good way to describe I dont think many people started Kickstarters as true scams, but many people who back Kickstarters got scammed."
## [1] " Did you ever have a espresso that was made in their espresso machine?"
## [1] " Was it good stuff?"
## [1] " But having a functional product puts them at least three tiers above all ICOs for me."
## [1] " Yeah, they were going to the ICO hall of fame for that."
## [1] " Yeah, exactly."
## [1] " For building but failing to scale-"
## [1] " This is the most reputable, successful ICO in history. Hall of fame."
## [1] " I think that you just described, actually, what the closest similarity between the Kickstarter and the ICO is. The audience is in a similar position, where youve got their money. Youre supposed to deliver something and you may or may not actually be able to deliver it, and a lot of the people who are selling it, not necessarily people you would bank on to be able to deliver the thing that they set out to deliver."
## [1] " And that already existed."
## [1] " But it existed-ish."
## [1] " In terms of where they were at that-"
## [1] " Gideon, this one of the things that This is a total aside, but it was one of these things that I think your writing is good at with little details, but isnt it the first time they went that these two, the Breitmans, went on a date, that he took her to a narco-capitalism meeting?"
## [1] " Under false pretense. She believed that she was going to a different event."
## [1] " I was going to say, that is the worst first date idea Ive ever heard of in my life."
## [1] " Thats definitely the first scene in the crypto movie, though, is the guy being like, Hey, you want to go to a meetup with me? And then its just all dudes."
## [1] " Its so crazy to be like, Im interested in this woman. My first idea will be to take her to a crypto anarchist meetup."
## [1] " Do you think he did this serially? He would find women that he thought might have libertarian leanings, and then just be like, Come to a classical liberal meetup? Is there even such thing as a classical liberal meetup?"
## [1] " The only thing I can think of that would be worse is if you went to a Craft Homebrew Convention, that was your date. I think I would rather got to a narco-capitalist meeting than a bunch of home craft brewers. Anyway, Im sorry. This is quite a diversion, but go ahead."
## [1] " This is like a description of a person that I would just run away from. I mean, South-African living in Switzerland with a background Id be like, No, dont want to do business with this person."

## [1] " Yeah, youve actually looked into this person."

## [1] " And additionally, part of the claim is, Those tokens will allow you to ride the rides, and this amusement park is going to be so awesome that everyones going to want to ride these rides, and your token will increase in value as a result."
## [1] " So this will allow you to ride one ride, and [inaudible 00:24:20], theres a decentralized exchanged in which you might be able to sell it, but hey, who knows?"

## [1] " Additionally, as I understand it, when you take something like Ethereum, youre selling tickets to ride, but people are buying well more tokens than they would ever have an appetite for roller coasters, so you at least If you dont believe that its going to speculatively be worth more, you at least believe that you will be able to exchange with other people those tokens."
## [1] " Yeah, its a-"
## [1] " Because otherwise youre signing up for a life of amusement parks."
## [1] " But thats-"
## [1] " Right, and Jay and I, if I went deep on roller coaster coin and Jay went on giant soda coin, Im like, Hey, we could swap. I could get my giant soda. You can ride the thing. Everyone wins."
## [1] " You pay rent coin."
## [1] " And it was mined."
## [1] " So people didnt have to put in fiat in the first place. People were able to create the initial value through mining, which is not true in the case of Ethereum or Tezos, as far as I understand it."
## [1] " Well, I think economists would also argue that people figuring out how to mine it is a form of productivity."
## [1] " Not surprising that theres a Swiss loophole that makes it easy to do things that are financially frowned upon in other countries."
## [1] " I mean, its also strange its a strange environment that by a factor of 10, people are uncertain about how much money theyre raising. When people have raised money for startups, etc., they have some idea of what theyre raising it for. Like the idea that something-"
## [1] " But people had to deliver it. For each person who backed the Kickstarter, they had to deliver one product, so it was scaled. I mean, its just Its strange to think a company that conceivably could have delivered a product for $10 million within rational thought also could take $200 million."
## [1] " $10 and $20 million is actually a lot until people are raising $200 million."
## [1] " I mean, Ethereum was $18 million-"
## [1] " And that was considered a lot when it happened."
## [1] " And weve got a great name like the canton of Zug."

## [1] " And this is not a totally original idea. Theres Decred is another."
## [1] " Okay. At the time it was-"
## [1] " Well, I mean, I thought you were going to say the flip side of that, of why this one, why then, is coming off of Ethereum, a much smaller raise. Everyone made a shit ton of money who bought in early, so theres a bunch of that. A bunch of the money thats coming in is not true fiat but people whove made a bunch of money by speculating on Bitcoin. So people are gambling with-"
## [1] " A lot of house money, and house money gambling has been very good to people at the time. I always kind of read it, and tell me if you disagree, that Tezos was a bit at the right place at the right time."
## [1] " I still dont totally understand what Tezos is, though. I want to read the description from your article. While the irony of preventing the fragmentation of cryptocurrencies by releasing a new one does not escape us, the second paper concluded, Tezos truly aims to be the last cryptocurrency. So my frame of reference here is Ethereum and various what we refer to as matryoshka doll cryptocurrencies, which are its a currency that you can make more currencies with. Its a token for making more tokens."
## [1] " So there wasnt like an ERC20 of Tezos."
## [1] " So the whole thing could run just on Tezos. Okay."
## [1] " Theres a moment in the story, I would say maybe the most damning moment of the story, in which Breitman wife, whats her name?"
## [1] " Kathleen says, Its just like tote bags. And this has been a longstanding question weve had about ERC20 tokens, Tezos, whatever, which is, is the token guaranteed to actually do anything?"
## [1] " Because theres this company in San Francisco, I cant remember the name, that was selling a token based on the idea that they would do security audits, and the whole thing was built on the idea that the only way to get these security audits was to buy their token, and then they actually sold the token, and then theyre like, Oh, some people wanted to get a security audit, so we just sold it to them in US dollars, and some of them paid in Bitcoin. And it was like, Oh, well, theres not really a market for that anymore."
## [1] " Theyre like souvenirs for-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Or if you The context in which she said it was like, If you give money to NPR, theyll send you an umbrella, or something like that, and thats a gesture of appreciation."
## [1] " And she didnt say this to you. She said this to a Reuters reporter who originally wrote that in a story."
## [1] " Sure. Its kind of hard to describe how tokens work, because even people who understand them, I dont even put ourselves among them. Theres not a unified view on them. You Yeah, okay. [crosstalk 00:43:36]."
## [1] " Hmm. I dont believe that."
## [1] " Do you believe that? Ive never heard of a single person buying because of that."
## [1] " I think it is 99% speculators, 0.9% people who are like, Maybe I can use this to build another coin, and then 0.1% who might be not real either."
## [1] " Let me make a counterpoint, though. I agree that almost everyone whos investing deeply in cryptocurrency is ideological and has a religious belief."
## [1] " Really? I mean, I invested, and I had no ideological or religious belief."
## [1] " Well, at least early adopters."
## [1] " Were talking about at the time of that."
## [1] " People who havent touched a vegetable in a year. But my point was going to be, I think you can be both. You can be an ideological believer and a speculator."
## [1] " And someone like Saifedean would say, I think, that in the case of Bitcoin Saifedean hates shit coins, right? But in the case of Bitcoin, if you buy $1,000 worth of Bitcoin, you are buying that percentage of the overall supply of Bitcoin in the world. You are actually You own a piece of Bitcoin. You may not have governance rights to it, but you Actually, you do have a form of governance rights because you can buy and sell forks, but youre owning it, whereas in the case of an ERC20 token, or an ICO, youre buying into something that doesnt have some clear supply relationship like that. Youre getting a little bit Its more like a tote bag. Youre signaling and youre speculating, but what the thing is One Bitcoin is not the same as one ERC20 token, and that-"
## [1] " Right, or an Ethereum token, lets say."
## [1] " The deflationary world."
## [1] " Mad Max."
## [1] " I feel like people would If youve listened up to here, read the story for how it all fell apart, and suffice it to say, it all fell apart, and not in a code-based way, not in a security flaw, in a very human way."
## [1] " Yes, and has yet to produce anything with that billion dollars."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Just awesome."
## [1] " Amazingly, one of the best business models might be to do a failed ICO that just gets you a bunch of ETH, and just sit on it."
## [1] " Dont make me get down the crowbar. We only allow Austrian school of economics here."
## [1] " I mean, they failed in that respect. They failed as much as two people could possibly fail."
## [1] " Interesting. So you believe that they could come back from something like this. When we got into crypto a year ago, if you had started typing ICO scam, Tezos would have auto-corrected from Google. It became synonymous with a project that people poured a ton of money into and produced nothing except hilarious if you didnt put money in stories, and additionally, I think that theres a certain schadenfreude here, which is anarcho-capitalists who believe that the market can solve anything being thwarted by the most basic of human conflicts and everything that happens that makes things not a pure market, like when you get into business with a South African Swiss [inaudible 00:51:33], it may not just play out as a frictionless system of energy bouncing around. Where are they at now?"
## [1] " Rich?"
## [1] " This happens in a lot of This happened in Bitconnect, everything. It almost becomes a worthwhile project simply because its built a passionate audience, because that passionate-"
## [1] " Aaron is talking himself into $SUMO again right now."
## [1] " Well, but this is the psychology the people who hold these tokens that go down in flames, is if this is our low moment, we got a bunch of people here. If we could just build this back, we could at least get our money out, etc. This seems like a dangerous form of thinking, though."
## [1] " A thing weve talked about on the show before is that its hard to figure out why anyones actually going to build these projects if theyre rich. If you make a ton of money on an ICO, and it sounds like, actually, they didnt, but some of these ICOs are structured so day one, the founders are fuck you rich, why actually build something? What incentivizes people that-"
## [1] " Really? I mean, do they mean that? Or-"
## [1] " Okay, but we hear the same-"
## [1] " Austrian school. Good."
## [1] " We hear similar things from every tech company. I mean, so what level of sincerity compared to, lets say, your average Silicon Valley startup that is figuring out how building spikes so that the homeless cant sleep on the sidewalks, and then saying, Were trying to help the world."
## [1] " Well, if you consider exposing people to free markets and stateless banks as good, then thats good, right?"
## [1] " Okay, but I dont think that thats true of ICOs, though, because this is something Aaron and I talked about last week, which is that I dont doubt your reporting at all. I think that if you tell me that these people are well-intentioned, then I believe that theyre well-intentioned. The reason why the initial response is to be skeptical is because I think that part of what Ethereum did was that it made it so that its so easy to print coins and so easy to do ICOs, that in fact there is no emotional labor or anything to get one, and we just find a whole bunch of them, that there is no good intention. Theres actually no intention, period. Its just, Hey, maybe theyll open this door."
## [1] " Mozart sucks."
## [1] " So if we remove intentions, and I agree, intentions are hard. If a scammer and a well-intentioned failure end up in the same point, it makes it difficult to say, Oh, intentions are everything. In some ways it becomes results. So in thinking about what went wrong here, and I think at this point we still have to classify Tezos in the what went wrong camp."
## [1] " Thats a Silicon Valley ideology."
## [1] " Theyre post-human, in a way."
## [1] " Like Saifedean talks about the Blockchain extending for hundreds of years, beyond a persons lifetime."
## [1] " Dont make me get the crowbar down."
## [1] " Well, I think thats absolutely true, and also it seems like they ran up against some of the limitations of people."
## [1] " That we keep imagining these frictionless market systems in which people cant intervene or whatever, and they only assume this slight bit of human trust, but the minute you give the guy the only keys to the bank or whatever, thats a human thing in there, and I feel like crypto imagines itself to be post-human, but the realities of doing anything in the world right now are that you have to interface with people, and I dont know. I guess Im curious about projects that would sort of assume that, rather than assume, Oh, people wont play into it."
## [1] " If this was a novel, Id be like, Eh, its hitting the nail on the head a little bit hard here. Did they have to get screwed over by the Swiss South African bank guy? Yes, they did. They did."
## [1] " Where can people find the story?"
## [1] " And where can people find you?"
## [1] " Are you going to continue to write about Blockchain and crypto related stuff, or do you need a five-year vacation at this point? This story took a lot out of you. Youre grayer than the last time I saw you before you were working on this. Yeah, and you were personally threatened during this thing."
## [1] " Okay, well, if you disappear mysteriously, Im going to investigate, okay? Will you come back on next time you get something on this copy?"
## [1] " Awesome. Thanks."
## Joining, by = "word"
