## [1] " You and I have been burned."
## [1] " Yeah weve been burned many times by Zcash and I guess the market saying that this isnt like enough to like really change the situation, which is crazy. I would have [crosstalk 00:35:39], but the thing I was the most surprised not to see on this list was Augur."
## [1] " Yeah, me too. I mean, good segue. So why were you surprised not to see Augur."
## [1] " Augur is this would be an amazing time to announce Auger because the Augur markets opened this week and there was a lot of attention on Augur. I think it shot up to being in the top five [inaudible 00:36:00] apps on the Ethereum network by daily volume pretty much right out of the gate. It seems like people are pretty excited about it. When you told me about it, I definitely was like, what questions are on it? Whats happening? Its the kind of project that gets your imagination going, which is sorely needed, I would say at this point."
## [1] " Yeah. And this is something weve discussed quite a bit, but it actually interfaces with the exact thing that you and I think crypto in the short term should be focused on, which is gambling, you know, gambling prediction markets."
## [1] " Im going to amend that to the short, long and [inaudible 00:36:36], which is, thats the thing people actually want to do is gamble."
## [1] " Yeah. But right now what can crypto maybe handle? What can smart contracts maybe reasonably handle, like gambling, seems like one thing. Right? And so yeah, I was a little bit surprised as well, like it did seem like there was a lot of hype, but then I actually took a look at some of these prediction markets that they have. So for those who dont know, a prediction market is essentially like a way of betting and you are essentially crowdsourcing an opinion and you can bet for or against that as the line moves up or down. And so for example, if you think that like, leading up to the election, basically if you thought that Donald Trump was going to win, you could go on a prediction market and you could put a be in, and you would get amazing odds because Hillary Clintons chances of winning were valued somewhere around, I think like 92 cents to the dollar. Maybe theres a little bit less than that, but its like an odds maker essentially."
## [1] " Yeah. And that plays into the general crypto world belief that smart open markets can answer any question and can efficiently find the perfect line. And that if we just open ourselves up to them, we can almost read the future. I mean, people actually believed that wed be able to predict terrorism and events like that through prediction markets."
## [1] " Thats how it started. Prediction markets started because DARPA decided to create a prediction market. And"
## [1] " Decided to created a prediction market, and their only question was, where will the next terrorist attack be? And their belief was that, somebody would eventually be financially incentivized enough to put a lot of money into the place where they knew it was going to be, and that it would be some sort of tell into what was actually going to happen, that obviously was stopped for several ethical reasons. Prediction markets are pretty easy to find now, I mean, you can find all sorts of them here that you can do legally in the United States. So, its not like Augur is a particularly new idea, but it supposedly was gonna get around the biggest problem of prediction markets which is that it is gambling, and so its illegal. And so all prediction markets in the United States have to basically have a.edu address, or have some sort of affiliation with a university."
## [1] " Do you ever go to a place, and they would ask you to use your student ID, or there are certain deals you have to set up where you have to have a.edu address. Thats kind of what a prediction market is. It needs to have some tie to a university. And also the charge on these things is insane, so to withdraw money I think they have like a 5 to 10% chop on the money that you try to withdraw out of a prediction market which, you know, kind of kills your odds immediately. So theyre very hard to win."
## [1] " Theres one other major difference between a traditional prediction market and this, which is that users themselves can set any question into offers."
## [1] " Yeah, there are versions of that that exist, but theyre not legal, so. The decentralization of this kind of makes it better in the sense that you can bet almost anything. Like Aaron, you and I could have made a Augur prediction market that was like, will this podcast recording take over an hour or something like that."
## [1] " Right. I mean, wed have to find a taker on the other side for it to actually create a contract."
## [1] " I mean, you and I could take opposite sides."
## [1] " Oh I see, I see. And then you just start grandstanding and trying to push it over and hour."
## [1] " Yeah, and youll be like, I actually have the button that makes this stop recording."
## [1] " Id be like, oh, cant hear you, talk later, bye! Theres a few things that surprised me, I mean. When you go on it, theres not actually a way to access it unless youre, I believe, running an Ethereum node. Or you can run the software for it. But someone made a web GUI for it. What is it, something like global.predictions or something?"
## [1] " Predictions.global."
## [1] " Predictions.global. So this allows you to visualize the biggest best on the Augur network."
## [1] " Yeah. So Im gonna read a few of them to you. Have you looked at the percentages of these?"
## [1] " Yeah, the lines seemed really wrong."
## [1] " Yeah, yeah. So for example, the first one is, will the price of Ethereum exceed $500 at the end of 2018? 52% say yes, and that theres 72,000 at stake."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Apparently, so then there are ones that youd expect that are more exciting like World Cup Final, France versus Croatia, resolved after 90 minutes. Augur predicts that 50% France wins. I mean, thats a terrible line."
## [1] " Okay, so lets pause here, because youre a more experienced gambler than I am."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The first thing that looks fishy there is, that would suggest that France and Croatia have even odds. And every line I saw in any kind of a sports book has France heavily favored."
## [1] " Yeah, France is heavily favored, so if you are a smart better, than what you will do is you will bang France on this line, because youre getting a much better price."
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " So what that indicates is two things. The first is that its kind of exciting, which is you can get it on early betting and you can profit from it, right."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " But the thing that is more concerning is that the second that you and I and everybody else thats seen the action line bangs France on this, the line adjusts, you know. As its supposed to."
## [1] " Right, but arent you locked into the line though, when you bet?"
## [1] " Yeah, you are, but I mean the line changes for the next person. The handicap shifts."
## [1] " Right. And it should get better and better over time."
## [1] " It should get closer and closer to the real odds, but the weird thing is that this, it just didnt shift at all, which means either nobody is using this, and nobody actually made these bets, although it says that $27,000 are at stake. Or it means that somethings broken. And that its not just reflecting anything."
## [1] " Well, even though this is a top five D app, when they actually show the volume, the daily volume use, theres only 330 address or something like that that are being used, so this is not a large enough pool to get anywhere close to real lines, especially with the weird crypto ish questions, which Im like, if Ethereum exceeds $500, Im like it does suggest a pretty crazy future in which you can create futures on anything, on any coin, on any crypto position, by asking and letting it zero in here. But it seems like we need thousands if not hundreds of thousands of betters to really get full coverage, enough to be accurate for most of these questions, because there would be a lot of questions at that point also."
## [1] " Yeah, well. Theres two theories about this. The first is that you are right, and that things need a certain volume. But for specific questions that get no volume, for example, not who will win the World Cup but something like, the number 4 question here which is, will MedCredits release Hippocrates medical app on Ethereum mainnet by October 15th, 2018? Shockingly, Augur predicts that 85% say yes, right. So what does that tell you. It just tells you that somebody that is involved in the MedCredits Hippocrates medical app created this market and put all the money on it for some reason, right. Hoping that someone would take the other side so that they could profit off of it. So in that way, that is more telling, because you can almost certainly trace it to somebody whos involved with that market. But I would say that something like France, or the popular ones, like will Donald Trump be the president in 2021. Those types of things you need some sort of volume for it to be interesting at all."
## [1] " The final two, the number 29 and number 30 questions are, will Donald Trump be impeached before the end of his first term? 30% yes. Will Donald Trump complete his first term as President of the USA? 90% yes. These things are not even being matched with each other. So, look. This is in a very rudimentary state. I almost feel goofy trying to critique it because its obviously not fully working yet, and I think that the developer Joey Krug whos behind it was like, yeah, theres some problems, what do you expect. This is a rough launch, you know."
## [1] " There are tons of things that launch better than this. My favorite one is number 11, which is will the REP tokenREP token being the, I believe that is the currency of Augur, right. Will REP token trade above $32 at the end of 2018. Augur predicts 90% yes. I mean, I will just say this. As a gambler, as somebody who likes prediction markets, as somebody who is into crypto and would rather use Ethereum to bet honestly, than giving my credit card over to any number of shady offshore places. This is exciting, but man, this is not a good launch. It could have gone a lot better."
## [1] " So, youre a gambling man. Its well known, its discussed on this show. All of these bets are paid out in Ethereum. So despite REP being the token of Augur, these bets, I assume that you put Ethereum into escrow, and then at the end of these terms, which like in the case of the World Cup would be today. In the case of that Donal Trump question would be in a couple years. There is a system which users vote on which side was right using the REP tokens as some sort of a staking-"
## [1] " Wait, really?"
## [1] " Yeah, thats how it works. And then it pays out."
## [1] " Oh, so like basically, you have to use a REP token to vote on whether or not something that happened, happened?"
## [1] " Yeah, and you earn REP by saying the right one. So its almost like, 51 percenting. And bitcoin."
## [1] " Who audits whether or not its the right one?"
## [1] " Well, its like the majority of users. More and more users vote on it, and it figures out using some sort of a smart way. Look, I dont really know. But the surprise to me is I always thought, Im a REP holder, I hold a little bit of REP. That REP would in some way be used in the settlement. I was completely wrong, the settlement is all in Ethereum. Which is, for real, and will probably be worth more in the two years or in the long run as these bets play out. Would it make sense for us, and I mean you, because youre the gambler among us. To go in, hunt, and pack, and find some of these ridiculous lines, and lay a little Ethereum on it? Especially if theyre ones that are gonna resolve fairly quickly."
## [1] " Yeah maybe, but I dont think it would be wise to do a lot, because we dont know what the future of the project is. And so the biggest problem with betting really on anything strange or anything exotic is that, its hard to get your money paid out, you know? And so, there are all sorts of books out there that advertise better vigs than other books, but at some point youre more willing to pay an extra 2% because youre confident that youll get paid out than-"
## [1] " Absolutely."
## [1] " 72% and not knowing what the hell you put your credit card information into."
## [1] " I would certainly be worried when I see, will Serena Williams win the Wimbledon 2018 Womens Tournament, it says it ends in 21 hours."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Thats already resolved. So Id be a little bit worried about weird after hoursI dont quite understand how this stuff works. That said, looking at some of these lines, if you did go bold and bet on them, you could make a pretty good amount of money."
## [1] " Yeah no, I agree with that, I just feel like I think a small controlled about is the right way to go about it, and just hope that Augur works. And then eventually these kinks are fixed. I actually think that they will be, I think that this product will probably work eventually, I just think that at this point, going around, hunting around with Ethereum. And also apparently one of the problems here is that to make the transaction work, you have to pay gas, which is the Ethereum tax to make something happen. Apparently the gas fees are pretty high, and so you might actually do better just going to a normal prediction market, you know. Because depending on the gas that youre basically paying as a tax in every single bet, it might actually be worse value than just going to a established prediction market that you know at least youll get paid out on."
## [1] " Yeah, but these lines are just radically wacky. Like, okay for instance. Will Ethereum trade above $500 in July 2018. So thats the next two weeks, more or less. That meansand the line is 75% yes. That means to take Ethereum-"
## [1] " Whats Ethereum at right now?"
## [1] " Its at like, four hundred something dollars. Its not that close. Here, Im gonna look it up right now. Right now, Ethereum is trading at $449. So thats saying that you can give me four to one, that Ethereum wont go up $50 in the next two weeks? Ill take that. In a second."
## [1] " Yeah, I would take that too."
## [1] " Very good, fantastic."
## [1] " Actually, youve convinced me, lets do this."
## [1] " Yeah, lets grab some Ethereum off of people, thats fantastic."
## [1] " Isnt it impossible to get money in in these markets, though? I mean, you and I do not, we dont run an Ethereum node."
## [1] " I dont know, we havent tried."
## [1] " Do we run, do you run an Ethereum node?"
## [1] " Okay, if youre listening to the show, and you can set us up an Ethereum node so we can take some of these bets, I think we should go through and cherry pick the worst bets here. I also think, will the REP token trade above $32 at the end of 2018? 90% yes. That means to take no, which is basically just that its gonna go down, is ten to one? Ill take it."
## [1] " Yeah, I would take that too. Yeah. Huh. Yeah, actually youve convinced me. I dont have any Ethereum, but-"
## [1] " Ive got some Ethereum-"
## [1] " Its gonna take me two days to figure all this out, but maybe we should do it. Lets do it and see what happens for the next show."
## [1] " Look, if youre listening to this show, send us an email, and tell us how you can help us make some of these bets. Theyre not financial advice, in fact were saying they are terrible bets, which is why we want to take them. I think we want to get in while its early on some of these. I feel like its like the rare Pepe cards, you know. The first people to buy in get a good one, and sell them to the next sucker down the line. Because thats another thing you can do, with Augur. Is you can lay a bet, and then sell that bet to someone else."
## [1] " Yeah, prediction market works that way, in which you get it at 50 and then it moves to 90, and then you can sell at 90, right. You can sort of take your profits whenever you want. Which I think is cool."
## [1] " I feel like we should scoop up some of these Trump to win second term bets, and then just resell them in a few weeks for more."
## [1] " I mean, I think hes gonna win again, so which side would we take?"
## [1] " I dont even care which side, Im gonna look at whatever the line is, and Ill take whatever the obviously better side is. Like for instance, will Donald Trump complete his first term as President of USA? Augur predicts 90% yes, thats ten to one that he doesnt. I dont know if I like that, actually."
## [1] " Yeah, I think hes definitely gonna finish his first term, dont you."
## [1] " Yeah. No, not definitely, if you give me a hundred to one, Im all over it."
## [1] " Yeah, ten to one is not a hundred to one."
## [1] " Im just saying, theres a point to some of these. I would just cherry pick the lines and work up."
## [1] " Yeah, lets do this."
## [1] " And the longer term one."
## [1] " I mean, I do not want to buy Ethereum, but maybe Ill borrow some of your Ethereum, lets do it."
## [1] " So you can post one of these questions without actually putting up money, and then other people would put money into it. So if you go far enough down, you start seeing the questions that no one has put money on. Heres one, number 42, will Warren Buffet die by the end of 2019."
## [1] " Oof. I dont want to answer that."
## [1] " The other thing you can do is lay some uneven ones here, and then try and stake our spot on some of these. Like, no one has bet yet on who will win the next Superbowl."
## [1] " Actually, I see an answer on that, which is Eagles."
## [1] " Some of these are double posted, too."
## [1] " Yeah. I see one that has no money, will Chelsea win the English Premiere League in 2018/2019. And theres no money in any of that. So I dont know, it seems like there are questions that have answers that already have betting answers. Like that for example, you can definitely go see what Chelseas actual odds are, and you can bet it both ways and you can see which way it swings, and you can get in and you can get out. And so, in some ways thats attractive in the sense that you have a very, very virgin prediction market that you can manipulate. But at the same time, I dont know if you and I are the sharks to do that, you know? We might be the ones that are being taken advantage of. But yeah, I dont know. This is interesting. Maybe we should have Doug on, and we should tell Doug that we want to do those, and have Doug do it too."
## [1] " Yeah, lets have Doug on. I say that we put one Ethereum in on behalf of the show, and just buy up whatever the dumbest contracts we can on here."
## [1] " Okay, lets do it."
## [1] " Alright, cool. Well, talk soon?"
## [1] " Yeah. All right. Talk to you soon."
## [1] " All right. See you later."

## [1] "Jay Kang"
## [1] " Jay."
## [1] " Yo."
## [1] " Welcome."
## [1] " Hows it going?"
## [1] " Always nice to sit with you both in front of the monitor here."
## [1] " Yeah, this is the closest weve done in recording in a long time."
## [1] " This is a rare Coin Talk tutorial session."
## [1] " Hows the Crypto Cave doing after the recent flooding events?"
## [1] " The Crypto Cave is on a flood plain. You know where youre uninsurable, youre gonna flood again, you need to move off of this bayou?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Id say thats basically the status of the Crypto Cave."
## [1] " Its like real estate in Coastal Long Island right now."
## [1] " I Googled the best mop for floods. Because I decided I needed a flood mop.."
## [1] " Whats the answer?"
## [1] " No one they dont make a flood specific mop."
## [1] " The only way that I could see that a mop would be made for floods if it was really big."
## [1] " Thats basically what I was asking."
## [1] " Here Google, hey what is the biggest possible mop?"
## [1] " Comically large mop."
## [1] " You need to go to a prop store or something like that."
## [1] " So, last time, last episode, you and I talked a little bit about Augur."
## [1] " Yeah, in an episode which was full of misinformation, we should say."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " I think that we have a good justification for the misinformation."
## [1] " Personal incompetence."
## [1] " Well more that like, you and I approach this show in a we are the average consumer."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " We are the average crypto consumer, and we will do an average amount of research into these things."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " Sometimes we do more than average-"
## [1] " Sometimes were a B minus. Sometimes were a C minus."
## [1] " Yeah, were never a solid B."
## [1] " Weve never received an A."
## [1] " We dipped into the F plus."
## [1] " Weve had a couple Fs. Look this stuffs confusing."
## [1] " I think that my justification for it would be like look, if Augur wants to launch and if it really wants to be what its worth and it wants to put out a product which is rare in Crypto, that product should be easy to understand. I dont think that we were approaching this as full noobs. We understand here I see twenty tokens, we understand Ethereum smart contracts. And we understand-"
## [1] " Were very experienced at gambling."
## [1] " Yeah, we understand gambling and prediction markets. And so if we couldnt figure it out after a few hours of reading about it, then I would just say that thats Augurs fault and not our fault."
## [1] " Im gonna take the other side here, which is Augurs brand new, just launched and I take this product the same way I take Crypto as a whole, which is, you can think about it, talk about it, read about it, you dont really have a full impression until you try it. Until you actually buy coins, hold coins, and in this case of Augur, actually download Augur get it going, have the experience. Its almost like theres a way its described and theres a way that it actually is. I found that way it actually was much more interesting than how it had been described to me."
## [1] " Okay but what if Blizzard put out a game right?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And there are no instructions to the game, and you couldnt figure out really how to download it and then there was a ton of misinformation about the game. And there was no attempt from Blizzard to differentiate between real and fake information?"
## [1] " But this is almost like what games were like in the Pong era or whatever. Or like when I was trying to-"
## [1] " Im pretty sure that we can figure out Pong."
## [1] " I mean, that were in the infancy. Remember how hard it was to run Leisure Suit Larry on DOS?"
## [1] " No"
## [1] " Jay, you know what Im talking about."
## [1] " C:// run-"
## [1] " Run.exe. So I decided that I would give Augur a run, and for people who are interested in doing this at home, we chose this project because it appealed to us and we wanted to give it a try. I went into this, I didnt read the instructions, there didnt seem to be instructions. So the first thing you do is you just download Augur. Its an app for Mac, Windows, Linux. A quick download."
## [1] " Okay, and just for those who are listening who dont know about it. The two second explanation of Augur is that it was one of the hottest Ethereum apps or Ethereum ideas in companies in coins that came out early on. The people who made it became pretty wealthy, I think theyre part of the Crypto community in Puerto Rico now?"
## [1] " I think Joey Krug lives in San Francisco."
## [1] " Okay but theyre in one of the rich Crypto houses."
## [1] " Yeah, and I believe that Joey Krug whos behind the project is also part of a fund and has been involved in other-"
## [1] " Yeah, no shaming of them for that. But just to show that this is not a small project."
## [1] " This is a very hyped up project. And I think its also a project that for the layman, for the noob out there whos not into Crypto, its easy to explain why this might be an interesting idea. You can create, ask any question, and create a market for it. And anyone can come gamble on that market."
## [1] " Yeah, so we could ask, will Coin Talk be around in 2019?"
## [1] " Right. Will Donald Trump be elected to a second term? Thats currently-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So thats the kind of stuff people would be asking on here. So you download it, and then you have to choose a network. Now, Im going to tell people here, you can choose a bunch of networks including a couple of test nets here."
## [1] " You have to pick a network?"
## [1] " Yeah, you have to pick a network."
## [1] " Is that like a blockchain that you-"
## [1] " Yeah, yes. Im going to get there, Im going to get there."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " So, I recommend that you pick the main net. I tried it on a couple of the test nets, and I wasnt actually able to get the live data, I was only able to get the questions. So, if you go to main net, you connect through a service called Infura. Infura.io. Youll see the HTTP endpoint is mainnet.infura.io. So, when Augur was first coming out, people were like, you are going to have to run your own Ethereum node in order to run Augur. This is not totally accurate. You can use this service called Infura, which it is a centralized node, but they kindly give you access to it. However, once you choose the main net, you have to click update connection and it will sync the Ethereum chain to your local installation. Currently our good friend Ledger Status who will be on the program later, is sitting there waiting until his node syncs. Jay, Ive done you the great courtesy of syncing this node before he arrived in the-"
## [1] " Oh yeah, its like a cooking show where you already put the stuff in the oven."
## [1] " Okay, so this story started a few hours ago. When I synced the node. I think it took me half an hour to an hour or so. I dont have great wifi here. Its a clunky, slow antiquated way to do things, but its a window into how things are going to work on the blockchain. Which is, in order to interact with the Ethereum block chain, youre going to have to sync it."
## [1] " You have to download software and sync it."
## [1] " Directly or through Infura. I understand that lots of people who are decentralization purists would say that its not that great to use a service like Infura, but okay well come back to that."
## [1] " Okay, so, this is not on video, but we have been staring at the number 99.9% for about a minute now."
## [1] " Say that it crawled up into the high 90s and after it got there, it gave me the option to open the Augur app, so I guess you dont have to be at a full 100%. But once it gets up to about 99.9, look at the button that says open Augur app. That becomes lit once its ready to go. So Im going to click that, and what it does is it opens Augur in your web browser."
## [1] " Oh."
## [1] " So, were now connected to the Ethereum block chain, but were in the web browser. And Ive two option here, Ive got markets and Ive got account. Without actually making any kind of account, or putting any money in or anything, you can go and look at all these markets. If you want to make markets or place wagers, you need to click account. Once youre in the account tab, you basically need to sync it up to some kind of a wallet."
## [1] " Its the same service that was used for Cryptokitties."
## [1] " Yeah, and Shape Shift is kind of similar if youve used it before. They support Metamask, Ledger, Tressor and Edge. I just happened to already have a Metamask going here, so Im going to connect Metamask."
## [1] " Okay, so were five clicks in so far."
## [1] " I think were doing pretty well-"
## [1] " Were doing pretty well-"
## [1] " at keeping our clicks down."
## [1] " and I gotta say, as a person who doesnt care as much about logos and UX as you do, it looks kind of nice."
## [1] " Its pretty slick."
## [1] " Its like a very pretty purple-"
## [1] " If you tell me this was a successful new application start up out of San Francisco, I would not doubt you."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Okay, so now Im logging into my Metamask account. Now, Ive gone to the liberty, Jay, of popping a couple ETH into my Metamask account so that we would be fully funded-"
## [1] " Okay. Great."
## [1] " when we got here. So lets go check out the markets."
## [1] " So at this point we are ready to make our first yes no bet in prediction market."
## [1] " So if you click over to markets, I believe theyre sorted by popularity. So the most popular markets at the top. This has been the most popular market since launch. I now see that it has moved a bunch today."
## [1] " Yeah. So the way that a prediction market works, for those who dont know, is that the question is, Will the price of Ethereum be over $500 by the end of 2018? And you bet on it. Theres a price that comes out. Yes right now, is what 70-"
## [1] " Well its weird, its putting it at 70 because thats the median between the best bid and the best ask."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So the bid is 63 and the ask is 84-"
## [1] " Okay, so well lets call it a 70-"
## [1] " Okay call it a 70."
## [1] " the way this works is that if you believe Ethereum is going to be higher than 500 by the end of 2018, then you say yes, and if you get that price at $0.70, you have 1 share at $0.70 and if it is over $500 at the end of 2018, that $0.70 becomes $1. So you get 30%, so youre basically 1 to 2.6 or whatever."
## [1] " Okay, for people whos primary reference here is sports gambling, basically, if you think Ethereum is going to be over $500 at the end of 2018, you can bet 7 to win 10, and if you think its not, you can bet 3 to win 10."
## [1] " Yeah, thats a and the difference between a prediction market like Augur and sports betting is that you can sell your shares at any time, which is actually a because when you make a sports bet, its locked in. If you buy it at $0.30 to say no, right, so 3 to win 10, and Ethereum takes a huge tank and the price shifts to like 50/50, you can sell it at that. Youve make a 70% profit, you can sell it at that profit. Right there."
## [1] " And simultaneously, if you bet the no, and youre like wow, Ethereum is already over $1,000 and the line is now instead of 30%, 15% you could lose half of your stake there and sell it off then."
## [1] " Those are the basics. Obviously these types of markets exist in the United States, I think we talked about it last time on the show. But for those who werent listening, you can do this very legally in the United States, its not really considered gambling because its seen as academic research."
## [1] " How is that academic research?"
## [1] " Because its basically tied loosely to Political Science departments-"
## [1] " But you can put money on it?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " So I can go put money right now, legally in New York City on whether Donald Trump will win the next election?"
## [1] " Yes. For sure."
## [1] " Really? Online?"
## [1] " Yes. Online its all legal."
## [1] " Really?"
## [1] " The problem with prediction markets is that they have very high costs of withdrawal, which is what they do instead of charging a vig, which is what a sports book would do. They charge a withdrawal fee which, I dont remember what the percentage is, but its something that is completely prohibitive. And you have to be really good to beat that fee. The appeal of a decentralized prediction market is A that you can come up with any question that you want and get people to bet on it which is great, and that you dont have the withdrawal fee outside of whatever youre paying for the gas for the Ethereum network."
## [1] " Last week we talked about predictions.global, which is basically a web interface for Augur, in which you dont need to be logged in, you dont need to do anything. You can just look at the predictions. It does not, I will say, have nearly as rich information as actually being on Augur. You can see stuff once youre actually on Augur, like the volume of shares here-"
## [1] " This is for will Ethereum be over 500 at the end of 2018."
## [1] " Yes, 1400 shares. So that, each share represents one ETH."
## [1] " Okay so-"
## [1] " So that means 1400 ETH is whats been wagered."
## [1] " Which is about at this point like 7-"
## [1] " $642,000."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Okay? So, its a pretty good amount of money. Once you start getting into other markets on Augur, youll quickly find that theres almost no shares and no volume. But this seems to be the topic people have most closely grabbed onto. And also, I think this is going to be really interesting to look at, not so much now, because it hasnt been up very long, but you can basically look at what this question has been trading at at various historical periods."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " So, it looks like the percentage chance that ETH will be over $500 at the end of 2018 has been going up, starting closer to 50/50, creeping up to 70% now."
## [1] " Oh wow, so it started out at 50/50?"
## [1] " Yeah, well its a little hard, theres so little volume you cant really see where it is here. You can also see what the market depth is, looks like right now, its kind of stuck between.8 and.6. theres a lot of buy interest at.6 and a lot of sell interest at.8. thats for the yes market. Theres really like a full order book here in which you can see."
## [1] " Yeah. Thats because theres not much volume. As theres more volume, the price will become more normalized, I think."
## [1] " Okay, so Im a little confused Jay, you understand stuff a little better than I do. The only outcome listed here is yes. So if I want to put a no in here, then I sell the yes position?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Okay, so you can sell something that you dont have."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Unlike in a Crypto portfolio."
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " So if I want one share in no, I sell one share."
## [1] " Yeah and look, this is an extremely confusing way in which theyve done this. If you go on places like predict it, you just click yes or no and then it does it for you."
## [1] " I assume that they will make this UI more friendly to the amateur gambler as time-"
## [1] " Yeah. I mean, saying yes or no is not that difficult to put. But maybe we should have a no button. But yeah-"
## [1] " They also have multiple choice markers-"
## [1] " Sure. But you would think that putting no would make it a little bit easier, but I mean, we dont have to complain about that right now."
## [1] " So, another thing here, is they show you what the fee is. This fee is not the gas fee, the gas fee that you pay to Ethereum is on top of it. When I was trying to make new markets, the fee was about $1.70. This fee is a percentage based fee, which goes to the creator of the market and those who report on the outcome of the market to ensure its veracity."
## [1] " Oh okay, so this is like, for example in the futures bets on some of the more exotic online sports books for a while there was a bet on whether or not Danica Patrick and Aaron Rogers would break up by the end of 2017, I think it was?"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " And the terms for it was that, the break up had to be reported by TMZ."
## [1] " Oh okay."
## [1] " Yeah, so like instead of that, it seems like what Augur has done is created an incentivized democratic way of litigating whether or not this is true?"
## [1] " Yeah, and my understanding is that you can actually earn the native token of Augur, REP, Reputation by backing the right side. So if 100 people report on an issue and 98% of them are on one side and 2 are on the other side, then resolved to the 98 side and all 98 of those people get some small REP stake."
## [1] " Okay, heres a question then. Lets say that you and I put 15 ETH into this bet, which is more than you or I have, but lets say that were heavily leveraged into this bet."
## [1] " Jay do we have to put in 15 ETH for our very first bet? You degenerate."
## [1] " Why couldnt we just and we have like 500 friends who are also betting this market at a certain price, why couldnt we just, even if it doesnt go over $500, why couldnt we just vote the wrong issue? Or the wrong outcome as the outcome?"
## [1] " This is how I understand it to work, none of this is investment advice. Its also not gambling advice. Its not legal advice."
## [1] " Also we dont have 15 Ethereum, so please dont try and-"
## [1] " Its not advice about how to get the REP token by reporting incorrect answers on Augur. So I think it works sort of like a 51% attack. You actually, the people who are putting, you stake your own REP when you say what the outcome was. All of the people, once it becomes a majority, they, the people who picked the right side, steal the REP from the people who were repping the wrong side. So if you and your friends got together and tried to brute force the untrue outcome, an even larger group of Augur people could come on and put in the right outcome and they would then win your REP because they were right. If you have the 51%, good man. But thats kind of generally how all Crypto stuff works, is if you can get a large enough pool of people to try to defraud it, you could do it."
## [1] " So, like were dealing with extremely metaphysical questions about truth-"
## [1] " Yeah, yeah."
## [1] " If you get enough people to say that something is not true, that is true and you have money on it, then you can actually make that the actual outcome-"
## [1] " Yes."
## [1] " as it relates to this specific bet."
## [1] " But, this is an interesting topic which is, I had always thought, have you owned the Augur token?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " Okay, I own some Augur, some REP. I thought that I would be betting with that REP. Not true. All of the bets are made and settled with Ethereum, REP is only used in this verification rewards system."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Which brings up a question I want to ask later when we have our good friend Ledger on, which is, why is the REP token going to go up in value if this is popular?"
## [1] " Yeah thats a good question. Like all ERC tokens, it seems like they were a little bit vague about what it actually did at the beginning and what it actually does is it facilitates actions within inner layer things within the product. Which is how most ERC pointed tokens actually work if you look at the use case for it. Not that compelling to me, Ive got to say."
## [1] " So, lets look at this market. Its the most popular market, its got the most liquidity. What do we want to come in here on this ETH over $500 dollars at the end of 2018 issue?"
## [1] " Okay, so you and I have talked about this for the past three days and we have decided that we should bet no, on basically every single Crypto bet, we should take the bear-ish position on almost all this."
## [1] " We should act like some no coiners, basically."
## [1] " Yeah and the reason for that-"
## [1] " We should hate on Crypto."
## [1] " is that theres three things that I think are happening here just from studying it in a very cursory way. The first is that a lot of the biggest markets seem to be have created by people who are somehow linked to Augur, so the second most popular market is will the REP token be over $32 by the end of 2018?"
## [1] " That would make sense. This is one of the promises of Augur is that we can have an options market for any coin ever. Sumo coin could have its own future market."
## [1] " Im surprised that you havent started an Augur on Coinbase market. I think that theres a lot of people that are incentivized on saying yes. The Bitcoin Crypto community is extremely bull-ish by nature and probably over confident in prices. I think this would be similar to saying if you had a prediction market that said oh and the last thing being that almost everyone who used Augur is definitely heavy into Crypto."
## [1] " To take that idea even further, were basically saying that Augur users are probably on tilt. Right?"
## [1] " Oh yeah."
## [1] " I would believe that theres some-"
## [1] " Perma tilts."
## [1] " Some Bitcoin haters in the mix, but I think youre going to see a lot of ETH fans."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " This is a ERC 20 token, its been it rapidly shot up to be one of the most used Ethereum apps within the first couple days it was out. This market, this first market should be one of the most tilty markets on here."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " The sort of long Ethereum market."
## [1] " And the way that prediction markets and actually any betting works is that large bets swing the number proportionally, so if 200 people bet one Ethereum, and one guy bets 200 Ethereum, they have the same exact effect. I imagine that as this thing started, just like Cryptokitties, just like Crypto Art Auctions, theres some whales who want to see this thing work just because not because they think theyre going to even make money off the bet, but because they want these thing to be healthy because its better for the entire ecosystem-"
## [1] " Right."
## [1] " I cannot imagine that any of those people would vote no. I think we probably have some whales who are betting yes just to sort of seed this thing. I think the best option would be to go against them"
## [1] " Right, okay. So, the fact that theres this big spread between the ask and the bid, if we put in a bid here for a no, or if we put in a if we sell in order to get-"
## [1] " Yeah we sell some yes-"
## [1] " no shares. Does someone else have to take the other side of that bet for it to-"
## [1] " I dont know how this one works. But generally if you use a prediction market all those mechanics are done without you having to worry about it."
## [1] " Right, okay."
## [1] " So what are we gonna do here? Are we shorting Ethereum here?"
## [1] " Well the weird thing, are you holding any Ethereum?"
## [1] " No."
## [1] " See, Ive got Ethereum in my bag, so I guess if I bet Ethereum under $500, Im basically hedging-"
## [1] " Yeah. But youre hedging at a good percentage. If we can get the price at like $0.30 to $1, and it goes up to $0.80 a dollar, then youve done basically what almost 2.6 something to 1 which is a great hedge because youre getting that extra value in there."
## [1] " Okay. So let me ask you a couple of questions about that. Do we worry that Ethereum is going to be at 502 on January 1st and were going to get double REPS?"
## [1] " Thats a disaster for us, but Im not so worried that it will be at 502."
## [1] " Okay, let me ask you one more question. 500 nice round number, a lot of people are looking at Ethereum 500 the way that we used to look at Bitcoin 10,000, you know?"
## [1] " Are they though? I mean, Ethereums already gone up to like 1200."
## [1] " Heres what Im saying. If its December 31st and Ethereums sitting at 497-"
## [1] " Yeah, I think that were in trouble."
## [1] " are some bull-tards going to come together and look at it and say we can rack a bunch of these shorts by getting it over 500?"
## [1] " I dont know. Because if there was lets say that there was 500,000 Ethereum in this market, then I would say maybe there is some-"
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " fear of that, but right now were at 1400 Ethereum."
## [1] " But this only launched this week and theres 1400 shares. I mean, this may get more and more popular."
## [1] " The market cap of Ethereum is enough where Im not so worried about that."
## [1] " Heres what were going to do. Were going to act like idiots right now, and then were going to call Ledger and get him to tell us everything we did wrong."
## [1] " Okay."
## [1] " Okay so, Im going to say our bet, Ethereum is currently sitting at Ethereum is at 468. Okay? So, if we bet it right now, and we bet, lets say.05, thats like $20 worth of Ethereum."
## [1] " I think Id go heavier."
## [1] " For our introductory dumb bet, we have to make it bigger? We just described how we were probably doing this wrong."
## [1] " Lets do at least.1."
## [1] " Im reimbursing myself out of show funds for this. Okay, so-"
## [1] " Tax deductible."
## [1] " so if you put in.1 on the sell side, it automatically inputs the bid price, which is only.63, even though weve been quoted a 70% median price."
## [1] " Oh wow, that sucks. Can we change that? Theres a little clicky bar over there."
## [1] " Lets see, can we change it to.70? But will-"
## [1] " Yeah someone has to take that then."
## [1] " Someone has to take that. So were basically just yeah. And then theres a check box for fill orders only."
## [1] " What was the default? Lets go with the default."
## [1] " Default was off."
## [1] " Okay so lets go with default because we dont know what were doing."
## [1] " Okay then were going to hit review. So okay, so this is good. If we win, this bet, we will make a 233% profit."
## [1] " All right!"
## [1] " Yeah, look if we lose this bet, we will lose our entire share which is.075 ETH."
## [1] " So were getting plus 230 on our money which is a pretty good price."
## [1] " But we dont know if this is actually going to work, because we just quoted a higher price [crosstalk 00:28:19]."
## [1] " Lets see what happens."
## [1] " Okay, so then you click confirm and then it opens a Metamask window. So it looks like were going to pay $1.60 transaction fee and Im sending $36 in ETH,.07. All right, here we go."
## [1] " Did it work?"
## [1] " It says order placed."
## [1] " Okay, so we dont have it yet."
## [1] " No, someones hey if youre listening-"
## [1] " Yeah someone buy our-"
## [1] " and youre some kind of an ETH head-"
## [1] " Someone buy our action please."
## [1] " [crosstalk 00:28:48]"
## [1] " Yeah. Okay lets see what we did wrong."
## [1] " Yeah."
## [1] " Hey, Ledger. AKA Brian."
## [1] " Is it okay to call you Brian on is it okay to use your government name in this Crypto broadcasting space?"

## [1] " It felt very much like someone from Augur had gotten to Aaron to explain that this was a really easy process. I was like this seems impossible."
## [1] " Lets do it."
## [1] " Thank you Brian, I was thinking that a couple days ago when we first talked about this, that it wouldnt be that hard to just even make an app, you know like it doesnt even have to be a phone app. Like a browser in which you could just hit yes or no and it would be really easy. I dont understand why that doesnt exist, because it would make the launch a lot more exciting because you wouldnt have to go through all these difficult processes. It would actually make the markets bigger, which I think would probably entice more people to trust it to actually put money into it."
## [1] " So the number one market, youll be unsurprised that the first things to catch on here are Crypto currency futures and the biggest market is for Ethereum. So the bet is, will the price of Ethereum exceed $500 at the end of 2018?"
## [1] " That turns out not to be true. So-"
## [1] " there was well it sort of ranges between 63 and 83?"
## [1] " It actually reminds me of a sneaker sales and buys. If you try and get a specific type of sneaker and there isnt much market for it, but its a pretty rare sneaker that youll see such a wide range between the bids and the asks that it makes the like you could get it from anywhere between like lets say $240 and like $490 it just depends on the luck of what you actually get. The spread in this does sort of reflect any type of market that doesnt have that much volume in it."
## [1] " So, we could have just bought at 63. 63 is the bid thats just sitting out there. We didnt want that, so we put in a 70. Lets just pretend someone takes our 70-"
## [1] " Brian, youre the no side of 70."
## [1] " Were taking the no side, do you want to take the other side? Hows your progress on downloading the Ethereum block chain over there?"
## [1] " Okay, so the theory then, like the way the prediction markets work is that youre saying that at some point Ethereum will be like $520, and that many more bull-ish people will get into this market. And that it will go from like 70 say if you bought it at 70, to 80 and that you would sell at the 10% profit there. You would see a profit opportunity there because you felt like the second it goes over 500, people will feel some combination of bull-ishness and confirmation bias, and theyll say it will never go under 500 at this point. They would buy into the yes side."
## [1] " Where else would someone be able to make a bet like this on Ethereum?"
## [1] " Yeah. So is that how most people play these kind of markets? Not as Im going to sit on this, hold all this share until January 1st and either win or lose. But most people are looking at them as an asset that they intend to trade, buy, sell over the course of that period?"
## [1] " Its like $0.99 an ear."
## [1] " Its like $0.99 an ear right now, at the supermarket near my house."
## [1] " A famous example of that is airlines do that with the price of gas."
## [1] " Or the price of crude oil. They hedge themselves again increases in the price of airline fuel."
## [1] " Brian, so one thing that is interesting to me here, when I was thinking about this in the idea of making your own market. That the biggest opportunities and the biggest thing that was interesting to me was what you said, is that you could find these arbitrage opportunities. The problem with exotics in sports betting or just general betting is that they cap the action on it."
## [1] " Sure."
## [1] " Heres the scenario that Aaron and I talked about a little bit, which is that if all the yes or no, for example basically if truth is weeded out by REP tokens and like 51%, so if Donald Trump loses, you could actually vote theoretically that he won. And that you would win that bet, right? What would prevent somebody for example then, to basically place like 5,000 random markets that only a few people will be interested in that they might eventually even forget that they were a part of, hoard REP tokens and then use that to win every single one of those bets even if you lost it? Theres all these weird opportunities for cheating in something thats this decentralized, where it does seem easier to just have somebody being like, nope, Donald Trump actually lost the election or won the election, whatever the truth is."

## [1] " The case is essentially that most of the people who buy this see it as a security for a new company and that they dont understand that the token itself is not what we are vaguely saying that the token might be. I find that to be a little bit scammy, gotta say."

## [1] " But if you have $600 million, the most work youre going to do is to get from zero to $600 million. To get from $600 million to like $1.2 billion, youre not going to do as much work. I guess thats my point."
